body: Right now Greek life is pretty underground after the University made it against the rules for freshman to even be in a Greek house. The Greeks are not recognized by the University at this time.
author: Freshman

body: Freshmen and Sophomores aren't allocated any on-campus parking space. Juniors and Seniors must pay a fee to be allowed to park on campus.
author: Sophomore

body:
There is no parking on campus. At all.
The nearest parking lot is usually crowded, and several blocks away from the rest of campus.  If you need to get around in a hurry, bring your bike.
And underclassmen can't even  live off campus or have cars, so that kind of tells you what it's like.
author: Student

body: 98-99% of all undergraduates live on campus. Enough said.
author: Student

body: Greek life is not really recognized by the university and not really a part of student life.
author: Freshman

body: I don't know anyone who lives off-campus because it's expensive and not widely available.
author: Sophomore

body: Princeton needs more true diversity.
author: Alum

body: If you like non-bland food, late meal will be your only salvation. Dining hall food sucks. Eating club food is sometimes good but sometimes sucks too.
author: Alum

body: Speaking specifically about alcohol: once the weekend comes, it's almost everywhere. Whether in its physical form or if a student is talking about it. Pregaming is almost the rule. Fortunately, most of it is in a designated location (Prospect) with the exception of students who stash in their room. If you get caught with alcohol, you will probably be given a warning.
author: Sophomore

body: Greek life is pretty non-existant. Apparently there at 12 Frats, but only two are considered "cool." Most people see Frats/sororities as a gateway to a certain more exclusive eating club.
author: Freshman

body: I happen to live in one residential "college" that I was randomly placed in. I am a mile from my nearest class and as a second year student share a 180 sq. ft. double with a roommate. I pay the same rooming fee as someone who lives in central campus with a 300 sq. ft. single.
author: Freshman

body: Everyone lives on campus; there are good facilities and locations for upperclassmen
author: Freshman

body: Your experience with computers will definitely depend on where you are. I live in Whitman College, and we have a library downstairs. However, during peak seasons, the library is always crowded, and you'll be lucky if the two media macs are available. I usually go to Butler, because there are less people. Their computers also work better. In the Whitman Library, computers sometimes freeze up while I'm trying to print.
author: Freshman

body: There's a Lot of Drinking – The drinking at Princeton is comparable to that of state school students.
author: Freshman

body: Limited Selection – There's very few choices for off campus housing, and they are more expensive compared to on- campus housing. Most students live on campus.
author: Sophomore

body: P-Safe Can Be Tough – Public safety, if they catch you, will be strict. While you are safe on the Street or walking around campus drunk, DO NOT ever drink outside. Drinking in your room is safe, provided you are never caught with a drink in your hand. As for parties in dorms, make sure that there are no drugs (if drugs are found, everyone at the party gets punished), but feel safe going to one. P-safe doesn't come too often, usually only in cases of extreme noise. Just don't get caught with a drink in your hand, and you are fine.
author: Sophomore

body: Housing Horrors – The far flung outskirts of Princeton are home to a smattering of houses and their dreary denizens will tell you that it is both expensive and inconvenient. Dorm housing, though under the beady eye of the administration, is far more prudent.
author: Freshman

body: Some of the buildings are very old. The buildings known as "the slums" have tons of cockroaches. You do not really have a choice of where you get placed your first two years, and there is a wide variety of quality of the dorms.
author: Alum

body: There is barely any Greek life presence on campus since the University does not really recognize the groups. Most people are not involved in Greek life and it usually won't have an effect on the social scene.
author: Sophomore

body: Princeton doesn't have much of a dating culture, especially early on in college careers. That's not to say that there aren't relationships, because there are but they are less common than just hookups (whatever you perceive that to be). The guys and girls here are okay. There's a rather negative perception that all Princeton students are "preppy" but that's really not the case. People are pretty approachable here and although you may find that some people are a bit into themselves, there are plenty of people who are willing to talk or socialize (either platonically or romantically).
author: Freshman

body: Princeton doesn't really have Greek Life in the traditional sense. It's quite low-key and the Eating Clubs replace it in many ways- the parties occur in the Eating Clubs and they carry the same sense of exclusivity that Greek Life would. There are traces of Greek Life but as an underclassman I almost have no experience with it. Definitely not a big thing on the Princeton campus.
author: Freshman

body: The town of Princeton isn't exactly known for its affordability. I usually stick with places like Panera and Qdoba just because those are pretty inexpensive. Other places on Nassau Street are a tad bit more expensive and seem to be more catered to tourists rather than Princeton students themselves. Many people save off-campus dining for special occasions. I hardly know anyone who goes to Nassau Street on a regular basis.
author: Freshman

body: Princeton school spirit could be better. It seems as if only the Princeton University Band and the sports teams themselves really care about the athletics. Princeton isn't really big on sports but performs well against several of the other Ivies.
author: Freshman

body: our sports teams are definitely good but we don't go to the games unless it's ivyleague vs. ivyleague (like Princeton v. Yale or Princeton v Yale)
author: Freshman

body: they are okay. Decent show up for most games, bust should be more
author: Senior

body: Students rarely eat off campus. The dining services provided by the school don't leave you wanting anything more.
author: Freshman

body: Princeton has a little bubble. So other than the main street right by campus, most people don't notice the city that we're in. If anything, a student may take the Saturday shopping bus to go run a couple errands, but that's it.
author: Freshman

body: Low school spirit. Low attendance at football games. Gym is relatively small for class size.
author: Freshman

body: I have not been to much parties but from what I know the party scene could be better and its not my style because there is lots of alcohol.
author: Junior

body: Greek life is practically non existent at Princeton.
author: Alum

body: Not too bad.  Its not as happening as a big 10 school.
author: Senior

body: Depends on where you live.  There is really great housing, but also some locations are on the older side.
author: Senior

body: Princeton is a good example of a quiet little Northeastern town.
author: Sophomore

body: Our health services are very supportive towards students.
author: Sophomore

body: Nobody cares about them, typically players/coaches aren't very good, and the facilities are subpar.
author: Sophomore

body: I've no idea about anything that happens at Columbia University concerning Greek Life
author: Junior

body: No one cares about football, and while other sports have their specific followings, there's really not a single sport that unites the school. Sports really aren't that big of a deal at Columbia.
author: Freshman

body: Took away my grant halfway through Freshman year.
author: Junior

body: Choosing Columbia if you care about school sports in any fashion is a terrible idea. However you have plenty of professional sports in NYC
author: Sophomore

body: There was no scholarship or aid opportunity other than FAFSA for the program I am in.
author: Alum

body: I would have liked and probably taken part in a dining plan for summer students.
author: Alum

body: Not worn your time not worth your time not worth your time
author: Sophomore

body: No one parks here. If you commute, you take the public transportation. Parking lots are absurd if you're staying for longer than a day.
author: Sophomore

body: As a member of the cheerleading squad, I witness just how poor the school spirit is weekly. The basketball games are well-attended (meaning people actually show up) but football always has more parents or alumnae than students watching the game. Because the school is so academically focused, athletes are looked down upon as only getting in due to their athletic capabilities and not because of their academic intelligence.
author: Sophomore

body: It's New York City. You should leave the car at home, you absolutely will not need it. There is no parking provided by the university, so you're stuck to parking on the street.
author: Freshman

body: At least in the law school, and this isn't fairly uncommon, scholarships are hard to come by. You either get them when you are admitted or you don't get them at all. There are also very few of them to begin with.
author: Sophomore

body: Words can't describe the amount of vitriol students have for Columbia athletics. Personally, I find it tasteless; as much as Columbia students like to express their tolerance for all walks of life, they're unrelentingly critical of those who find a passion in sports.
author: Sophomore

body: New York City is definitely not a place that welcomes car owners. There is absolutely no need to have a car in the city. If you do decide to have a car, expect to pay a second rent just to park and maintain the car.
author: Junior

body:
There are athletics at Columbia?

If you like gigantic, overcrowded gyms, Columbia's Dodge Fitness Center is the place for you...
author: Sophomore

body: It gets very, very cold here. Walkways become slippery and it can sometimes be hard walking to classes if you don't have shoes with grip. Also, the buildings act like wind tunnels and if you don't have the right gear you will freeze. When it isn't freezing, such as the summer months, it is very hot! and if you don't have AC or a fan in your room it turns into a sauna. The only upside is the cool fall and spring months.
author: Freshman

body: Living in New York, university housing is undoubtably the best possible options for students in terms of convenience and especially cost. There are university owned apartments available outside the main morningside heights campus, however, I don't know anyone who would spend the outrageous amount of money on non University housing in New York.
author: Freshman

body: I'm by no means an athlete, but even I wish the facilities were better. A combination of not having the space for adequate athletic facilities in Morningside Heights and general malaise for anything that makes student life better on the part of the administration contribute to the lackluster facilities. The teams are mostly not great, but athletes work hard, and if you really want to, you can be involved.
author: Sophomore

body: The school is extremely bad at most sports.  One sport that we excel in is fencing, but almost nobody watches that.  Columbia did win a basketball championship as well. And baseball is great too. But our football is among the worst in the country.  Almost nobody attends the sports games, either.
author: Freshman

body: We are not good at sports. That is not why we come here. But, if you pay attention, and don't believe in the stereotypes, they're awesome.
author: Freshman

body: I wasn't interested and didn't pay much attention and that wasn't a unique attitude on campus.
author: Alum

body: The campus and staff don't seem to do anything specifically to address the issue of campus rape.
author: Freshman

body: Even if the team is good and/or successful almost no one on campus will care about them or go to any of the events.
author: Freshman

body: Most of the companies that showed up for events were interested in market themselves, not recruit. If you are an international student, it is very, very hard to get an internship. Me and a friend applied for some 80 internship positions last Spring We had no answers at all.
author: Alum

body: Columbia, pretty much like the other Ivy universities doesn't care about getting athlete students to make consistent sport teams. Not a problem to me. Sports facilities were OK, pool was closed during the whole summer though. Even being a summer researcher, they made me pay to use the facilities during that period.
author: Alum

body: As a man, I feel incredibly safe walking just about anywhere on campus (and in the city). However, I don't like letting female friends walk home alone, just out of concern for safety, especially if the dorm is off-campus. Campus police are noticeably present, however, which helps.
author: Freshman

body: NYC housing sucks and it always will.
author: Alum

body: There's nothing in the area. You have to travel somewhere for it to really be worth it.
author: Alum

body: Only speaking for the medical campus. There isn't a lot of diversity.
author: Alum

body: I'm only speaking for the Public Health administration. It's very disorganized and sometimes they are quite rude.
author: Alum

body: They don't give enough aid and you have to fight them to increase work study stipends.
author: Alum

body: Minnesota weather is not for the weak! DO NOT come here if you cannot handle the cold!
author: Freshman
name: Macalester College

body: I'm from California and am not used to this... just going outside hurts and they don't cancel classes for weather. I'm told that this year was unusually bad though, so it's definitely manageable if you're okay with being inside all the time.
author: Freshman
name: Macalester College

body:
Leaving Minnesota ASAP! I never grew up with winter. Not a real winter, anyway (just a grey, chilly mess and occasional snow/city shutdown in Washington DC). So I really had no concept of what the winter would be like here, and figured it would be like an extended version of what I'd already experienced. I was wrong. 

The winter is miserable here. There's just no other way to put it. It's just so long, and SO much colder than I ever thought it could be... To be fair, the transitional seasons before and after the winter are beautiful. It's just too bad that unless you live in the Twin Cities over the summer, you only experience a month or two of that beautiful weather, at best.
author: Senior
name: Macalester College

body: Not So Great. Most Macalester parties are broken up by midnight and honestly don't get very exciting.  People drink, they get sick, and that's about it.  Many students (including students who enjoy partying) complain that Macalester parties are not so great especially students who are under 21.  There are night clubs in Saint Paul/Minneapolis but I can't say I have much experience with those.
author: Senior
name: Macalester College

body: Didn't Like It. Dupre wasn't great.  The building is old and the floors are stained.  RAs don't really have the authority to do anything about noise, drama, alcoholism, bullying, or anything else.  The school staff (including deans) don't do much about these issues either.  The policies in effect don't really allow anyone to do much of anything about bullying.  Dorm life was very cliquey and it was hard to get much sleep with the noise.  Macalester also has a "gender house" in Kirk designed for students wishing to explore issues of gender and sexuality.  It is a joke.  Most of the kids who applied for it the first year were rising sophomores who just wanted an excuse to live in upperclassmen dorms and drink without getting caught by RAs.  Frequently both toilets would have vomit on them so there would be no real way to go to the bathroom until a janitor arrived.  Complaints about this did nothing to help the situation.  It was loud enough to be a super bowl night at two a.m. on weeknights and was fairly ridiculous.  I have also heard that the Veggie Co-Op is incredibly cliquey and is kind of the closest thing we have to a sorority or a fraternity.  Most people living there aren't actually even vegetarians or vegans, but are simply living there to be closer to friends and not have to be on the meal plan.  For the most part, Kirk is alright but it is unfortunate to live in if you have a single because you won't have access to lounge space unless you have gracious friends willing to invite you over.
author: Senior
name: Macalester College

body: Who Drives? Most people don't drive. If you do, there are stories about getting fake parking tickets by Macalester security, which you don't have to really pay. There's not much parking though, which encourages students not to drive.
author: Senior
name: Macalester College

body: Small school small parties same people. Eventually get bored and tired (me, at least). First years tend to be a little crazy and try to be all hardcore. Some gatherkngs may be more exclusive than others, say athlete parties but if you don't mind the cross contamination inthise circles, go for it. But really, it's a small, small school. I suggestyou make some friends off campus or at the U who can get access into frat parties and the like if you're into that.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: Minnesota winters suck! But a warm coat makes all the difference…the longest walk to class (across campus) is 7 minutes. If you dress for it, you'll be fine.
author: Freshman
name: Macalester College

body: The athletics program is really building and really great but only other athletes go to games and support each other.
author: Junior
name: Macalester College

body: Our cafeteria is too small for how many people eat at the prime meal times. Also, the food is good but so unhealthy. I lost 15 pounds just from not eating at the cafeteria (even when i was eating very healthy options there!).
author: Junior
name: Macalester College

body: Most drug use is smoking pot.  Things are hardly enforced and when they are, you don't get in much trouble.
author: Alum
name: Macalester College

body: Parking is pretty difficult to find and there are lots of problems with cars being towed during the winter snowplowing months.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: The underclassmen dorms are horrible but at least the RAs are nice.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: Cold and Humid – MN is known to be the coldest state in the US. It snows ALL the time, and we end up having to cancel a few classes here and there.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: Point of Bonding – The weather sucks from November to March/April, but when there's remotely decent weather, Mac kids make the most of it. Plus, the campus is so small and most of the dorms are connected, so you don't have to spend too much time outside if you don't want to.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: Cold, but Not Horrible – It is really cold here and snows a ton, but it doesn't inhibit the social scene.  Also, dorms are close to campus and campus is small, so its not that big of a deal.
author: Freshman
name: Macalester College

body: Can Be a Buzzkill, If You're Not Careful – RAs tend to only care about one thing: noise.  If you're being loud, they will come and bust you, and then write you up for drinking/smoking/whatever it is that you're doing.  Consequences are pretty light until it happens multiple times.  The police on the other hand have been cracking down on off-campus parties.  I know students that have been fined for noise violations and having underage drinking in their homes.  Just watch where you go and be a good neighbor, and it shouldn't ever be a problem.
author: Senior
name: Macalester College

body: I do applaud the campus dining for having vegan options.  What frustrated me a bit was the insistence that "taking too much" would induce waste.  Oftentimes they would give you less than a cup of pasta and you'd have to come back multiple times to get a full helping of it.  If pasta was the only thing you liked that day, it would take a very long time to get fed and if you needed to get in, eat, and get out you might not really end up full.
author: Senior
name: Macalester College

body: No Strong Opinions Either Way. If you have any kind of mental health or medical issue that might require you to miss more than two classes per semester, don't expect a lot of understanding.  Courses are interesting (in some cases) but few were life-changing or particularly exciting for me personally.
author: Senior
name: Macalester College

body: Parking is not the best at Mac since there is not availability of parking spaces unless you want to walk 10 minutes from the dorms to the Janet Wallace parking. It doesn't affect much of the students because it is strongly encouraged that students not bring cars and the public transportation is pretty reliable.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: The gymnasium is open to all, athlete or not.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: It really depends on the dorm. Some are great, some aren't.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: There are a lot of athletes on campus, but only the athletes pay any attention to sports. Intramurals are much more popular.
author: Sophomore
name: Macalester College

body: Housing is pretty average across the board. A large chunk of the dorms have sinks, which is awesome, and the options improve a lot after the first year. Also, the water pressure is amazing.
author: Freshman
name: Macalester College

body: There wasn't a huge amount of on-campus crime, but laptops and bikes were stolen fairly frequently. Nothing violent though. Security could be a pain in the butt because they take their job very seriously sometimes, but I didn't have a lot of run-ins with them.
author: Junior
name: Macalester College

body: Macalester isn't well known even though it's a near-Ivy, so it's not like you can exactly name-drop. A degree is a degree; no one actually cares where you went to undergrad. There were job and internship prospects available, but they certainly weren't ubiquitous and I didn't see many employers recruiting on campus.
author: Junior
name: Macalester College

body: Living in Dupre my freshman year kind of sucked because the rooms are tiny, ugly, and of poor quality. Also the communal bathrooms are gross and not comfortable to be in. It is the farthest dorm from campus and can feel like a haul in the freezing Minnesota winters. There was a great social atmosphere though. I lived in Bigelow the next year, and my room was much nicer. It had a sink and cabinet, and it was a much cozier room. No one talked to each other on my floor though, but that is maybe just sophomores regardless of where they live.
author: Junior
name: Macalester College

body: People really like clubs and intramurals there, and I think that's where a lot of the focus is. Competitive, high-profile athletics are just not really important there. The varsity teams are all DIII, and kind of suck. I played tennis, and the coach was terrible in that he put a lot of pressure on us and had high expectations when we were all really there to have fun and be part of a team. I also don't think there's a huge variety of sports to choose from.
author: Junior
name: Macalester College

body: jDont have much experience with it.
author: Freshman
name: Macalester College

body: The administration here is horrible. They are the most fake group of people I've ever had to interact with. They appear to care about the students, and want to act like they care, but when students reach out to them they don't help and don't care.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: The night life here is depressing and pathetic. Every weekend people get their hopes up that there will be good parties but every time we are let down one weekend after another. People don't like to enjoy themselves here and criticize those that do. The only way to have a real good time is to go into Boston. The ONLY parties at Babson are in the suites in Mccollough which are always overcrowded and not enjoyable.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: The food here is absolutely disgusting. Being gluten free they run out of gluten free food most of the time. There were many instances where I had absolutely 0 dining options and had to order from local restaurants to deliver to me. This schools food is so gross. They serve rice just about every day, and not one time was the rice somewhat decent. It is always crunchy and poorly cooked. Everyone here hates trim food, and Reynolds is slightly better, but being gluten free is hard because the people who work here usually can't speak English or understand what I'm saying when I tell them there can't be gluten in my food. Trim not to mention is just one disappointment after another with few options and poor food to begin with.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: The campus housing experience I had was horrible. I was put in a forced triple even though the school claimed it was a regular triple. It was a substance free dorm even though I didn't apply to live there. There was another room in my dorm where two people lived and it was bigger than my triple. Not to mention that whenever we filed work orders for the maintenance people to fix something it either took weeks or they just didn't show up. The microwave was broken for 3 months despite the RA filing several work orders. And even when the maintenance people did come, they wouldn't tell you when they were coming so they just showed up and if you weren't there at the time they just left. Not to mention the bathrooms get disgusting over the weekends because they don't clean them from Friday to Sunday.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: Admin doesn't care about students. It's an oligarchy
author: Senior
name: Babson College

body: no reason to be scared
author: Sophomore
name: Babson College

body: not really big in this school
author: Sophomore
name: Babson College

body: Recieved no financial aid and the financial aid department was not willing to  change financial aid packages.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: Honor code violations, drug possession, and underage alcohol possession can get you into a lot of trouble
author: Junior
name: Babson College

body: Trim SUCKS – The food at Trim is horrible, repetitive selection and early hours
author: Sophomore
name: Babson College

body: sometimes they cancel the shuttle and don't even tell us
author: Senior
name: Babson College

body: Let's be real, I have never gone to a sporting event here, nor have I ever heard of anyone going ti a sporting event. My high school have more spirit.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: No indoor tennis courts, exclusive facilities for varsity athletes only, very disappointed with not being able to access these facilities. I pay $60k+ and don't get to use them? Come on, what is that...
author: Sophomore
name: Babson College

body: Babson has its own distinct party culture. Campus police shut down any large scale parties, so drinking usually happens in dorm rooms in the beginning of the night. Upperclassmen suites will open up for dancing (though they are not roomy at all), especially during the spring for SODA season (Seniors out drinking again). After spring break, there is a party in a senior suite every night until finals, each one a different theme. About a third of the school regularly goes out on campus, and drinks pretty heavily. Another third goes clubbing in Boston, and the rest don't really go out. Many people find it hard to manage the courseload and party extensively.
author: Junior
name: Babson College

body: Not much partying and Babo break up the few parties that happen.
author: Alum
name: Babson College

body: The coaching structure here at Babson is poor. The varsity gym shouldn't even be considered a gym due to their lack of necessary workout equipment.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: There are not many options close to Babson. The only housing available is usually at least 15 or 20 minutes away, unless you're going to live in Wellesley which is extremely expensive.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: There are many good options available locally. However there aren't any late night places except for Domino's.During other hours there are dining options but they're all very expensive.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: All places close early and far and few in between.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: Wellesley is expensive, so off campus housing is not feasible on a college budget.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: ugly campus, too many trees
author: Sophomore
name: Babson College

body: There is no Babson Spirit and this directly effecting campus life and the lack of support to athletic events.
author: Junior
name: Babson College

body: Within the past 4 years there have been two fraternities kick-ed off campus and student life happiness has overall decreased in huge steps.
author: Junior
name: Babson College

body: There should be more variety with the food.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: You can smell the alcohol and drugs in the residential halls.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: There isn't a lot of nightlife on my campus because many of the events tend to occur off campus and in the city.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: There are supposed to be big snow storms.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: There isn't much to do because the town is remote and the towns people do not tend to interact with the students on campus.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: It all depends on who you know and what you consider to be fun, the college doesn't put on too many parties but there are plenty of students who will throw them in their dorms or suites
author: Junior
name: Babson College

body: You'll find an abundance of hard drug users if you really get to know people, but its never forced upon anyone
author: Sophomore
name: Babson College

body: I haven't been to a single athletic event but then again it's only the second week of school so who knows. I am surprised that there's an actual gym here. They have workout sessions as well if you want to join.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: There is really no separation between greeks and non-greeks. Most greeks don't live in greek housing.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: The athletic center is not the best, but I always have great workouts there.
author: Sophomore
name: Babson College

body: I dont have much experience with Greek life
author: Senior
name: Babson College

body: School spirit is pretty important at Babson and students enjoy attending athletic events
author: Senior
name: Babson College

body: It's expensive, especially since you'll need a car to commute to campus. Most wealthy international students live off campus in Cambridge, most domestic students stay on campus.
author: Junior
name: Babson College

body: Trim has improved and now has grilled chicken during weekday lunches in the salad bar. Guests can use host swipes. It's possible to be healthy and eat the campus food, but everyone tries to cook and eat off campus as much as they can.
author: Junior
name: Babson College

body: There's one new freshman dorm, and many other dorms are getting renovated. The campus is small so everything is within a 15 min walk. Room size can vary, but most people are satisfied with the amount of space they have. Singles are hard to come by until junior/senior year. Most dorms have slightly distinct cultures and there is a "party" dorm for each grade. For freshman it's Forrest, for sophomores it's Putney, for juniors/seniors it's Pietz and McCoullough.
author: Junior
name: Babson College

body: Not much of a social life
author: Alum
name: Babson College

body: Babson claims to have great alumni connections, but as a student looking to reach out to one it was nearly impossible. In attempting to seek funds for a business I was starting I assumed the school would be able to connect me to Babson grads but despite my multiple attempts, no one could connect me with a single Alumni. There are many job opportunities but you must have a high GPA to get them, if you don't have a high GPA you don't stand much of a chance.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: Seems to be decent. The few people that are in them enjoy it.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: There are some places that are decently close to campus and buses.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: Hockey is the only amazing sport here, they're pretty good. Other than that, sports are not that big as we are DIII school.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: Greek life for some people is life. For me I do not want to nor plan on being part of a sorority.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: The usual is Lemon Thai, Dominos, Nick's Pizza, Comella's. Alot of food delivery options in nearby towns that deliver to Wellesley.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: Dorms are pretty nice, and pretty specious.
author: Freshman
name: Babson College

body: CU Housing – New york is hard to find apartments. Cooper Union is a free tuition school which i appreciate, but more assistance in housing should be open to all.
author: Senior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: There aren't many options for athletic teams and there are no athletic facilities.
author: Junior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: I don't know much about the sports in my school.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: The snack bar serves lunch boxes and chicken sandwiches among other items. Other than that, you will need to venture outside for food.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: It's a tiny cafeteria that has some sub par bagels, coffee & lunch options. If you want anything substantial/ (or just better..) to eat you can just leave the building & cross the street.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: There are no facilities (as far as I know) There are some sports teams that you can participate in but nobody takes them seriously.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: There's one small fraternity. They live in a 2 story apartment on the lower east side about 10 blocks away from the dorms & they throw parties sometimes. It's pretty low-key and they are integrated into the rest of the community.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: While the dorms are good and close to the school, there are only dorms for the first year.  After that students must either find an apartment in NYC or commute
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Lack of Dining Hall – There is one small dining kitchen that is not your typical dining hall.  That aside, dining in Manhattan is as good as it gets.
author: Alum
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: No Real Sports Teams – There are only a few recognized sports teams at Cooper: Basketball, Tennis, Handball, Volleyball, Soccer, and Baseball(just started this year).  The women sports also seem to be the same people recycled over and over.
author: Senior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Parking spaces are very difficult to find around Cooper. We don't have a parking lot so you need to park on the street and almost all of the time, most of the spaces are already filled up. If you park in a space that needs to be cleared for street cleaning, you get fined a pretty sizable amount. You don't need a car on campus at all. Most people walk to school or take the subway. The people who live on Long Island or in New Jersey take the train.
author: Sophomore
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: There have been very few incidents that were made known to the students about health and safety issues that had happened, so we don't actually know statistically. The school doesn't let that information out.
author: Alum
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Student housing could be better, it's only available to freshmen and afterwards everyone is left to find something on their own in very expensive New York City.
author: Alum
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Only one fraternity on campus, they aren't very active in making parties but do some charity work and fundraising during the school year.
author: Alum
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Athletics aren't very important at school, there isn't as much time available for them as there could be, plus there are no facilities for students to participate, we have to rent from nearby schools or other universities for practice or games. Only student athletes can use gym facilities, that are also provided by a sister university.
author: Alum
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: There is definitely diversity among the student body with regards to race, economic background, religion, and sexual orientation. However, some of the groups considered as minorities in our state are represented as minorities in our school.
author: Junior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Drugs do not control the social environment of the school. Students can get access to them just as easily as they can stay away from them. There is no peer pressure in the use of drugs.
author: Junior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Since the school is small, it only has one fraternity and no sororities. Greek life is not very active among the school other than hosting a few events and parties.
author: Junior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: You obviously don't go to Cooper Union for sports. There are no facilities and teams rarely get practice time.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body:
It's Manhattan. End of story. 

Not sure how many people live in other boroughs or New Jersey, but quite a number of students commute more than 45 minutes to school. You will not pay nearly as much if you extend your commute time.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: There is something wrong with the administration and I don't know why. There is a general distrust between the student body and the administration.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Everyone drinks, some people drink casually way too often (esp. in the art school) . The faculty, administration & the R.A.s have an incredibly lax approach to this. Drug-wise most people have experimented extensively & at least have been exposed to drugs in the past, but with the amount of work it's difficult to keep up a drug addiction. However, there's a solid 1/5 of the freshman art class that still take drugs so it's really up to you.  From what I hear, the engineers smoke more pot than the artists.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: I wouldn't expect any random hook ups in the art school.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: It's NYC. In the summertime you can't breathe. In the wintertime everything is frozen sludge.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: You have a few options for nightlife. Cooper union or NYC. The Art School has parties almost every weekend but most of the time people do their own thing. Parties never really get too crazy or too big. Just by being in NYC you really have an unlimited amount of options.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Although the sports programs aren't particularly strong, Dean Baker really cares for his student-athletes. Student involvement is high, and there is a lot to be gained from playing on an athletic team at Cooper.
author: Senior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Wish We Did Have a Cafeteria – There are a lot of places to eat around campus but sometimes (especially on a rainy cold day) you don't want to make the extra effort to go out. We do have a mini cafe but there's not much variety beyond 3-4 sandwiches and bagels.
author: Alum
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Cooper has definitely been one of the most amazing experiences I've had, and if I had to rewind time and choose all over again, I would want to come to Cooper again. Overall there is a strong sense of community and everyone works together to keep the school progressive, in all aspects of life.
author: Alum
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Students are very safe on campus and very trusting of each other. There are rarely any cases of campus crime.
author: Junior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: I love being on sports. Its a perfect break
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: The school no longer offer free tuition for all, but the financial aid is still pretty generous.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: There are enough computer labs open weekdays until midnight that I don't think a personal computer is totally necessary if you don't have one, but most people do anyway.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: The weather is typical New York weather. It is cold in the winter/fall and warm in the summer/spring. Bad snowstorms can occur every so often and we happened to have a hurricane (Hurricane sandy) this past year.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: The process of getting into the Engineering major is very straightforward as that is what you apply to when you first apply to the school. However, you can switch to a different type of engineering major such as from civil to mechanical if you can maintain a 3.5 GPA.
author: Senior
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: There are many different people here and mostly everyone is accepting.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Although The Cooper Union is not in a division, nor has any athletics facilities of its own, there is a great percentage of students who participate in the sports program. About 80 students out of the 900 at Cooper participate in sports. We have Men's and Women's Volleyball, Basketball, and Tennis as well as co-ed Soccer and Cross Country teams. Each summer, the sports teams travel to Cape Cod, MA for a week of pre-season training. We stay in beach houses and train 4-6 hours a day and spend our free time on the beach, having BBQs, and making friends. Some of the teams are involved in conferences, while others just have scheduled games against other schools. Our Dean of Athletics, Dean Baker, always says that the scholar athletes at The Cooper Union play sports because they do not have the time to watch sports. Our scholar athletes have some of the highest GPAs at our school. We practice at nearby schools' gyms and/or parks. The athletes at Cooper are definitely some of the more outgoing and social crowd.
author: Sophomore
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: We have 5 computer labs in all, 4 concentrated on one floor of one building and then a separate on in the other building. We have both Macs and PCs and they are all loaded with AutoCad, Rhino, Adobe Master Collection (Photoshop,etc), and other top of the line programs needed to complete your coursework. Each building has a few large format plotters and of course many smaller scale printers. The large scale plotters and color prints incur a fee. Black and white printing is free for the small scale printers. There are two campus wide wi-fi networks, one which is a faster technology than the other. They are fairly reliable. Having a personal computer is preferred, as you will inevitably need to type essays and research, which could be done in the computer labs, but is much more convenient to do so from your studio or desk (for Art and Architecture).
author: Sophomore
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Not too much snow in winter...nice in the spring and fall...hot in the summer
author: Alum
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: obviously everyone wants a cooper grad
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: You can probably find all the food in the world within 10 minutes walking radius. It problem is whether you have the time and money to partake in such activity.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Very accepting community. There is no 'majority'
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: It's NYC so it's incredibly stimulating & provides you with access to literally anything you could imagine, but at the same time it can make you feel really displaced and isolated. The area around the school & the dorm is incredibly active and overly-stimulating. It can be difficult to find a moment of peace or silence in such an environment. Personally, I was really surprised to realize how much the condition of this environment can affect students & their schoolwork.
author: Freshman
name: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art

body: Terrible housing, exorbitant prices, and apathetic RAs galore.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - San Diego

body: This school has absolutely no school spirit, and very few people attend games.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - San Diego

body: Our teams are amazing but our school does not want to move up to D1 for some reason which affects them. It's sad to see them try so hard but it not be praised due to the fact that we are not a Division 1 school. The fan support is great during spirit week other than that you don't really hear much about the sport events unless friends are on a team.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - San Diego

body: No school spirit, no football team
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - San Diego

body: There is no sports life here.
author: Senior
name: University of California - San Diego

body: Too strict and administration tries to shut down any student activism before it even starts.
author: Senior
name: University of California - San Diego

body: Sucks as much as the dining halls. The salads are the best thing on campus.
author: Junior
name: University of California - San Diego

body: Way too strict. A party gets you on probation
author: Freshman
name: University of California - San Diego

body: Sucks. Nothing on campus. Security too strict.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - San Diego

body: The only financial aid I received were loans. I could not qualify for anything else because the financial aid office required me to use my parents income information even though I am the one who will be paying for my education. I think it is absolutely ridiculous that I am not able to use my own financial information to receive aid for my own education.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - San Diego

body: They police us like parents. It's no fun being on campus. It's no fun being anywhere near UCSD. RA's will write you up for alcohol and drug offenses. There's a loud-noise curfew in general, and parking enforcement is really strict.
author: Alum
name: University of California - San Diego

body: I only went to one off-campus party in my 4 years of UCSD. It was a binge drinking fest, and filled with try-hards who practiced beer-pong way too much. Is it bad that even the party games are taken way too competitively here at UCSD? I mean if you're part of the Greek Community, then having fun will not be a problem, but for ordinary people, you can just about forget about it.
author: Alum
name: University of California - San Diego

body: I pay so much money and live in a room with rampant water damage in a dank basement that keeps us all sick. The value is awful, but I think we may have just gotten very unlucky.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: Strict about the wrong issues, ie. parking.
author: Senior
name: William & Mary

body: Campus housing needs to be completely renovated.
author: Senior
name: William & Mary

body: I really cannot stand the weather here! It rains consistently and it so cold during the winter without accumulating any snow. If there is a single nice and sunny day it is almost clock work that is will be a soggy and cold day the next.
author: Sophomore
name: William & Mary

body: The campus is exact opposites from the surround in all aspects. The city of Williamsburg's extremely aged population seems to be out to get College students. And townies are just freaky sometimes.
author: Sophomore
name: William & Mary

body: I hate Williamsburg weather. It's humid and mucky and gross. It's December now and it was 80 degrees today. I don't understand. Maybe it has something to do with being in a swamp.
author: Junior
name: William & Mary

body: There are police EVERYWHERE. They are not always in students business, but their presence alone creates a strict atmosphere.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: Cost of parking permit is expensive. However, if you are living on campus, there is no need for a car. Very limited parking on campus, hard to find a spot during class. Students used to be allowed to park in faculty/staff spaces after 5 on weekdays, but parking services has changed this policy so now only allowed on the weekends. Parking services gives out lots of tickets.
author: Alum
name: William & Mary

body: I have never received a scholarship from W&M, despite all my efforts and hard work.  But people who do get them say they are worth it.  Some are just more lucky than others.
author: Alum
name: William & Mary

body: our football and basketball teams are pretty awful. depending on the opponent, I have seen fans of the opposing team nearly outnumber WM students at football games (i.e. the 2012 game versus Delaware). we don't have a varsity men's lacrosse team. a lot of our students don't seem to be huge sports fans in general, and I think that extends to caring about collegiate sports. I am a woman who is a huge NFL and NHL fan, and I have many friends who couldn't name 3 players on the Redskins, who are probably the most popular NFL team on campus. we definitely have school pride in spades, but lackluster major sports programs (due in large part to difficulty recruiting talent to a school like this) and general student apathy towards pro and college sports in general makes for a school that you shouldn't attend if you want college football or basketball to be a big part of your life. I think at larger schools a star football player would be a bit of a campus celebrity; that is not the case here at all. Go to Tech, UVA, JMU, or even VCU if you want an in-state school w decent sports. We are, however, good at random sports like gymnastics, and their meets can be quite fun to attend if you enjoy the olympic gymnastics.
author: Junior
name: William & Mary

body: If you're out-of-state, you're screwed. They have something that they call a "gap" which basically means that they acknowledge up to a certain amount of aid that they simply will not match. After that, they'll only meet a certain percent of your demonstrated need. On top of that, they do not give out-of-state students work/study, and they have VERY few merit scholarships for out-of-state students. They have some scholarships that look like merit scholarships, but the money you receive goes toward any research you might conduct, not toward your tuition. I am an excellent student, one of the top in my class, I've made Dean's List every semester, and I have yet to be given a merit scholarship. On top of that, if you're having trouble, they won't do anything to help you, and they very obviously favor in-state-students. Out-of-state students were called "bags of gold with feet" by the college president earlier this year, which just goes to show you how little they actually care about us as people. If you have any questions about struggles that I have had with paying for the education here or with how I have interacted with the administration, please feel free to comment below. I would be more than happy to share my story if it will help someone else! Basically, if your family can't afford to spend $50,000 (and you're not an athlete), then you shouldn't come here (as multiple members of the administration have very frankly told me).
author: Sophomore
name: William & Mary

body: Athletics is definitely not a big thing at all at W&M. But there was that one year our basketball team almost made the March Madness tournament!!
author: Alum
name: William & Mary

body: Despite high academic achievement there was no schloarship made available to me.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: parking on campus for students is extremely limited and is very expensive. There need to be more options for students to park that are both greater in the number of spaces available and closer to class buildings. Faculty/staff parking greatly outnumbers that of students despite the fact that there are more than double the number of students than faculty/staff on campus. Also, parking services is awful and give out tickets very regularly and are not very understanding of the limited parking available to students.
author: Senior
name: William & Mary

body: Lots of cockroaches. Housing sucks.
author: Sophomore
name: William & Mary

body: Coming from a school where I was in Greek Life, the Greek Life here is awful.
author: Junior
name: William & Mary

body: Bathrooms are unclean (especially the showers), lounges are okay, but as long as you keep your own room clean things will be fine.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: The best food on campus tends to be the least healthy food. Meat and veggies are not cooked well.
author: Sophomore
name: William & Mary

body: Most of the best available options are passed down between friends and through fraternities, sororities, and clubs. Other options are limited.
author: Sophomore
name: William & Mary

body: Very hit or miss. The food doesn't set well with me and I don't like being forced into a meal plan. The option of Flex is nice but is very limited.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: The school is not known for athletics. It is an academic school. The gym is empty if you go before 8 am classes, but it gets more crowded as the day goes on.  There are a few cardio bunnies always taking up the treadmills and stationary bikes, but the majority of students do not work out or lift so the weights are not in super high demand, but still at the wrong times of day you cannot move in the gym.  Intermurals are fun but there isn't enough participation to make them awesome.
author: Sophomore
name: William & Mary

body: Getting financial aid is difficult and the scholarships are very competitive.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: The quality of the dining hall food is lackluster at best.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: The student Rec is great. Its renovated, big, and offers lots of great classes for students. Club sports, though underfunded, are also really well organized and very inclusive to all students. If you're looking for a big "sports" school, though, you may be in the wrong place. Sporting events are underwhelming, and games have pretty low attendance. WM has an abundance of school spirit; it just happens to come from outlets other than athletics.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: Don't ever go to the counseling office if you're depressed or have a mental illness. They are extremely unhelpful. Instead, tell your professors up-front at the beginning of the semester and they'll work with you - they're usually pretty good about that.
author: Junior
name: William & Mary

body: Not many scholarship opportunities for tuition and the only ones focus on student diversity.
author: Freshman
name: William & Mary

body: Sexual assaults are a problem and so is crime and violence in general, especially if you are female.

name: The Ohio State University

body: In the business school, greek life is very big and if you aren't in a fraternity, it can be hard to network.

name: The Ohio State University

body: My freshman year I was in an old building that was very small. I was sick through out the entire year because of the poor air circulation.. sophomore year I moved to off campus housing.
author: Junior
name: The Ohio State University

body: Never stayed in campus housing, cuz it's a ripoff.
author: Freshman
name: The Ohio State University

body: My goal is to become a special education teacher, however getting into the program is much difficult. Since the program only accepts 35 students and it seems a bit unfair to restrict on a high demand work ethnic. I find programs are restricting the number of students or asking to much under a short period of time. It doesn't give the student a opportunity to explore and desire a career/degree they wanted when not many could get in.
author: Sophomore
name: The Ohio State University

body: It is not easy to get financial aid because if you don't meet their specific requirement, it is almost impossible to earn any type of aid.
author: Freshman
name: The Ohio State University

body: i dont party much, I work at a bar and im not into the house party scene
