name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: tooo crazy! and disgusting, the party scene is not fun at all just gross.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: Campus lacks good art. Most of the buildings on campus are really short and lack the sort of awe that most people would expect college campuses to inspire. The lagoon is kinda cute when you catch it reflecting the sun at the right angle. There really isn't any glorious art piece or building on campus that would remind you that you're at an important educational institution (which UCSB actually is). The library is being renovated. It's not very aesthetically pleasing. From the 8th floor you can see the beach a little bit, which is cool. Overall architecture of the school is just bad. There are no giant shady trees to sit under: most of the trees really look like bare babies. There are a good amount of chairs in the student center.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: Triples is being enforced for freshmen this year and it's very expensive for a crammed little room of three. Not enough closet space either.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: Chile I hope I get a job after this...
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: We don't even have a football team.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: If you don't for sure want to go into research, don't go to this school.
author: Alum
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: They keep letting in more and more freshmen so rooms intended as already small doubles are now triples with 3 people sharing two closets. Alcohol and drug policies are overreaching and ruthlessly enforced. Even the farthest dorm is only a mile from campus; the others are within walking distance of class. Social atmosphere in the dorms was great. I'm still good friends with a lot of the people I met three years ago.
author: Alum
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: Crime is common in IV and cops seem more focussed on ticketing people for sitting on curbs than curbing sexual assault.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: Athletics are not very important to UCSB. We get our kicks elsewhere.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: not worth what we pay
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: Lots of the groups have bad reputations.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: I like to be alone and I like quiet, but I ended up in the two tower dorms with 10 floors each.  My floormates (who I do not call friends) have never socialized with me, and rarely do I even get a smile from them as a hello.  Also, they don't respect quiet hours and although I brought this up to the RA, I still wonder if the RA ever said anything to them.  The room is spacious compared to other dorms, but still cramped feeling.  Being off campus is a bit of a struggle, but having to bike to class makes you not get that Freshman 15.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: UCSB has been known for its partying and there are visible signs of that. However, there are also a great deal of students who choose not to participate and peer pressure is very minimal.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Santa Barbara

body: No Greek life, but the closest thing to a frat would be the Drinker House, full of baseball guys.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: Could not have been more disappointed by the food at Haverford College. It's borderline insulting.  I love almost everything about this school, but the Dining Center is a joke. The food is low-quality and prepared poorly. You can bet that almost everything you consume will be overcooked, including the coffee. The dishes are often unclean, yet put out for the students to use, and the staff can be rude at times. The Coop is decent, but isn't open on weekends, is very expensive, and is super-slow. The Dining Center is the single worst part of my experience at Haverford.
author: Sophomore
name: Haverford College

body: The Dining Center food is the worst but the Coop and Lunt Cafe food is great, although they have terrible hours.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: There is no greek life.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: The RA equivalent practically provides alcohol to the freshmen. As a freshman alcohol is pretty much inescapable, people are not ordinarily pressured but it depends on your hall. The policy is super lenient and ill enforced.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: Not strict. All accountability falls on the student.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: Don't know much about off-campus housing. Almost everyone lives on campus. Occasionally students are kicked off campus or don't get the housing they want in the selection process, and move off campus. The housing around the school is expensive and limited.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: While the coop and lunt cafe offer nice alternatives to the DC, with good sandwiches, sushi, snacks, desserts, and other delicious but unhealthy options, their prices quickly add up. The DC's food is one of the biggest complaints among students, although it is slowly improving. After a few months, you learn what is good and how to make the most out of the food the DC offers.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: There is not a lot of selection in the Dining Center and the coop and lunt cafe cost money so that is not ideal either.
author: Sophomore
name: Haverford College

body: All about the athletes and their group. They throw most of the parties and no one wants to go to a non-athlete party. Jerks!
author: Junior
name: Haverford College

body: Christians, Republicans and lower-middle class people are completely outnumbered.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: It depends on your socioeconomic status, lower-middle/middle-middle class applicants beware.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: Parties definitely have had a positive impact on my experience here.  Everyone comes together for them, so its a good way to hang out with people you are friends with but might not have classes with or bump into a lot during the week.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: Parties here typically only happen on Friday and Saturday nights, and some of them are good and some are bad.  Based on which campus group is hosting the event, it is usually pretty easy to predict whether it will be an enjoyable event or not beforehand.  For those who aren't into parties, Nerd House on campus has a bunch of great, creative options every weekend.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: There is definitely diversity on campus, and the vast majority of people are very accepting.  Ethnic/racial diversity isn't talked about all that often, but there are places on campus to go to engage in such discussions.  The most outspoken people on campus are liberal, so at times it can seem that that is the opinion of the whole school, but in actuality there is a pretty even mix of political beliefs.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: There is a real choose-for-yourself vibe here.  I have never experienced peer pressure to drink or do drugs, and it is definitely possible to have great fun on weekends without using substances.  Because of the honor code, the campus administration is very lenient regarding alcohol use.  Campus Safety is always there to call when a situation may be getting out of hand, and it is their goal to protect people, not to be punitive.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: About 1/3 of Haverford students are varsity athletes, and some teams perform well for their division.  There isn't a ton of school spirit, and athletics are mainly important to those who are directly involved in them.  Students do sometimes go to games or events to support the school or their friends.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: Haverford is a D-III school. I am not a varsity athlete, but a club athlete. The varsity teams have a lot of privileges and resources that other teams don't receive. There are a number of club teams that are as or more committed and successful as varsity teams but we don't gain any recognition or resources. The teams offer great "families" within the broader community to those who join them, but I would say that being a varsity athlete means you will be spending a great deal of your time with the team and not with other groups.
author: Junior
name: Haverford College

body: A lot of Haverford's teams are very good in their conference, but of course as a division three school, we don't get the same funding or fan turnout as a bigger school may. However, our gym is one of the nicest in our conference and we have great facilities that both athletes and non-athletes can use.
author: Junior
name: Haverford College

body: I'm not into the athletics division at Haverford, but there are many sports that people can participate.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: It may be different than an average state school social scene, but Haverford has a surprisingly robust party scene when you know where to look. Most Saturdays there will be at least one large party, and many groups party on Thursdays and Fridays as well, if not also during the week. Parties are very welcoming and open to the entire student body, and even when intoxicated students are friendly and look out for each other.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: Some dorms are better than others. Freshman housing is decent; even Gummere, which is by all accounts the worst dorm, is fondly talked about by its residents. Except for the two new dorms, Tritton and Kim, which are sparkling clean and have nice facilities and amazing bathrooms, the rest of the campus housing options are remarkably average.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: The school is very small so sometimes seeing the same people over and over again can be boring. However, the best parties are ones where you can simply dance with your friends. The party scene is usually well contained and has a good impact on the student body.
author: Sophomore
name: Haverford College

body: It is pretty great to live on campus. I have been lucky enough to live in the two newest dorms both my freshman and sophomore year. They are very environmentally friendly and allergy free and generally very clean and nice to live in. The housing process is done through a lottery system and can be very stressful at times.
author: Sophomore
name: Haverford College

body: There are always parties going on during the weekend, however sometimes it feels like there could be more.  Still fun though.
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: Very generous, but I definitely used external scholarships to cover costs that I can't afford
author: Freshman
name: Haverford College

body: I think campus is mostly safe. That being said, I have never had a problem that requires safety and security to get involved and they are not particularly noticeable on campus anyway so if I did have a serious problem I would sooner call the police than campus security.
author: Sophomore
name: Haverford College

body: The few rules that exist are NEVER enforced, which is good if you like to smoke and terrible if you don't. The rooms are very spacious and you are pretty much guaranteed to have a single if you want one. There is no substance free housing available for freshmen (though hopefully that changes soon) but there is Cadbury hall for upperclassmen. Currently there is also a community house called Nerd House for anyone seeking substance-free fun. Most dorms are very near everything else, except for the apartments, but the apartments have their own benefits. Most buildings are pretty old, and you can tell, the one exception being Tritton and Kim which have air conditioning and the most beautiful showers you will ever lay your eyes on! I like living on campus because there is always stuff going on, but be careful who you live with (and where) if you are not keen on alcohol and/or drugs!
author: Sophomore
name: Haverford College

body: too much freedom for athletes
author: Junior
name: Haverford College

body: I am a big weightlifter and very into fitness and the one thing I have to say about the gym is that it sucks.  D- at best.  Everything at Taylor gym is awful.  The equiptment is old and outdated.
author: Freshman
name: Lehigh University

body: There's a clear divide between Greek and non-Greek
author: Freshman
name: Lehigh University

body: Bethlehem police ticket the cars if meters run out.  Metered parking
author: Freshman
name: Lehigh University

body: The campus has become so strict in the past 4 years, hardly no frat really party on the hill anymore.  BBQ's are so hard to host and have them last for more than an hour.  The school is so strict with stupid things like if you have a party you can't have any hard alcohol and if you get busted like once your already under probation.
author: Junior
name: Lehigh University

body: Parking is terrible and expensive.  There are never any spots and no matter where you are you usually get a ticket.  I was parked in a lto on a Saturday and got a 50 dollar ticket.  I didn't pay it.
author: Senior
name: Lehigh University

body: You can never find a spot, and if you do, it's pretty far away.
author: Freshman
name: Lehigh University

body: Safety is a major concern. Living off campus in Bethlehem you have to be vigilant of your surroundings. Lehigh Police does all they can to curb the crime but Bethlehem Police are more worried about the underage drinking than the crime ridden area.
author: Senior
name: Lehigh University

body: Parking permits are really expensive, and even with them you need to pay for meter parking on campus. I never drive to class because I don't want to pay for parking
author: Junior
name: Lehigh University

body: Lehigh Parking Services is out to get you. They charge a lot for permits and constant patrol to give tickets. If you need to park, pay and do it legally.
author: Alum
name: Lehigh University

body: they give the word clique a new definition!
author: Senior
name: Lehigh University

body: I think the career services can do a better job. In general, it is very hard to network with past alumni. The career center has very few job postings and that most are only open to US-residents. I would be great to see the career center bolster our alumni network and reach out to more companies to provide opportunities.
author: Senior
name: Lehigh University

body: Alcohol is literally every where and so is weed if you know who to ask. Coke has a prescence on campus too but thats a bit more difficult to get. Adderall and ritalin are very present around finals as is xanax right after. You could really get anything you wanted if you knew who to ask but alcohol and weed are what you would see at parties typically.
author: Freshman
name: Lehigh University

body: Most people I see are rich, white, rude snobs
author: Freshman
name: Lehigh University

body: Lehigh lacks diversity as far as race and class.
author: Freshman
name: Lehigh University

body: Very small rooms, and the cleaning people are not very good
author: Freshman
name: Lehigh University

body: Wesleyan's Greek life is in the process of being overthrown to co-educated societies
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: There is no greek life.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: There is virtually no off-campus housing. Every student is required to live on campus all four years; housing is guaranteed.
author: Alum
name: Wesleyan University

body: There is no off campus housing!
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: Nurses and doctors in the health center are judgmental and it is impossible to get in to see the doctor.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: We can't use it mostly, we've already payed an arm and a leg for the meal plan and other food options are either far away or terrible/overpriced. Food carts are OK, but they're only around on certain nights and they're overpriced. No  one wants to spend real money here.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: Funny how they can be getting higher and higher salaries, raising tuition, and still taking funding away from everything which once made this school great. Life at Wesleyan feels like a constant battle between the administration and the students.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: At Wesleyan you have to buy their meal plan to enroll. It's expensive, way too expensive. You will run out of food three weeks before the end of the semester and if you don't have a car you'll probably end up having to pay for more overpriced food. The school grocery store has limited options in the way of healthy affordable food, but if you need a 20$ chocolate bar, they got you covered. Most students I know end up sneaking into the dining hall by the end of the semester because they've run out of 'points'. The dining hall is poorly stocked, they run out of most foods by the end of the year. The vegan section is great when it's great, they have an amazing chef, but he isn't there all the time. All in all, it's like going to school in a factory town.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: DO NOT GO TO WESLEYAN. It's my biggest regret in life so far, I couldn't have possibly had a worse experience with college and many people here feel the same.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: I struggled every semester to try to live off campus, the university rarely ever allows it. There are great, affordable options in the area, but the university wants you to lease their overpriced cement boxes. When I finally got it, my living costs reduced to about a quarter of what they were while I lived on campus and my quality of life shot up immeasurably. However, don't consider this an option; they almost never allow students to live off campus.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body:
The Office of Residential life will screw you for every penny. They act like it's downtown Manhattan real estate when they cram you like sardines into dysfunctional facilities.  Even when the school gives you houses, most of them have broken down heating and plumbing. The University rushes you to pack your life into boxes immediately after finals, giving you no time to say goodbyes or rest. They will slap you with egregious fines for staying late, for having dust on the floor, for having minor aesthetic flaws (a pen mark, a frayed screen) that were present before you moved in.

Somehow Wesleyan is simultaneously the worst place I've ever lived and the most expensive. Oh, and they forbid you to live off campus. It's in the fine print when you enroll in the college. They monopolize your life here to exploit your wallet.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: Could not get an internship this year, not many alums help
author: Alum
name: Wesleyan University

body: Its becoming bad, the school has such a poor rep, now just know as expensive and full of druggies, all its known for is drug use.  falling out of the top 25 schools this year, applications dropping, no endowment $$$, so sorry
author: Alum
name: Wesleyan University

body: Upperclassmen get to stay in University owned housing, most of which is falling down, you wont get anything repaired until the end of the semester, its the worst
author: Alum
name: Wesleyan University

body: I have had a lot of trouble with financial aid due to my family's unique and precipitous decline in income over the past sever years. Wesleyan has good financial aid for people of specific documentable income brackets.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: Wesleyan is, well, Wesleyan.  Drugs are everywhere.  I can't step out of my dorm without smelling marijuana.  On Saturday and Sunday morning, you can easily walk through campus and see red Solo cups and beer cans strewn about.  In spite of this, Wesleyan does a relatively good job on drug safety with presentations...only your freshman year though.
author: Freshman
name: Wesleyan University

body: There are roughly 2500 students attending Wesleyan. Of those 2500, about 15 live off campus because it is school policy that you do not live off campus. Of those that live off campus, the exception has been made because most of them have families with children to come home to. It's a shame because there are a lot of students, even a small movement, to make off-campus housing an option, but it doesn't seem to be happening. I, for one, would appreciate it because that would mean less debt and I wouldn't have to live in an un-heated house again.
author: Junior
name: Wesleyan University

body: I'm not really into Greek life. Most people don't care one way or another.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: Currently, Wes doesn't have any frats or sororities with houses. We currently only have 4 frats: DKE, AEPi, Psi U, and Chi Psi, but only the first three really have any sort of presence. Psi U is coming back to Wes in the fall, which should change things, but currently none of the frats have any relevance to anyone else other than the members. We have one sorority, Rho Ep, but it isn't nationally recognized and is more in place so girls who would normally have a hard time finding a girl group can have a solid friend group of girls.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: The school has dismantled greek life over the past two years. It is almost nonexistent now.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: People aren't a big fan of greek life on campus. Lots of controversy.
author: Junior
name: Wesleyan University

body: Unless you are a student-athlete, varsity sports are at the bottom of your priority list (a significant number of athletes that I know end up quitting towards the end of their college career, for what it's worth). No one attends the games. Though, friends I have who play club sports (especially Ultimate Frisbee) get very into it and form wonderful communities.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: You aren't truly a Wesleyan student if you haven't hated the administration in some capacity during your four years here. Whether they're expelling students to improve their PR image or letting perpetrators of sexual assault off scot-free, they know how to royally mess up the lives of students.
author: Alum
name: Wesleyan University

body: Financial Aid is very low as an international student.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: Most of the campus dislikes Greek Life. The administration is trying to slowly shut it down.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: Pres Roth wants them gone, so i time they will be gone, most of the bad things that happen on campus wither happens in the frats or the dorms, so really bad thing happen everywhere
author: Alum
name: Wesleyan University

body: Its tolerable, but really if you like food, consider your options and town is not so close
author: Alum
name: Wesleyan University

body: The administration is pretty unfriendly in North College, and P-Safe is really only interested in busting parties. Supposed "Fire Safety" examinations of our rooms are really just a guise to find our booze and alcohol, and to impose fines on students.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: I've only been to one football game, when my parents were visiting and wanted to see it.
author: Freshman
name: Wesleyan University

body: Here's the thing: Greek life at Wes is complicated. It doesn't exactly jive with the activist community with all the sexual assault accusations that have happened in the last few years. That being said, they're well-known for the parties they throw; in particular, the co-ed societies (Eclectic and Alpha Delt) are very popular on weekends.
author: Freshman
name: Wesleyan University

body: They're not meeting my needs at all. They're asking for more than my family can pay. I've had to appeal every year so far. It's an anxiety-inducing headache every time. Plus, they just repealed need-blind admissions.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: The houses aren't bad, but everyone hears horror stories about the people and sexual assault at their parties. We have one brand-new sorority, but they aren't allowed their own house. The administration has been cracking down on all the fraternities recently.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: I've only lived in the dorms, but for this up and coming semester I will live in the apartments, which are heard are a way better option. I've also heard that the freshman dorms are great, they have AC.
author: Junior
name: Wesleyan University

body: I haven't really differentiate greeks from other students
author: Junior
name: Wesleyan University

body: I personally always feel safe on campus
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: It depends on what dorm you live in. Most singles are an okay size but they could be bigger. There's also not a lot of closet space either.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: I was never interested in it.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: There are usually a number of break-ins during the school year, typically perpetrated by non-Wesleyan students. There were also a few muggings on campus. Public Safety is pretty on top of their job, and I've had good experiences with them. I lived kind of far from the center of campus, and I often did not feel safe walking alone at night.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: The housing process can be really hit or miss depending on your lottery number. The housing options are overall pretty good, and if you really don't like your dorm/roommate, you can usually move elsewhere. The Residential Life office is only okay - some of the staff are quite unpleasant to deal with, but the RAs are all great and really nice.
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: Not a huge part of general student life, but fun
author: Senior
name: Wesleyan University

body: I've seen better and I've seen worse. Senior year and Junior year housing is great because Jr year you get an apartment and senior year you get a house, ALL of them being on campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: When people go to sports, it is usually just to support friends, not because people are genuinely interested in how the team does, with the exception probably of football and sometimes basketball. For D3 athletics this is pretty normal-- very important games will have high attendance with most others just getting a few stragglers. Usually Friday night games can get a good crowd.
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: I give it an average rating because it's not horrible, but some buildings could use a little more modernization of sorts. But overall, my dorm life was good. Room seemed small at first, but then I found it to be comfy
author: Sophomore
name: Wesleyan University

body: The quality of food is poor, and its prepared poorly. Not much variety, same things over and over. No nice berries, just frozen berry mix. Can no longer swipe for other people, which is bogus. The online menu is wrong and nonexistent fall semester. The retreat is nice, but I can't spend meal swipes there. A meal swipe is worth too much for the little I get with it.
author: Junior
name: Vassar College

body: Vassar claims to be very diverse and accepting and it is towards the LGBT community, but I cannot say the same for minorities on campus. Since it  is a private university White students make up over half of the school and it is very evident.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Vassar does not have Greek Life :(
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Hardly anyone lives off-campus, and those who do don't speak too highly of it. Poughkeepsie isn't a nice place.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Have to park really far away and parking enforcement is terrible.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: There are hardly any available and they are slow. But people hardly use them anyways.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: There are no consequences for drug use. It's a very big part of the Vassar culture, and limiting for students who don't want to be involved. Sure, you can do other things,  but in a school so small, there's no way that the drug culture doesn't influence your experience, whether you're participating or not.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: Unless you have a car or go down to the city often, there's nothing to do in Poughkeepsie. There are restaurants around Vassar, and the variety isn't bad, but Poughkeepsie is by no means a "college town." The closest movie theatre is 25 minutes and a $17 cab ride away.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: Recently the campus has been buckling down, being much stricter with security and handing out outrageous to minor offenses. It's abhorrent.
author: Junior
name: Vassar College

body: Almost Completely White – Attempt to diversify campus is accepting solely Chinese-nationals
author: Senior
name: Vassar College

body: Sports Not a School-Spirit Booster – Varsity sports at Vassar are not a very big part of campus life. Those who go to various games usually go because they themselves have some sort of connection to someone on the team or to the sport itself. Sports events are not  campus-wide events and are rarely even talked about by other students. Those who do play sports, however, set themselves apart due to the rest of the student body's lack of interest, resulting in cliques.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: People on campus tend not to care about athletics too much, though people on teams (from what I gather) seem to be happy and taken care of.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: They're ready to help but these problems still happen.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Social atmosphere is rather exclusive. Dorms are old, and though many are refurbished, there are still bugs and rodents. Bathrooms are of very poor quality/cleanliness.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: The THs are the only place you can attend a decent party,and even those are pretty weak. The music is basic, the dancing is kind of sad, and everyone is packed together like sardines in a can. Once in a blue moon, you will have a lot of fun in a TH party and that will be your excuse for going every weekend in the hopes for another fun night.
author: Junior
name: Vassar College

body: Poughkeepsie is definitely not a city worth seeing thats why many students hardly leave campus except to run errand or to eat.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Unless you break into the scene early as a freshman, it's extremely hard to get involved. Parties, even in senior housing, tend to be small, with lots of hard alcohol since kegs are banned on campus. You mostly party with the friends you live with, and it is impossible to get involved unless you have a connection.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: Its in the middle of a bad city with horrible atmosphere
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: The school is Division 3, so it's not like anyone coming here comes for athletics anyway. Some of the sports teams are really good, but they're not heroes on campus or anything.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: "Bad" is not a good term. This school just isn't much of a sports school. If you are in a sport, then it's all good, but there's not much attention to it.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: Drug use on campus is visible. It's very easy to obtain drugs and alcohol. But there are plenty of people who don't engage in it, and are perfectly happy.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Poughkeepsie is a seedy, semi run-down town that most people dislike. That's why the majority of Vassar students don't frequently leave campus.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: The campus shuttle will take you to different parts of campus during the week and to the mall on weekends at select times. Other than that you're stuck using the expensive taxis that charge per-person, so splitting a taxi is pointless.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: The early fall and spring are nice, warm, and sometimes sunny, but the winter is long, cruel, and you spend 99% of it indoors hiding from the snow.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: They have a bad course selection for biology. I can't get into classes because there aren't enough teachers.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: I think sports deserve more credit here and I would definitely love some more school spirit.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Only public transport is a shuttle to the mall on weekends.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: We have amazing coaches and great team dynamics. Many students on campus join one or more of the 27 sports offered. Many students who join sports will stick with the team for as many seasons as they are students here. Sports are in general considered a lot of fun even if it isn't a priority to most students.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Security seems pretty minimal, although campus crime hasn't been too much of an issue from what I've seen. Despite the lack of security, I still feel pretty safe.
author: Sophomore
name: Vassar College

body: difficult to get classes you want
author: Senior
name: Vassar College

body: vassar is not a school focused on athletics
author: Senior
name: Vassar College

body: Vassar College is mostly safe due to a great presence of security and other similar services. However, people should be careful of their belongings and of each other. In addition, there are those blue light stations around campus that people can easily use for emergencies and concerns relating to safety. But they are not evenly dispersed throughout campus to the point that there are places where there were none of those stations nearby.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Vassar College don't have Greek life, but there are other places available for partying such as the Mug or the Town Apartments (TA's).
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: There are varsity sports, intramural, and club sport teams available for students interested in sports, but they are not widely popular or attended by other students at Vassar. I don't even know much about the sports teams, and I never went to a sport game before as of now. In addition, sports are not as big as in other schools because Vassar don't have football or a cheerleader team. However, the sport teams played pretty well despite not having a great presence on campus.
author: Freshman
name: Vassar College

body: Campus police wage a forever war against students

name: Case Western Reserve University

body: Probably several times a day there are robberies
author: Senior

body: literally crap for being $6,000 a month
author: Senior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: As a freshman you get to walk a mile and a half to classes through the snow, pay 9 grand a year for a single if you want that, and get to fight the aging buildings. As an upperclassman you get to pay similarly and live in the older, cruddier buildings closer to the quad. Wait, nah... they are all cruddy. You could also pay for an apartment 'managed' by the university and have more black mold than you would if you just rented from one of the nearby slumlords.
author: Senior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: International kids don't even get a single penny
author: Freshman
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: High cost, small rooms, little atmosphere
author: Junior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: The safety and security are absolutely terrifying.  We just had three armed gunmen enter one of the study rooms and rob students at gun point (7/19).  This is the latest of many crimes happening on campus and affecting students, as in the students are victims.  The school made no comment to the students in regards to what the university will do to prevent such issues.
author: Senior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: It's really cold most of the time. There is rarely any sun, it's usually gloomy and cloudy. The winters are long and cold and dreary.
author: Sophomore
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: There is no variety in nightlife. The only option are frat parties and after the first few even they get old. There are no nearby bars or clubs.
author: Sophomore
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: It's non existent except as a social girl or a guy from select frats.
author: Sophomore

body: D3 school.  Enough said
author: Sophomore

body: There is no sun.  If it's not raining, it's snowing
author: Sophomore
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: Total ripoff - $1350/month rent is ridiculous
author: Sophomore
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: I mean it depends. For freshmans, the newer buldings like Taft and Smith are pretty nice. The older buildings, like Storrs and Pierce, are pretty ugly and have smaller rooms, kitchens, and laundry rooms.
author: Sophomore
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: Greek life is expensive and takes up too much of your time. You can make great friends, but you can do that without paying too.
author: Sophomore
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: Co-op office can't handle the students they have
author: Senior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: I never bothered with the drunken buffoonery available.
author: Senior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body:
Heh heh. I played in a mediocre marching band and watched our division three football team get their rears handed to them from the bleachers. 

Don't expect much.
author: Senior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: There's no real good way ti put this so I'm gonna be blunt. Football games, soccer games, pretty much most sports games don't turn up much of a crowd at all. Basketball games are much better but it's still not what you'd see at other schools. Of big sporting events are your thing then this school isn't for you. What case does have is a great intermural sports program. Lots of people enter and it's a really fun way to make new friends.
author: Freshman
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: There might be something going on about every other weekend. And because parties are so hard to come by, they usually are busted pretty quickly.
author: Junior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: Horrible cultural foods and all overpriced. A sandwhich, three snacks, and a soda for $13? Forget it!
author: Sophomore
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: The dining halls, while accessible, are universally known to be pretty terrible. However on and around campus there are plenty of great options for meals, some of which take meal swipes or case cash. So I'd say, get the lowest meal swipe meal plan and then get off it as soon as possible and enjoy all the food Cleveland has to offer (which is plenty).
author: Freshman
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: BLEH! Oh my god Bon Appetite is terrible. Okay, not that bad, it's just that first semester you're like 'Eh.. this is okay. Not as bad as it could be.' And then you come back after winter break and it's just downhill from there. I have to force myself to use my meal swipes. Jolly is pretty good compared to other things on campus but you only get 2 meal swipes for things (Jolly Scholar and Denny's) that aren't the campus dining halls which is so restricting. There's barely any variety at Leutner and it's just.. bad. Bearable, but bad.
author: Freshman
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: For how much you pay, campus food is terrible. On the other hand, once you're off the meal plan, you have some better, less expensive choices.
author: Junior
name: Case Western Reserve University

body: They only enforce policies on certain minority groups.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Davis

body: For my major which is biomedical engineering there are not many opportunities and internships available besides genentech which is very competitive. I have also not found many research opportunities in this field on campus.

name: University of California - Davis

body: Sports are not really big here at all. Even when certain teams are doing well, people generally don't talk about them much, and if they do, it's because they won a game or title and are hosting a party later that night.
author: Junior
name: University of California - Davis

body: Athletics are fun for the athletes. Students not very supportive except for basketball.

name: University of California - Davis

body: UC Davis is not a school I would bring up to brag about in the athletics department.

name: University of California - Davis

body: Sports teams at Davis are rarely supported which is disappointing because that is an important part of college life.

body: I apply every time and they give nothing, even with siblings in college as well. Both of my siblings received some help, but Colgate offered nothing.

body: It is confusing, and most the student population doesn't need it. Its not worth the time to even apply.
author: Junior
name: Colgate University

body: Many students do not receive financial aid. It is hard to receive aid unless you are very poor.
author: Freshman
name: Colgate University

body: Colgate needs way more diversity at it's campus. One of the very least diverse campuses.

name: Colgate University

body: There's a party scene, but I personally hate it.
author: Freshman
name: Colgate University

body: Terrible dining. Maybe something good like once every week.
author: Freshman
name: Colgate University

body: Hamilton, NY is the most boring place on this planet. There are so many things I took for granted coming from New York City that are simply luxuries up here. Hamilton has all the bare necessities (and I mean ABSOLUTE BARE). You won't find any mall for 40 minutes and the closest 24 hour anything is close, but a car ride away. If you like things like city life and culture, STAY AWAY FROM COLGATE. It's incredibly isolated and if you don't have a car you will be incredibly stir crazy.
author: Senior
name: Colgate University

body: I didn't receive as much financial aid as I thought I should, and after taking a semester off, my grant was removed.
author: Senior
name: Colgate University

body: Colgate is situated in Hamilton, New York.  Let's just say that the town's population drops in half when Colgate is not in session.  Hamilton is REALLY small and does not offer much.  There is an Indian restaurant, a Mexican restaurant, a few bars, two cafes, and the infamous Slices, which I'm sure you've read about.  There is not really any shopping and there is one movie theater that offers free movies to students every once in a while.  Besides the fact that the town itself doesn't offer much, Hamilton is in the middle of NOWHERE.  We are surrounded by miles and miles of farmland.  The closest city is Syracuse which is about a 45 minute drive.  Transportation in and out of upstate New York is also extremely difficult.
author: Freshman
name: Colgate University

body: Rape is a real threat and especially at Colgate sexual assault is a clear and very present danger. Colgate has on average of 3% more sexual assault than the average college student. After our Campus Climate Survey which interviewed around 800 members of the student body( 75%ish being women) almost 13% of the responders listed some sort of sexual assault. This compared to the national average of 9%ish is very scary. There have been numerous movements and sitins in order to prompt the university into acting and changing the system, however, their voices have fallen upon deaf ears. Colgate will always experience abnormal amounts of sexual assault because of the Greek system and its many flaws.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: Diversity is lacking at Colgate, however students seem to be quite tolerant of all sexual orientations/races/classes/etc., at least in my experience. While the majority of students seem to be white, wealthy WASPS, people aren't going to treat you poorly if you're not.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: The drug scene is very big here. Many people partake and a lot of students use the dark web to get various drugs. Most people do drugs
author: Freshman
name: Colgate University

body: Overall, a majority of people do not feel safe walking around campus alone. By people I mean females, because sexual assaults are so common.
author: Freshman
name: Colgate University

body: Greek life is too strong on campus. It acts to alienate students who choose to go non-Greek and routinely violate hazing rules to earn only slaps on the wrist. Greek alumni donors have the school in a stranglehold and act to soften any punishment against their houses. Greek students pay lip service to how they remain friends with non-Greek students. The fact is almost all social interaction on weekends is concentrated at the Greek houses. Lastly, Greek life is responsible for most social disruptions and alcohol/drug violations on campus.
author: Alum
name: Colgate University

body: You need to drive a minimum of 40 min. for new food.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: The food is just not good.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: There are not that many option, but the options are alright. The late night food scene is poor. There is one pizzeria. Don't get me wrong its good but nothing very very very good... maybe when you're drunk.
author: Freshman
name: Colgate University

body: There are not that many places to eat around Colgate.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: There is almost nothing to do in town. There are only a handful of restaurants.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: Most people are uninterested in forming real relationships.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: Off-campus housing is difficult because Colgate has very limited off campus housing. Also, people apply early (during their sophomore year in order to get housing), but Colgate's lottery system makes it so that that housing can be denied senior year.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: Not as bad as most.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: I come from a relatively humble background compared to the hedge fund and trust fund babies that attend Colgate. Still with this caveat I am able to participate in Greek activities. As a rising Sophomore guy, I have lived through the worst of the social scene and remained relatively unscathed. If you put yourself out there and meet the dudes and girls in the Greek system you will at least be on their radar. One of the nice things about Colgate is that even with its limited houses, they're all pretty much on the same tier just different kinds of guys. Stereotypes in fraternities are extremely real and accurate. If you are disgusted with the Greek system or the heteronormative/homophobic/sexist/racist social structure then Colgate will be hard for you. Greek life is just so ingrained in Colgate culture, that it is hard to have one night where there is nothing going on whether it is just the guys inviting down freshmen to get to know them or a large party/darty on a random night of the week. It is hard to be outside of the social norm and get in with the fraternities. You must fit the preppy, laidback bro in order to be considered a real contender for most of the house at Colgate, however, there are a few "nice guy" fraternities currently. The entire system is so fluid and dynamic that things change very rapidly and houses are kicked off or go underground but you really have to experience it to understand.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body:
Greek life was my primary concern when applying to Colgate, because I wasn't into it, and I was afraid I wouldn't like the type of social life it created. Fortunately, it turned out okay. 

As a girl, I chose not to join because (a) it wasn't my thing, (b) I knew a bunch of upperclassmen girls who I respected and admired who weren't in it and who assured me my social life wouldn't suffer without it. 

I'm really happy with my choice not to join, but I do have friends in a couple of the sororities, and it has had zero effect on our friendships. And, as a girl, I can still get into the majority of frat parties without a problem, so my social life hasn't suffered. As part of a sorority, you'll have more connections and more opportunities to mix with frat guys, but I had no problem going to just a party or two each weekend.  

As a guy, it's harder because if you don't join a fraternity, you won't be able to get into any frat parties (except in special circumstances) and sororities don't have parties. So joining greek life is a bigger deal for guys. 

That said, there are plenty of other opportunities to socialize and party/ Club sports such as water polo, skiing, and rugby have plenty of "pubs" among themselves, and other organizations such as a capella groups and OE and geology club party a lot too. Even physics club has an annual formal. Then there's always the jug or other bars in town. Or just hang with your friends. The point is: there are plenty of opportunities to party-- or not party-- outside of greek life. Though it is a big part of it, it doesn't define the social scene.
author: Senior
name: Colgate University

body: Housing can be very good if you're in a nice dorm. As you get older you move further off the hill and have more options available to you: Greek houses, apartments, town houses, speciality housing.  As a first-year most dorms are really nice and pretty large.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: Living on/close to campus is alright. My personal experience has been okay overall. However, there is such a wide discrepancy from dorm to dorm. Some are extremely spacious and well-endowed while others lack cleanliness and sufficient space.
author: Sophomore
name: Colgate University

body: The majority of parties are held by Greek houses.
author: Alum
name: Colgate University

body: Colgate students enjoy an active social life.  They work hard and play hard with an unlimited number of options available to them.
author: Alum
name: Colgate University

body: Colgate students are financially secure or wealthy, but those in need receive generous financial aid.  It can be challenging to afford a social lifestyle at a school like Colgate and to "look the part."  Professors lean liberal and though there are many loyal to athletics, many also feel that athletics should be downgraded to Div. III and become more like Williams, Amherst, Tufts or Middlebury.  Hopefully that will never happen.
author: Alum
name: Colgate University

body: Drinking is common at Colgate but the pressure to do so is not intense.
author: Alum
name: Colgate University

body: Trinity greek is a joke. They are all local chapters (the only chapter in the groups is Trinity's chapter). Essentially, by joining you're inviting the administration to have another reason to monitor your social media and what you do more closely. You're better off not joining.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: Don't eat here if you have a sensitive stomach
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: Honestly, you won't date, people just hookup, and everyone is ugly.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: Great way to slowly kill yourself
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: WOULDN'T KNOW because I'm stuck poisoning my organs for three years of my life at Mabee, which, trust me, is never as good as it looks when tour days come around. Yet another lie that Trinity tries to pull on prospective students.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: TERRIBLE. Living on campus is HELL. If they would just change the three year on campus requirement then MAYBE people would actually enjoy their time here.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: Very unpopular, unhealthy and overpriced.
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: You are basically screwed without a car
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: Geez first week was good, since then down hill it is robbery
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: I am unsure about this question. As, I did not have any luck finding off campus housing at this University. They may have improved in this area since 2004.
author: Alum
name: Trinity University

body: I mean the parties are fun, it's just that's not what Trinity wants its reputation to be so administration takes overwhelming action to prevent much of anything happening.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: Any time a group begins to party "too much" the Trinity administration catches word through social media or word of mouth and works to slow it down or end it. Houses that get busted by the cops are reported to administration and house owners are often called in and told to not have any more parties. Not enough of a bar scene to make up for how lame the parties have to be to fly under admin's radar.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: The dining hall can have some good options, but while eating there I have often received moldy bread and bugs in the food, but I do enjoy eating in The Pod and Einstein's.  It would be nice if we had more options on campus that way we had more flexibility.
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: The students are what make this school awful
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: Limited options. Everything is unhealthy. They run out of food during peak hours. It's expensive. There's no alternative. Taco taco is decent doe.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: Pathetic. Honestly, every single one of the fraternities and sororities is pathetic in their own way, so parties are no different. Just social gatherings for awkward, weird people
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: If only students could live off campus earlier.. *COUGH COUGH* LISTEN UP ADMINISTRATION!!
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: No one goes to the games. The teams suck. No one cares if you're an athlete because most people at Trinity are. Honestly, don't come to this school if you aren't on a sports team or in greek life because everyone else is weird af and you'll feel left out.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: There's not a whole lot you can do off campus in terms of nightlife, unless you're of age.
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: If you are into eye-candy do not come to Trinity University.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: Not many options and it is expensive
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: Science is extremely hard but it is doable.
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: There are very few good looking girls and most of the time all of them are taken after the first month or so... If you wanna hook up with hot chicks, Trinity is NOT the place to be
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: There is only one main dining hall on campus, Mabee. While the food is halfway decent for your first month on campus the quality goes downhill as the semester goes on, and the repetitiveness can really get to you. There is also a coffee shop in the Library (Java City), Eisenstein Brothers Bagel Co, Taco Taco, a deli place, and the POD (convenience store/burger grill); however they use a different part of your meal plan than Mabee (bonus bucks rather than swipes).
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: 75% of students at Trinity are involved in greek life, but those who aren't involved in it are still supportive and non-judgemental of the greek life. There are no national sororities here, so it's easy to get involved, even if you're an athlete
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: Since it's such small school, Trinity doesn't focus that much on sports, however, they still are a major part of campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: My first year, I lived in the newly renovated Witt-Winn building. It was close to the cafeteria, classrooms, and the gym. There were laminate floors, and a walk in closet. I loved everything about living there. Unfortunately, those are the best dorms on campus and they are only provided for freshmen. Next year, I have to live in a smaller dorm that is far away from classrooms and the cafeteria. I am not as excited to live in these dorms.
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: I was not interested in Greek life so I cannot offer any experience with it.
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: The facilities are very up-to-date and well kept. Athletics are a fun side activity at Trinity. Teams including "varsity" and club are popular, but the school does not focus on sports.
author: Sophomore
name: Trinity University

body: Very sparse, there are some good groups and others that can be so stressful.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: Living on campus is definitely good for the first year, as it helps people meet others, but only some of the dorms are nice (Witt Winn and North), and the older you are, the worse the housing seems to get (Thomas).  However, they are relatively large compared to most public universities and they provide good social atmospheres and Witt Winn and Prassel have pretty good places to use as study spots too.
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: Trinity is a division 3 school, so sports are far less important to us than academics.  However, the Bell Center (gym) is being renovated this summer and will be great for all students, whether they play sports or not.
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: The buildings are pretty old. Some are kinda gross, but they are all very spacious, close to classes, and within close proximity to food and other residences.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: I wish athletics were more popular at my school. The sporting events are fun to attend, but not much of the University students attend them. The athletic facilities are pretty gross and old.
author: Junior
name: Trinity University

body: It's what you make of it. If you have a bunch of friends and want to drink and smoke at campus you can. If you want to go to a club/bar and have ID's theres a fair amount of places to go, and Trinity kids are especially out in full force on thursdays (affectionately called thursbays) otherwise, they're pretty routinely frat parties which, if you make an effort to meet people, shouldn't be too difficult to get into.
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: It's more diverse then most schools, but it's still someone white dominate.
author: Freshman
name: Trinity University

body: Owen is a dump. I would never recommend it to a friend or enemy.
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: They rarely give out aid + scholarships in a great amount, and now that my parents aren't paying for part of my tuition anymore, I don't think I can go back.
author: Sophomore
name: Purdue University

body: The parking at process at Purdue is the absolute worst. The only reason you should not want to come to Purdue is because of parking. You can't park for more than 2 hours in one spot any time between 7am and 5pm. It's miserable to walk to class when it's cold, but parking is even more miserable. Just walk to class. You most likely won't find a close spot.
author: Junior
name: Purdue University

body: Weather is horrible, considering I'm used to the Texas heat.
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: The winters are horrible I grew up in Indiana wether and I still hate it. The side walks cannot unfreeze because it is often to cold for the salt to work. Some times the off campus side walks are better than on campus just because they are used less. Other times while walking into campus students have to walk on the roads.
author: Sophomore
name: Purdue University

body: The avaliable parking garages are not open to general public exept for M-F 5-7 and weekends the fact that you have to pay so much for a pass that would let you park in them the other times is crazy! Parking off campus is not very bad exept for some places only have 2 hour parking exept for M-F 7-7 and weekends
author: Sophomore
name: Purdue University

body: The most of the students that go to Purdue are narrow minded, but that is what you get when you go to school in Indiana. It is a place that is very judgmental and very segregated.
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: So expensive, a terrible experience
author: Sophomore
name: Purdue University

body: Is Indiana so the weather is always changing.
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: Beyond hot in the fall and many dorms have no A/C. This winter was the coldest and snowiest in decades. The walkways turn to ice with so many feet pressing the remnants of plowed snow down. This makes getting around very difficult. It's often just easier to walk thru the snow. Then there's the wind. The weather is NOT the reason anyone goes to Purdue.
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: You are required to pay so much money to live in such old and dirty buildings. The freshmen dorm buildings are small, gross, and expensive. They are community bath with small rooms and many people are thrown into triples. I hate the housing at the University and they refused to allow me to live off campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Purdue University

body: It's way too expensive for the crappy living quarters. The dorms are very small and very few are available that have bathrooms.
author: Sophomore
name: Purdue University

body: You only like Greek life if you're Greek. It's a very aristocratic system.
author: Junior
name: Purdue University

body: People don't come to Purdue for our sports teams
author: Junior
name: Purdue University

body: They are trashy and rude. Except for 2 sororities GPB & AGD
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: You would have to pay me to live in dorms again. And I wouldn't be an RA
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: I live on Meredith and I think this dorm is horrible. The quiet hours aunt enforced and the people in my hall are extremely rude and inconsiderate. The building is old and there is no air conditioning. The bathrooms are gross and needed to be upgraded. The building is just too old and gross.
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: Our football is horrible, but basketball's interesting
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: I'm a non-Greek, but a lot of Greeks here can be either nice or rude. Your choice.
author: Junior
name: Purdue University

body: very hard to get aid and be awarded scholarships
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: Purdue is competitive and sets up its financial aid accordingly. They act as though they do not care if you attend or not, even if you are a strong student. Unlike smaller, private universities, Purdue offers very little financial aid to middle class students that consists of mostly loans they must repay. It has a great program for low-income students, but it is unfair. 21st Century Scholars get absolutely FREE tuition and housing with the Purdue Promise. However, middle class students have a very difficult time even landing a small academic scholarship. They do not factor in or care if their parents are not helping pay for tuition, have more important things to pay for, or work very hard for their money. It is not fair that some students get free tuition because the school determines they are unable to pay, even though they likely are just irresponsible with money or lazy. Students whose parents do not help them deserve the same financial aid!
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: The meal plan overall is an awful value. Each meal costs around $11, even on-the-go meals, which you could buy at the store for $1! I never eat $11 worth of food, and I make myself sick every time I eat just by thinking about all of my wasted money. Sometimes, dining courts have poor choices. The menus are often random and do not go together, such as only offering various types of sea food, sometimes. The worst part is that all dining courts are buffet style or on-the-go. They should be arranged so that each meal swipe is worth around $10, and items in the dining courts are individually priced. You should be able to purchase items that add up to $10, use a swipe to pay for it, then either eat it there or take it back to your room. Ball State's dining court system is a great example of what Purdue should have.
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: Unless you're in a top tier fraternity, forget partying.
author: Freshman
name: Purdue University

body: We don't have an official Greek life, which is wonderful. We do, however, have underground frats and sororities. Though they are talked about, they are not too relevant and seldom affect the social scene. Mostly, frat guys consist of rich white guys who want to say they're in a frat.
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: Colby got rid of greek life for a reason. It SUCKS.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: There is so very little to do in Waterville.  You have to drive 1-1.5 hours to find anything.
author: Senior
name: Colby College

body: Underground frat stars are full of themselves
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: Most everyone drinks. If you don't drink you are automatically written off.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body:
In real life if you are underage and drinking you get in trouble by law enforcement. If you break something, you get fined and arrested. If you're an ass you get punched. Colby doesn't teach you about real life. 

Also Hillside is riot-proof. There is a reason for that.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body:
Most buildings are getting renovated. Tour guides are instructed to only show the best dorms and buildings. So, while looking walking remember that. Frat Row dorms are the best and newly renovated. Height and Hillside are seen as the worst on campus. 

Dorm damage is high here because people break things while drunk so there is little value. Also, there is little strictness. We have CA's which are different from RA's. Community Advisers can not get you in trouble. They are there only to make you feel better and to promote safety and community. They are like a built in best friend. Literally, you can drink with them too. 


THE BEST PLACES ON COLBY COLLEGE'S CAMPUS ARE:

1) THE ART MUSEUM

2) COLBY'S ARBORETUM
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body:
On the weekends:

* The Jitney (student transportation) is behind schedule. 

* Parties happen (with tons of drinking)

* The school sponsored events are rarely attended. 

The options you have are 1) drink alcohol, 2) drink alcohol or 3) study in your room/try to sleep/watch netflix or movies.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: People go out only because the on campus nightlife is non existent, but don't expect much.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: Colby tries pretty hard in getting diversity on campus, it's not that you won't meet any diverse people, but there are some, especially in the Pugh Center which is the multicultural building here on campus. Colby also has a lot of international students who are pretty awesome to meet. There are a lot of other groups here on campus that represent diversity, but it can be a little hard to be accepted because of the majority of white students here. But that shouldn't scare students to come to our school.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: If you're under 21, there are sweaty, gross, slimy parties with the underclassmen who really just want to hook up with as many people as possible. If that's your thing, cool. It's not mine.
author: Sophomore
name: Colby College

body: Social Scene – People like to go out but our college makes it so restrictive and taboo that if I knew the administration was so overly strict and unrealistic I would have gone to another NESCAC school in a heartbeat.
author: Senior
name: Colby College

body: The school has no connections.  Practically impossible to get a government internship.
author: Senior
name: Colby College

body: There are very little attractions in the Waterville area which is why everything for the most part stays on campus
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: The Colby teams are currently sub-par.  They have been improving over the past few years but are still around or below a .500 win percentage.  Many athletes have problems with their athletic director as she seems not to care or show up to many of the games and this may reflect the lack of success of the teams.  People at Colby would definatley feel better about themselves if their teams won championships more frequently.  The Athletic center also could use a tune up
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: A large amount of the population are white-upper class students from some of the top New England Prep Schools
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: It's something that really is not advised.  It's hard to do things on campus because you need a car and it's impossible to go to an on-campus party.  It's generally not easy and most people don't do it.
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body:
Many Colby students think Colby is very safe since we're up on a hill away from town. However, the campus is poorly lit, making it tough to walk back to your dorm when there's nothing but black ice. Also anybody can just walk on campus, so students should be more aware. 

Colby also does not follow the blue light policy correctly (supposed to see one in every direction). I have felt uncomfortable walking around certain parts of campus alone with the lack of these (especially by the gym).

Colby's security seems very nice and willing to help, but every time I have attempted to meet with somebody, they seem like they're never there and can be difficult to access

A lot of students leave laptops and cellphones around, but I have had things stolen out of my dorm room that is typically locked. So there are thieves on campus (as they are everywhere)
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body:
It could just be me, I'm used to cooking my own meals, knowing what I put in it and going grocery shopping. 

Also plates, cups and silverware are not always clean which just grosses me out.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: Waterville isn't exactly a fabulous city and is not economically stable to offer good rates.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: I wouldn't worry much about the transportation because Waterville is so boring and the lack of off campus housing means you don't really have a reason to leave except to go to Wal-Mart.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: Let's face it, there is nothing around Waterville, or even in Augusta. It's just so much better to live on campus, near classes. Life at Colby is at Colby and not anywhere else.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: It's a blizzard out here - a five-month long blizzard.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: The Jitney runs into town, but it is late more often then not.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: The campus has an average drug and alcohol usage. It is not openly visible which students are or are not drinking or doing drugs and the campus security constantly walks around campus to make sure no one is breaking the law of underage drinking.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: I have always felt welcome and comfortable on campus, but some students feel that they have encountered biases. Student groups and Colby's Administration collaborate to make Colby a comfortable place for everyone.
author: Sophomore
name: Colby College

body: Underage students do partake in drinking and partying on the weekends, but if that's not your scene you won't be pressured to take part. The school often sponsors sober activities for students to partake in.
author: Sophomore
name: Colby College

body: Mostly white kids, but diversity is very much welcomed
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: Too much dorm damage is incurred via drinking. Primarily by sports teams.
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: We have some issues with dorm damage. Otherwise, security is decent
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: The Career Center's strong suit is in helping students find careers in finance. As a social sciences major, I feel like the Career Center can be better. They do, however, offer a plethora of resources (online and on campus) to students and bring lots of employees and alumni to campus.
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: Many Colby students are part of a sport's team and take their athletics very seriously. They can be pretty cliquey and individuals are often identified in relation to the team they are on. However, our sport's teams don't rank too well...
author: Junior
name: Colby College

body: Sometimes I feel like my dorm has no community, but in general community is pretty good at Colby.
author: Freshman
name: Colby College

body: Only after a few of my friends went through the process of reporting sexual assault did I learn how much Colby is lacking. The deans of students have attempted to create conversations this year, and there are peer-training sessions, but sexual assault and misconduct is still not treated with the gravity it ought to have. President Greene takes it seriously, but the system is not set up well for survivors.
author: Sophomore
name: Colby College

body: Hillside and Heights are horrid, but MaryLow/ Coburn, AMS, and most of frat row are pretty good!
author: Sophomore
name: Colby College

body: It is bad because if you're not in greek life you do not exist.
author: Alum
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: They did not help me with getting scholarships. That is why I am looking to outside sources now because this school is very expensive!
author: Alum
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: Honestly, dealing with financial aid here is a huge hassle
author: Senior
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: It's incredibly difficult to get in touch with people, and countless mistakes were made with my file. Eventually things worked out, but it took considerable (to the point of unnecessary) brain power and effort on both ends.
author: Student
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: Absolutely horrible! Get off of the dining plan as soon as possible and run away!
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: Do not-- I repeat, do not-- own a car on campus.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: There's no where to park on campus; if you do drive, you'll need to park off campus or spend a lot of money in a garage or to get a permit. It's really useless to have a car and more of an inconvenience. It's best to bike around campus and use public transportation like SEPTA.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: There is no food for freshmen on weekends because of hours, and poor choice in dining. All grocers and convenience stores are overpriced and have poor selection. Food choice repeats over and over every day and is usually tasteless. The pizza is often still doughy. Sometimes they serve breakfast at dinner. Dining halls close way too early. 1st year students are forced onto the dining plan. Staff varies from detached to openly hostile to students. Sometimes the dining hall serve completely random food for dinner. For example, sometimes you go into a dining hall for dinner and they are serving breakfast instead.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: The food quality is poor. It improves only slightly when parents are around (surprise, surprise). The staff at the dining halls are generally impatient, mean, and not pleasant to deal with.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: There is WAY too much of it. It is actually ridiculous and not the right fit for me at all.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: It sucks!!! The quad looks nice only from the outside. The high rises are the only good options if you want to stay on campus. Insulation is pathetic and it is freezing. They take 9 days to turn on the heat.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: I am not from this area, but honestlty, I hate the weather here. Summers are hot and humid, winters cold and dry. There are like 6 nice fall weeks, and 6 nice spring weeks. We have airconditioners, dehumidifiers and humifiers in our apartments to keep it bearable inside during the seasons (and I live in a very nice building!)
author: Freshman
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: No one really cares about sports here at Penn to be honest
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: Being a non-greek, I only appreciate it for the parties they throw.. but even then, I didn't really go much after second semester of freshman year. Especially for women, the greek life promotes cliques and female-female competition. The way most, but not all, sororities are picked is through where you're from, who your family is, money, and physical attractiveness. People seem to be obsessed with what greek group you're in. I've been visibly looked down on when I get asked and say I'm unaffiliated, even by guys trying to hit on me. Despite this, there are some business, service, and cultural frats that seem great. The Panhellenic system is to blame here.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: Even at the homecoming game, most of the people there are freshmen and parents. Even then people only stay for 30 minutes or so
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: In general, the athletics are not what the students come here for.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: housing at Penn basically sucks - most of the upperclassmen dorms are decent but ones for freshmen are pretty bad. A lot of upperclassmen live off campus though which a lot of people find as a cheaper and higher value option.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: The only redeeming factor about Hill College House is the people I meet there.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: I had a very hard time finding an internship and had no help from my professors in this regard
author: Alum
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: Campus Apartments has a monopoly on off-campus housing, allowing them to charge whatever they want and continuously raise rents. In addition, they are very slow and unhelpful, and sometimes do not help at all, with necessary maintenance and repairs.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: RAs and GAs in the freshmen dorms are far to quick to break things up/get kids in trouble for things playing music in the dorm, even before quiet hours begin.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: Dining hall food is consistently awful.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: Horrible landlords that don't fix anything, and the owner of campus apartments has his two lamborghini's parked at 41st and locust--the man is running a racket in screwing penn students with incredibly jacked up rates.
author: Junior
name: University of Pennsylvania

body: This year, Penn athletics have been pretty terrible as a whole.
author: Freshman
