body: Drugs are pretty prevalent but no one will force you to drink if you do not want to.
author: Freshman
name: Northwestern University

body: I am not a supporter of Greek Life on any college campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Northwestern University

body: NUPD do good things. Absolutely. But in terms of mental health services here, as I've been made aware by friends, NU can be very unresponsive and negative in dealing with it.
author: Junior
name: Northwestern University

body: For a private school with such a high tuition, we should be receiving better housing.
author: Freshman
name: Northwestern University

body: If you're not in greek life, you probably won't have much of a social life.
author: Senior
name: Northwestern University

body: I know many people who did not receive proper support from staff/faculty after an assault. Requires a major change.
author: Junior
name: Northwestern University

body: Evanston locals are awful and hate fun.  Seriously this is where prohibition started and this is not surprising to nu students. It is not uncommon to see elementary school age kids as well as plenty of rich snooty elderly people.  The area itself however is beautiful and the proximity to chicago is perfect.
author: Sophomore
name: Northwestern University

body: As an athlete it definitely could be better as far as school pride and athletic focus especially in the big ten.  It is getting better though and more focus is put into facilities but compared to other big ten schools we're like a 3 out of 10.
author: Sophomore
name: Northwestern University

body: The worst part is evanston police department are very strict and often get complaints from locals.  Parties can never really be at full volume which sucks... its college.
author: Sophomore
name: Northwestern University

body: the dorms are fun and friendly if you end up in the right ones but all of them are pretty old and sub par.  Everyone keeps their door closed which I found kinda weird.
author: Sophomore
name: Northwestern University

body: It's terrible. Only lived in first year.
author: Junior
name: Northwestern University

body:
Very tense relationships between wealthy suburbanites in their gothic victorian mansions and students. Make sure not to walk in big groups down the sidewalks making noise. Don't have house parties. 

Chicago is a great city and probably the best reason to have a car. Yes, the L comes right up to campus, but a trip downtown involves transfers and can take upwards of 50 minutes one way, with long waits on frigid platforms at night.
author: Alum
name: Northwestern University

body: When I was there, a lot of the buildings were quite subpar. Too many cinderblock wall/linoleum floor jail cells. Very strict, sober atmosphere in certain dorms with RAs who would report small infractions/call police. Certain north campus dorms seemed like they were much more fun, but not at all luxurious.
author: Alum
name: Northwestern University

body: Ok so the standard Chicago transit system goes through Evanston.  EL stops are pretty close but if you use them regularly you better have some form of income because though they aren't overly expensive, they are not super cheep and there is no student discount.  Northwestern transportation is bad.  Though the idea is nice (the intercampus shuttle is great) shuttles (except the intercampus) can be very very late, as in this is not an option to get to class.  The times are terrible, they run around once an hour but a lot of shuttles don't start until evening.  The shop and ride (goes to target and CVS) is nice but is not consistent.  Honestly transportation through the university is bad.  We are just big enough for it to be annoying that transportation sucks, but just small enough that the University doesn't find it neccessary to really invest in the system.
author: Freshman
name: Northwestern University

body: Chicago is indeed the Windy City. Also this year was a particularly bad winter with the Polar Vortex, but you will survive somehow.
author: Freshman
name: Northwestern University

body: It's cold here in the winter. Like, blisteringly cold. But the fall and the spring (though short-lived) kinda make up for it.
author: Freshman
name: Northwestern University

body: The permit costs are outrageous ($500+ per year). Not only does Washington University fail to admit students who are from lower socioeconomic statuses, but also make going to school there very difficult for those who do get in because of the huge extra costs of attendance - such as mandating freshman to live on campus in dorms that cost $14,000+ per year.
author: Senior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: There are plenty of parties on-campus and at nearby off-campus apartments.  However, if you're looking for a "night out on the town", St. Louis is not the right city for you.  Coming from Chicago, St. Louis feels like a small town rather than a "city".  If you are over 21 there are some decent bars, but forget about clubbing here.  All of the clubs are really trashy.
author: Junior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Completely Unpredictable – The weather in St. Louis varies greatly day to day
author: Junior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Not Good – There are few parties and the only good parties are hosted by Phi Delta Theta fraternity.
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: There Aren't Any – We have a variety of sports teams but no one cares to go to or support them.
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Not Very Safe – They do not provide a "how to"manual on where and where not to go: students have absolutely NO CLUE as to where the safe locations and non safe locations are in St. Louis off campus
author: Senior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Most of the students are out of town and not given ANY directions
author: Senior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Some people smoke weed pretty frequently but other drugs are less present. Most people feel comfortable with this.
author: Junior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Lots of people like sports here, but nobody cares at all about our sports teams. Volleyball and basketball teams are good, but don't expect a state school experience.
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Shocking Prices. There's actually plenty of parking on campus - you can usually find a space, though not necessarily near the right building. The problem is the cost. A parking permit costs about five hundred dollars and each type of permit only applies to a few sections of the parking lots.
author: Junior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Fan support is almost non-existent- no one attends football games- but we have an extremely good women's track and field and women's soccer team.  The current athletics facility is definitely sub-par but there is a fitness center where the freshman/sophomore housing is.  Also the main facility is under construction so we will see how that turns out.  Clubs are even more popular, however.  We have a relatively competitive club Frisbee team but overall on campus acapella is by fat the most popular competative club.  Their concerts have the highest turn out of anything.
author: Junior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Ugh. Its not at all diverse and being in MO doesn't help at all.
author: Sophomore
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Honestly no one cares about our sports teams.
author: Sophomore
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: One in five is the national standard, and that's something that needs to be worked on everywhere. I wouldn't say my campus is more or less safe, but it does need work.
author: Sophomore
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Varsity Sports are intensive for athletes but unappreciated by the rest of the school. Intramural sports mostly cater to underclassmen. The facilities are adequate and are currently undergoing construction. When the main gym reopens in Fall 2016, it will likely be one of the best gyms in the country.
author: Senior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Nobody really cares about athletics
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: meh, people do it but it's not a big thing here
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Not because of the players. There's just not a lot of student involvement/fan support/school spirit.
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Party scene is only good during Wild.
author: Sophomore
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Not many people care about the athletics- I mean, we are division 3. People (especially your freshman year) will go to support their athletic friends!
author: Student
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: If you're looking for a school where the athletic games on the weekends are the place to be then Wash U is not the school for you. Students rarely attend football or basketball games but there is enough to do otherwise that most students don't feel like they're missing out on anything.
author: Senior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: If you want athletics do not come here. The students do not really care about them. The facilities are older, but a new large facility is opening in 2016. Many students are fit and do club sports, intramurals, or work out, but high level athletics are not a big deal here.
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: I have only completed one year at WashU so far but during that year the weather pretty much dictates your life. It was blistering hot last summer and I found myself always trying to stay cool. The winter was freezing cold and always raining and did not end until May. Which means we never got a spring. I hope next year is better.
author: Sophomore
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: The teams themselves are great and intramurals are enjoyable.  Many are more about getting an opportunity to play the sport than playing competitively.  Attendance at sports events is small.
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Washu is mostly D3 and most people do not pay much attention to sports.
author: Freshman
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: We have mostly Division 3 sports and people don't really pay that much attention to them
author: Sophomore
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: The disbursement of information during an emergency needs to be addressed but on campus safety is taken seriously.  there are blue lights all around the area which has an emergency contact button if you are in trouble, the police are on call at night to escort you home if you feel unsafe and I haven't heard of any petty crimes on campus like theft. I feel extremely safe on campus.
author: Junior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: On the South 40 where the underclassman live it depends on what style you want.  Traditional 6 person apartments let you get to know the 6 people you live with really well mostly because there is a large common room in the suite.  The floor style for the newer buildings lets you get to know a lot of people only a little bit.  The traditionals are older but are among the best options and I think the social atmosphere was great.
author: Junior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: 50% of girls rush and like 25% of boys rush.  The most they add to the college are the parties which are pretty fun.  People are pretty neutral towards people who are in Greek but big/little week can get a little annoying if you are around a lot of girls in sororities.
author: Junior
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: I see students practicing quite often but I do not attend the games.,
author: Alum
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Pot is everywhere, and the policy about getting caught is strict but few people get caught.
author: Sophomore
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Sexual assault is high on campus, and as the school is in an open carry state, its easy for people to wander into campus while armed. Security has always been friendly, but its easy to feel nervous.
author: Sophomore
name: Washington University in St. Louis

body: Not a big part of Caltech :/
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Not Much Support – Students are generally too busy and uninterested to come to sporting events, and a perpetually losing team doesn't help. About 5 or 10 people show up for most home sporting events.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Housing Can Be Unreasonable – As far as I know, academic violations are dealt with reasonably, but housing can be a bit ridiculous at times (this may apply more to Avery House, since it's a much newer residence hall). We were threatened with fines for drawing with chalk and window markers, both of which are easily removable. Also, Caltech has had issues with incidents of "hazing," which in my opinion some members of the administration did not mediate very well; the punishments were widely viewed among the students and unreasonably severe.
author: Sophomore
name: California Institute of Technology

body: If You Want to Be in a Sport, No One Will Stop You – If you're willing to show up and participate, a team won't turn you away. The quality is not very high, but it's a friendly environment. The gym is nice, we have a good training staff, and the coaches are quite good. Fan support is lacking. There is no women's soccer team, though women can play on the male-dominated co-ed team.
author: Alum
name: California Institute of Technology

body: A few houses have just casual parties; there are also the 8 interhouse parties which are really great / tons and tons of work. Literally preparing for the party for more than 1 month ahead of time, with hundreds of manhours.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: "It's ... okay." This is the line everyone says, and it's very accurate.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: The House system is fantastic. Really it basically renders the quality of actual on-campus housing irrelevant. :D You have to live on campus for the first year anyway.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Decent, basically only Lake accessible without a car
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Some houses better known for partying than others.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: This place'll break you, but it will still be the best, most painful four years of your life.
author: Sophomore
name: California Institute of Technology

body: It's a generally tight knit community, so it is possible to keep tabs on each other.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Nightlife is a little far to get to, so I'm not sure if  lot of people use them very often. We are also all very busy, so that's another limitation.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Nothing too glaring here. Ratio could definitely improve to increase number of girls in attendance.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: No glaring issues in this realm of campus life. Attendance might be helpful to be more strict with, but the standard of teaching needs to improve, first.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Handful of restaurants in the area give us decent variety. Not a lot of options late night.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Facilities are fine. We would like more places to work together besides houses and libraries.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Athletics are going through a revolution, so it is hard to tell at this time. There are many students who want to play competitive sports, and others who are there to have fun. This difference in attitude and motivation can be hard to deal with within a single team, as well as for coaches.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: A lot of people like living in the houses on campus, but off campus housing is cheaper and does not force you to be on the board plan, which is really good.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Academics are tough most of the time, but I have been told that people appreciate the education they received, many years after they graduate. Registration usually goes smoothly because it's a small school. Come prepared to work hard.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: I like my major, but I think there should be more tracks, so that people can specialize. I'm hoping to go to med school, but others with the same major will go into industry, but all of us still do the same work. That should change
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: You're guaranteed off-campus housing if you want it. Also, "off-campus" means "across the street from your classes" still, so you're fine there.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: They're very flexible about drinking -- "just put it in a cup so we don't know" is a common theme.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: The only school policy that is really prevalent is the honor code.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Lots of options in Chandler (and the South kitchen), but dinner is subpar
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: The housing system is definitely unique
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Food in Pasadena is expensive, but good.
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Caltech's honor code is great!
author: Freshman
name: California Institute of Technology

body: Most people get awarded SURF money, if they apply.
author: Sophomore
name: California Institute of Technology

body: I live only a few miles away from campus and it is an ok area.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: I am a single mom with two kids, I do not have a Nightlife.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: I never feel unsafe walking alone on campus. I do however don't like when some of the other students smoke weed in the smoking area.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: I drive my own car so it doesn't matter if they provide transportation.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: The school does not offer a lot of extras but I am there for an education so it does not matter to me.
author: Junior
name: California Institute of Technology

body: We are a Division III school, so our sports aren't very good. Our most talented competitive organization is the Claremont Colleges Ballroom Dance Company, and our most talented sport is men's water polo. Pomona is a college of brainiacs rather than jocks, though, and I don't think many people actually care about our sports teams.
author: Junior
name: Pomona College

body: Don't come here for the athletics. The facilities are adequate, but it's just not the focus of campus life.
author: Junior
name: Pomona College

body: Athletic programs are treated like a joke.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: They are lenient when it comes to parties, but in my experience going to them with a legitimate issue, they are very condescending.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: Almost everyone lives on campus, since the on-campus housing is better and cheaper than anything off campus. It also makes it a lot easier to get involved with campus events.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: Pomona was meant to be an on-campus residential community. Only 2% of the school lives off-campus, and in designated areas for Claremont College students, such as the College Park apartments in Upland. Off-campus housing is expensive and beyond these designated areas- not readily accessible. Because so much happens on campus, it's really not worth the hassle to travel back and forth.
author: Junior
name: Pomona College

body: It's just a group of people looking for an excuse to drink.
author: Alum
name: Pomona College

body: It's too much of a bubble on campus. There are very little options
author: Alum
name: Pomona College

body: There is a fraternity, no sorority at Pomona College
author: Alum
name: Pomona College

body: Guys & Girls – Wow, is this really important to you? College is for studying--not for relationships. I guess our looks are average, but we're all very smart and will have great jobs right after we graduate because of the school we attend.
author: Junior
name: Pomona College

body: I really have no experience, even second-hand, but I'm sure our policies are fair and justly enforced. Especially since we're one of like, a very small number of schools in the nation that has a ruling committee that contains mostly students. On the other hand, the smoking and drinking policy is way too lax for my taste. Supposedly, no smoking is allowed on campus, but after parties such as Pub or Table Manners, no one even tries to enforce it, and my asthmatic lungs are very disappointed at the administration's lack of enforcement.
author: Junior
name: Pomona College

body: Basically Non-Existent – There is two frats and one fraternity. Mostly just football guys and girls who like to be naked.
author: Senior
name: Pomona College

body: Recent Crackdown – There are stark differences between the written policy and how it is enforced by RAs. In the past, RAs have been much more lenient or reasonable when it comes to policy violations. However, recently there have been more incidents of people getting caught and written up/fined. Usually discretion is all that is required but the RAs have been getting more strict. The punishments are relatively innocuous ranging from a formal warning to actual fines. However, multiple offenders do risk getting kicked out of on campus housing.
author: Sophomore
name: Pomona College

body: Don't Expect Much – Don't expect to come to this school expecting to have a typical, blackout-filled college experience.  While there are some groups of students who wish they went to a more fratty college, and act like it, this school has a pretty subdued nightlife.  The upside is that there are a lot  of non-party events, so its a guarantee that you will find your niche.  Parties are out there, but it is not a frat row scene.
author: Junior
name: Pomona College

body: I think Pomona has two frats (and they may be shared with the other Claremont schools), and I didn't even realize they were there until second half of second semester. Evidently, they throw parties from time to time, I just didn't realize they were the hosts. I don't think there are any sororities.
author: Sophomore
name: Pomona College

body: Athletics is not exactly stressed as much. A lot of athletes are taking challenging courses and the coaches understand that academics is first priority. There are indeed basketball games when the whole school turns out for the game. But we are a small school so student involvement is not the biggest.
author: Junior
name: Pomona College

body: It is a DIV 3 school. Sports are important, but academics come first.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: I am dry and drug-free, and I didn't hang out with people who partied like this.
author: Alum
name: Pomona College

body: I personally have not felt threatened so far during my time here.  However, I've been told that the rate of sexual assault is pretty high here, although I don't know the exact percentage.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: It's fine: lots of space and cleaned weekly.  We have a huge ant problem though, but at least they are only sugar ants (harmless) and not fire ants.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: Some housing is better than others.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: Claremont is cute, but you'd have to drive to get anywhere more vibrant. However, I generally enjoy the events on campus and Pomona's Event Coordinating committee makes a HUGE effort to get (often weekly) tickets to events they provide subsidized tickets for and transportation to/from!! :)
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: If parties are your preferred way of relaxing, then you'll find plenty of options. However, there are lots of other fun things to do; it's perfectly possible to avoid them and still have a great time.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: Athletics are not a huge deal at Pomona. Personally, I prefer this, since it leaves room for other aspects of the social scene that I find more appealing. There is school spirit if you choose to get involved in that scene, but it's easy to avoid. I know plenty of athletes who are perfectly content with the facilities. Our teams do okay, but they are not great.
author: Freshman
name: Pomona College

body: I was not fortunate enough to stay in the luxury dorms, so I had to choose the cheapest dorm available. There traditional halls have not been remodeled for more than a couple years, there is no AC but they sometimes provide crappy fans, there are signs of BED BUGS on the mattresses when we first move in (friends of mine had gotten bed bugs before and had to wash all their belongings in the middle of the night), the walls and carpets are stained, the furniture that they provide (desks, bed frames and cabinets) are old and used up. I was paying the lowest amount but to pay $11,000 per quarter for a triple I was not getting my money's worth. I had a horrible first year experience in the dorms.
author: Senior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: I honestly believe that the athletes at my school get away with anything, including their grades. I have frequently heard stories about the athletes being able to choose their courses before any other student and the professors and staff giving them the easy grading scale because they need to maintain a good GPA.
author: Senior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: There is very little diversity in our Greek life given that mostly White students make up the majority of fraternities and sororities. I would like to see some change in its rigidity.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: I am not a fan of Greek life on our campus. The Greek life takes up so much space on campus and have such a loud, and often obnoxious presence. Although percentage-wise, they are not that large, they are loud and really affect the social atmosphere of campus. I am not affiliated with the Greek system and I am happy that I have no close relationship with the system.
author: Junior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Greek life adds unnecessary stress to it's participants. Members constantly complain about the work and effort that they have to put in. Sororities and fraternities are cliquey and jude people based on appearances.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Hedrick Hall is cramped, a hassle to get to and from, and construction is noisy. The walls are thin so you can hear people screaming at all hours of the day. It's inconvenient to get food from anywhere when you live in Hedrick. The walk back from class is literal hell.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Its very hard to apply.
author: Senior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: I'm not a US citizen and I'm not eligible for anything.
author: Junior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: I am currently undeclared. The major I want to be in is restricted to students. The major is nursing it does not let UCLA students apply to the major or declare it. Its pretty sad.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: i got no financial aid even though due to medical expenses i desperately could have used it. it is one of my biggest regrets for picking ucla over usc or another private school.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Don't bring a car. Get a vespa.
author: Junior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: There's barely any parking, and the spots you have to purchase are ridiculously expensive.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: I have heard many stories of sexual assault being reported to the school board but that they keep it at a need to know basis, they do not announce it to the student body because it will hinder the school's reputation.
author: Senior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: The majority is Asians and Whites on this campus. I have faced challenges as a Latina since there has been racial discrimination on campus. You might get attacked due to your political beliefs.
author: Junior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: People dislike the Greek system. They throw a lot of racist parties and upset the campus climate.
author: Alum
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: People smoke joints all the time, and I hear a lot of rumors of friends of friends doing drugs.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: People directly involved in Greek life have plenty of fun with it, and most of them are alright individually, but I feel like the Greek scene sucks a lot out of the rest of the campus's social atmosphere.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: I just think its an idiotic institution that serves no function.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Some love Greek life, but non-Greeks like me see it as a waste of time and money.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: It is okay. Nothing special.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Financial aid favors in state students, so being out of state, it's difficult to get aid.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Unless you're still in your first year or two of undergrad, the apartment party scene gets old really quick. Frats are disgusting and there is too much sexual pressure for hookups. The bars are the better choice for nightlife but unfortunately there aren't many in Westwood so you end up paying to Uber to Hollywood or Santa Monica.
author: Junior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: My financial aid came late my first quarter, it was a nightmare.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: its way too expensive and kept me from pursuing it.
author: Freshman
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Apartments in Westwood are expensive, poor quality, and run by crazy landlords and managers. Parking is very limited. However most people live off campus for their last two years because even with the downsides of the apartments here you still get a lot more freedom and choices by living off campus.
author: Senior
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Part of this is because it is a public university, but I have received no aid from the school despite applying many times. It's very difficult to get financial help.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: It was way to difficult to get any financial aide. I applied via FAFSA and everything, yet my school still believed that my parents were more than capable of paying for my college expenses as well as funding their own lives and my brothers back home without any aide, even though my father had recently lost his job and has since not found work. Upon being told we would be receiving next to no financial aide from UCLA, we called up the financial aide office asking why we weren't receiving any, why I was not allowed to have Work-Study, or anything. They told us that we would have to fill out an appeal, which we did, and we received only a little bit more financial aide. It's not only UCLA that is messed up in the financial aide department. The entire system is messed up. The basis for which household are believed to be able to pay for college is outrageous and the entire system is basically a house of cards and it's about to fall down. Between loans being handed out to students who are never going to able to pay them off in full, the failure for student loans to disappear with declaration of bankruptcy, and the overall terribleness of the system, everything is bound to collapse any day.
author: Sophomore
name: University of California - Los Angeles

body: Literally there might be negative fan support in general for our teams. Students definitely take advantage of the gyms and a lot of people go to work out, but no one really cares about our teams. Most of them are mediocre at best. Students would definitely rather go out to dinner or just hang out with their friends than go see a game, mainly because the students aren't particularly athletic. I myself am a huge college basketball fan, but the DIII quality makes me not want to go.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: More marching band members show up to football games than actual audience members. To be honest, the marching band is more entertaining.
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: They are very lame at CMU and everyone not in the system makes fun of them religiously.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: It's not worth your money, but you have to be on a meal plan freshman year. However, improvements have been made from last year.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: The weather here sucks in the winter. It rains and snows A LOT and CMU will never ever cancel class for snow even when all other area schools have.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: You have to pay so much money for it
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: They do not give an appropriate amount of Financial aid. They continue to increase tuition costs, but do not increase financial aid. They take away what they promised for no reason. Such an expensive school needs to give more financial aid to middle class students
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Very few sunny days in Pittsburgh and most of them are in the summer when you aren't there. Cold for half the time you are in school, winter just lasts forever. Not as cold as some places, but still very cold.  Rain will just come out of nowhere
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: I know that CMU values it's students and the education it provides, but I (and I'm not alone when I say this) just don't feel as though they do everything they can to make sure that students can really afford the education of their dreams. I know it's a private institution and that they need to make money, but, more often than not, it just seems like our school has so much money and yet so many students (myself included) have to struggle each semester to scrape together enough money to continue our education. Now, I got an okay amount of financial assistance from my school and took out student loans, but my mother lost her job and I'm barely making enough to cover our groceries. I've been selling a bunch of  my stuff, but we still have just over $6000 that we need to pay before I can start school. I just feel like trying to get an education shouldn't be so painful.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Parking is terrible, not just on campus, but through out the city. You are better off leaving your car behind. You can get around easily with public transit.
author: Alum
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: There are very few parties. If there are parties, they're going to be mediocre AT BEST.   Mostly, CMU students study or catch up on sleep, or get ahead on the next project over the weekends.  We study hard and don't party. It's unfortunate for some, but for most, we expect it'll be worth it after we graduate.
author: Student
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Most dorms are old, not well kept, and overpriced compared to off campus options. The problem is, it is very difficult to get an off campus apartment that is close by, since CMU is a bit of ways outside downtown Pittsburgh. CMU really needs to build more dorms and renovate the existing ones, but Housing & Dining operations are not very well run here. As an upperclassmen, you have priority choice in dorms but many upperclassmen leave the campus housing system since options are poor.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: The serving size decreases every year. The food is very unhealthy and can take some adjusting to (read upset stomach). The biggest downside is the cost. To get a filling meal, you can expect to pay ~$10. It's really not worth it.
author: Senior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: The cost of parking increases almost annually and the lots fill up really quickly. They're only free after 4pm(ish?) and weekends, and even then it's hard to find a spot.
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Terrible Library – The library at CMU is smaller than my high school library. I went to Phillips Exeter, where the library was one of the most renowned in the world, but CMU's library is absolutely dismal. There is hardly enough research material for anything, so we need to get things on an inter-library loan. I think this is a waste of valuable time for students!
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: There are parties, but they usually suck (bad music, bad alcohol, sometimes bad people), and they are constantly being shut down by the campus police who apparently have nothing better to do. If you're old enough, you can go to bars, where they'll have none of the aforementioned nonsense.
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Parties are usually in houses, unless you bother to count frat house parties, which will always suck to some degree. The best parties usually turn out to be medium sized ones with people you know. The party scene would have a better impact if it didn't consistently suck and if campus police didn't shut down anything remotely fun-sounding.
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: The professors here don't care about their students. Sure, they all want us to theoretically learn the material, but they don't really try to help. They think that a 'C' is okay to give to a hardworking student because "it's passing", but they fail to realize what we're all really here for: TO GET JOBS. News flash! Getting a job is hard to do when your GPA makes you look like an idiot.
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: These shoeboxes they stacked in the 1600's aren't top-notch on any front. I've seen dorms at other schools with swimming pools and tennis courts, meanwhile ours boast being mouse-free for a full month! Keeping on-campus housing is simpler than renting off campus, but considering how limited and how terrible it is, some students (who have money, or rather, whose parents have money) can afford to live in houses and apartments off campus instead.
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Sports aren't that important.  People participate in them for fun, but they aren't close to being a part of campus life.
author: Alum
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Not very much attendance at any sporting events.
author: Freshman
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: There are literally only a hand-full of merit-based scholarships. I know many people who do not come to CMU because they do not get enough financial aid.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: What can I say... it's a nerdy school. The stereotypes are pretty much true. I don't particularly notice the Guy/Girl ratio to be a problem unless you're in a high level robotics or ECE class. The guys are mostly unattractive. That being said, they are all nice and most people are friendly and kind. Everyone is intense and competitive and that serious culture carries over to dating. Girls tend to be more attractive then guys, but almost all attractive girls join sororities (there's a pretty stark contrast). Some girls care about their appearance and some don't, but girls be warned that although they may be nice, CMU guys are generally not that attractive.
author: Freshman
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: I wasnt a aprt of it so i really havent the slightest idea.
author: Alum
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: It was prerry consistently bad, i ate out like allllll the time
author: Alum
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: There are definitely POCs, although not enough black or hispanic students in my opinion.
author: Junior
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: It really depends on what dorm you end up in, some are right on campus (like Donner) and others are quite a trek (Rez on Fifth). Sizes and whether or not you have AC/kitchen/etc. also depends on where you end up living.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: The UC just got renovated and this included the addition of a new gym with fantastic cardio and weight lifting machines! There are a lot of athletes around campus but no one really pays attention to the games.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Not many parties take place at CMU. It's a fairly quiet campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Most of the parties take place at the frat houses. Other than that there aren't many parties going on.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Housing is rather expensive for the quality we get in return.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: I do not have much knowledge of Greek life on my campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Most people are too focused on their workload to pay attention to our sports teams.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Depending on where you live will depend on your experience in Campus housing. Overall, CMU needs to renovate some of the older dorms and build more campus dorms as well. A lot of forms do not have AC and some have extremely small rooms, but they are in good, safe locations.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Not a lot of school spirit in terms of supporting the sports team. Their usually are crowds for certain sports though (Football and Soccer). I wish there were more athletic facilities on campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: Athletics isn't a huge part of student life at CMU. Many students take part in club and intramurals, and some are even able to manage varsity sports with a demanding course load. However, I wish that CMU was bigger into sporting events and school spirit.
author: Sophomore
name: Carnegie Mellon University

body: You can get into greeks if you are white. it's that simple. They will allow a few token students of color in but it will never be more than their personal quote. Their parties are usually very exclusive and the rich of the rich students join Greek life. Personally tend to stay away.
author: Senior
name: Tufts University

body: i think the fact that all upperclassmen live off campus (as only 2 years housing are guaranteed) at such a small school really destroys the 'community' feel of the school. campus is pretty barren much of the winter and you may only see a couple people outside at any given time. the off campus housing spreads out students and ruins student unity
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: honestly there is not much going on. if you want to have fun this is not the place to be. parties are monotonous and rarely happen. one to two events a weekend and it tends to get shut down VERY VERY early (latest it will go is until 12)
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: If you want a strong social scene, this is not the school for you! Most parties are held at frats.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: The food is so disgusting and no variety or healthy options. I hate it.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: The suck so much and gave me no where near what I needed.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: Our school literally incorporates no technology into our curriculum, it's so sad. It will drive this school behind in a few years, no joke.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: The campus shuttle sucks so much. I absolutely hate Boston public transportation (so inefficient compared to New York's).
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: There's not much parking available, most space require you to be a Massachusetts resident, or one needs to pay for a space in a lot. It's really not necessary to have a car in Boston, public transportation is simpler. Unless, you're commuting I wouldn't recommend driving.
author: Junior
name: Tufts University

body: It's there if you look hard enough. Police are unforgiving, however.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: Housing is off-campus. You'll have to find an apartment anywhere in the neighborhoods of Boston. But there is the subway and public buses. However, the atmosphere in public transportation is not always pleasant, and expect some delays when the weather gets bad.
author: Freshman
name: Tufts University

body:
If you are wealthy or have some way of paying $1700+/month for a studio, you can have a nice place to yourself in nice neighborhoods near school. Looking to pay less than $1200? That will get you a tiny box or maybe something rat-infested in a bad neighborhood.  Even with roommates, renting here is extremely costly.  Realtors will try to lock you into "split" apartments which usually just means someone rooms in the living room with a partition or curtain.  Parking is virtually impossible in most neighborhoods, so if you have a car, expect to pay $100
+/month for a private spot or just pay oodles for all the tickets you will acquire.  Because Boston is such a college-centered town, there is a mad rush to get into apartments on Sept. 1st.  I recommend starting your search far earlier than you feel you need to, look for Aug. 1st or other dates to move in if possible, and plan ahead for the pandemonium that is Boston's move-in day!
author: Junior
name: Tufts University

body: photo area is full of chemicals with poor ventilation, and black mold
author: Senior
name: Tufts University

body: Our school doesn't really care about athletics. Our football team is one of the worst in D3. We actually have very good lacrosse and rugby teams in our division, but it's not a big thing.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: I am biased-- I really don't like Greek life and don't think it adds anything to our community that is positive. Luckily it doesn't have a huge presence here.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: My college has a very low-key greek life. They are only known for having incredibly rich members and crowded parties that have lots of alcohol.
author: Freshman
name: Tufts University

body: I live in one of the grossest buildings with some of the most annoying people.
author: Freshman
name: Tufts University

body: I got lucky with Haskell Hall, but it depends a lot on your community.
author: Freshman
name: Tufts University

body: I spent time filling out the applications for financial aid and only qualified for a loan, which I did not ask for or accept. The office was helpful though!
author: Junior
name: Tufts University

body: Our teams are not very well known, except for a special few. Sports don't really dominate the social scene, but they are always an option for those who are interested.
author: Freshman
name: Tufts University

body: Because of the addition of the green line right next to campus as well as a crackdown on the number of people able to live in one house, houses around Tufts are becoming more highly-demanded and more expensive. The location is prime, but the houses themselves are not in great shape. A lot of upperclassmen get houses solely to get a non-dorm experience.
author: Freshman
name: Tufts University

body: Living off-campus used to be one of the things rising upperclassmen looked forward to because the idea of living in a house with friends is very appealing. The rents and quality of houses near Tufts has been rising and steadily mediocre, respectively. Many students find the process of "house-hunting" and signing leases to be time-consuming and frustrating. They have ideas of what kind of apartment/house they'd like and the rent range, but these might not line up with the availability of houses and the proposed rents of the landlords.
author: Senior
name: Tufts University

body: Friday nights are often dead on campus. Frats are really the only places to party, unless you make fast friends with very social upperclassmen, the campus is very strict about alcohol and noise complaints, and Medford is far enough away from Boston that it is inconvenient to go into the city.
author: Freshman
name: Tufts University

body: There is a very strong Greek scene, and people who are into it are very into it. Personally I don't find the frats to be that fun, and the frat boys to be extremely stuck up and annoying. Usually the frat parties are freshmen and sorority girls. But if you're not into Greek life its easy to find a different niche.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: The administration is very lenient about campus security. The school does a good job outlining its rules and policies, but also informs students of their own rights. That being said, many students have been able to get around the "zero-tolerance marijuana" rule. Regarding underage drinking, TUPD does not normally write up students when breaking up frat parties or dorm parties, but students who are intoxicated to the point of being hospitalized face disciplinary action.
author: Freshman
name: Tufts University

body: greek life is fairly invisible and not really given much attention. there may be 1 or 2 parties every weekend but that is it. many thursday and friday nights when nothing is happening
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: lots of variety for majors and workload is rigorous but doable. internships don't seem to be easy to get through the schools career center
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: With the cost of attending over $70k a year, it's hard not to get anxious over whether the price tag is worth it.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: There is limited housing on campus. Be prepared to live off campus and deal with sublets.
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: I'm not involved in any personally, but from what I see and know, they are well attended and supported
author: Sophomore
name: Tufts University

body: Nothing to do if you don't want to go to bars.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: Barnard doesn't have its own sports teams! All varsity athletes at Barnard play for Columbia teams. There is very little school spirit at Columbia University because our football team is not very good. We excel at certain sports, like fencing, but not a lot of people watch those competitions.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: We won two football games this season!!! Our first game in years!!!
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: The food is generally bad, especially for the price first years are required to pay. The Diana is the only place with good food, but it is quite expensive. Barnard students do not have flex dollars at all like Columbia students do, and are not even allowed into one of Columbia's cafes. Personally I don't mind that but I'm just so confused about why our meal plan costs more at Barnard if it's so much worse.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: I didn't get offered any financial aid, and no merit aid is offered.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: I don't know why anyone would ever bring a car to Barnard. If New York's public transportation system is so amazing (and cheap), its parking is horrendous: good luck finding a parking spot (and then having to deal with NY's ridiculous parking rules and loop-holes). If you want to keep your car in a garage, get ready to shell out hundreds of dollars a month. All in all, there is absolutely no need to bring a car.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: The old dorms are very dirty and there is no AC which is rough for the first month.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: Lol nobody here has any school spirit when it comes to sport except maybe the athletes. The Columbia football team won two games this season, effectively ending our three year losing streak. It's a great school, but if you're looking for a student body that goes to games every weekend, this is not it.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: The upperclassmen dorms are generally suite-style in apartment buildings. Apartments in this area are more expensive, so it's not worth leaving the campus housing system. Lots of campus housing is actually pretty far away from campus, though I don't think it would be easier and/or cheaper to get an apartment.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: I have been to several dorm parties, all have been very small and awkward. I've only ever been to one frat party here and was not impressed. It seems the only way to party is to go out to bars, which in this area one must be 21+. Most weekends my friends and I just end up hanging out in one of our rooms. Also, Thursday is a huge party night because it is common to not have classes Friday, but my schedule has never worked out like that so that may be why I don't have a great party experience.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: It's New York City, small and expensive apartments are expected.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: Being a vegetarian, there is no food variety. It's either eat a salad or have pizza everyday. At Hewitt, once in a while at the "Home" station they will have an interesting option. But there is always 1 vegan option, 1 vegetarian option - which could be rice and potatoes. Very repetitive.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: You don't need a car since public transportation is right there.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: There is no need for a car, and I would not reccommend parking nearby.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: You can pay a fortune and live in a tiny apartment in Morningside Heights or you can pay a fortune and live in a tiny apartment AND commute to your 9 am class. Better make sure you packed all the right books, cus you never know with the 1 train.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: Greek life is pretty non-existent at Barnard/Columbia.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: There really is no need to drive yourself around campus. The only time I've seen a lot of cars around was during move-in day. The rest of the school year, however, most students walk or use the campus shuttles to get around BC and Columbia, and many take a cab, bus, or subway, to get out.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: There are many more girls on campus then guys
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: You have to go downtown to get to anywhere really fun in the evenings. On campus parties aren't that great.
author: Senior
name: Barnard College

body: Barnard guarantees housing for 4 years. Affordable off campus housing is extremely difficult to find. Why leave?
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: Very Hard to Get – Manhattan is expensive! Most of the apartments surrounding campus are owned by Barnard or Columbia, meaning that any off-campus housing is quite a commute. Parking is definitely a no.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: Most drug/alcohol use is off campus. Everyone has a fake ID.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: In New York, space is tight. It's a mixed bag at Barnard, you can get amazing housing or horrible housing but the lottery decides. The housing lottery is akin to the Hunger Games and causes a lot of stress for everyone. That said, I'm not sure there is any better way to do it.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: Athletics are usually the butt of jokes at Columbia. Barnard students who participate in Varsity Athletics play for Columbia. Columbia does have some great athletes and teams, surely, but students do not attend Barnard and Columbia for the sports.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: It's New York City, nothing more, nothing less
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: There isn't a lot of pressure or focus on them
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: It's a difficult process to join Greek Life.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: Only fraternities live together, and their houses are brownstones right next to campus. The sororities have brownstones, but they don't live there.
author: Sophomore
name: Barnard College

body: Honestly, I wouldn't know; it's fairly easy to drink at parties, I think, but other than that you have to go and look for yourself.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: I have not encountered an issue with health and safety.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: I am honestly biased against greek-life because of the negative image that society paints. However, I do see the benefits of being in greek-life, I just strongly believe that those benefits are not worth it in the long run.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: Greek life is only relevant on the weekends when they are in charge of the parties. No one really discusses greek life and frankly I am not sure who is a part of it and who isn't.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: Lots of pride in school.
author: Freshman
name: Barnard College

body: Almost no one lives off campus. The only person I know who does has a medical reason.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: There is no place to rent around Wellesley! It's extremely expensive and if you manage to find a place, it'll be far from campus. Better off living in Boston and making the commute (if you're a senior with 1 or 2 Wellesley classes).
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: 99% of students live on campus. I don't even know anyone who lives off campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: I have been verbally assaulted on numerous occasions by residents of Wellesley and this makes me feel incredibly unsafe. I no longer go into the Ville alone. I think residents are generally unfriendly and not accepting of Wellesley students.
author: Senior
name: Wellesley College

body: Everyone mostly lives on campus
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: There is literally no fast food besides the food at the convenience store and Dunkin Donuts. All the restaurants nearby are very nice but way too expensive. And there is no food open late, which is terrible.
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: The food is disgusting. Many people love the food, but I come from a home where we eat healthy and we use a lot of delicious spices. So eating the bland, sometimes questionable food that is served is puke worthy. Most of the time I have to resort to eating a bagel, bread, rice, ice cream, salad (MOST of the time I have to eat this, even when I am sick of it!) or whatever else I know for sure will taste normal.
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: the food has deteriorated at a rapid pace over the last few years.
author: Senior
name: Wellesley College

body: There are two places open late at night but Wellesley is a very high stress and high intensity place so "nightlife" isn't really a big thing.
author: Senior
name: Wellesley College

body: The town is geared towards its wealthy population. There's really nothing for students to do there except get ice cream, go to CVS, and window shop. The stores are ridiculously overpriced. It's not a fun college town- you'd be better off going into Boston to have fun. But be aware that Boston in farther away than admissions likes you to think. It's a 45 min (minimum) bus ride.
author: Junior
name: Wellesley College

body: There is quite frankly no such thing as off-campus housing. The town of Wellesley is very much catered (in all aspects including night life) to its extremely wealthy population. There is no such thing as affordable off-campus housing. However, some students will live in Boston, which is a very big hassle considering Wellesley in +45 minutes away from Boston. Usually students who do such, however, do so because they are not fond of their experience at Wellesley and hope that living in Boston will make them happier. Don't be fooled by the brochure and campus tour guides. You will not be popping into Boston unless you really have some time on your hands.
author: Junior
name: Wellesley College

body: Dorms or Nothing – 99% live on campus end of story.  You're trapped in the dorms.  Some brave, rich souls adventure off campus, but the rest of us, stuck.
author: Junior
name: Wellesley College

body: No Night Life Unless You Leave Campus – The nerds are always hitting the books.  Not even the nerds but everyone is always studying.  PLEASE be a cool person leave campus for a night and hit up the frats or bars in Boston.  Nothing in the town of Wellesley as far as night life.  Few on campus parties.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: It seems that our campus po don't have anything better to do than bust parties. Our dorms are generally clean and quiet, and neighbors will often call po on each other before asking the girl next door to turn down the music/voices. Its frustrating.
author: Senior
name: Wellesley College

body: It's Easier to Take the Bus – Parking sucks -- only seniors get to park in the "good" parking lot, which can still be a ten minute walk from dorms. Sophomores and juniors have to park in the farthest lot, at least a ten minute walk but up to twenty if you're in the new dorms. It's easier to walk to the Ville than to a car.
author: Junior
name: Wellesley College

body: It's just boring. There is a nice bookstore and some expensive clothing stores and boutiques. Wellesley is a very wealthy town.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: We don't have greek life, we have societies. Some people are obsessed with getting into a society, but most seem to look down on the whole idea. It's an endless source of low key drama. Most societies advertise themselves as having a specific academic theme (like Classics), but it doesn't sound like they are really involved with their theme and mostly get together to party.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: I've heard there isn't much support for athletes, who often have to miss class and penalized for it, and nobody really cares about sports here besides athletes.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: Everyone mostly gets drunk in Boston and then they have to find their way back to campus, which is a 40 minute shuttle ride at least. (As you can imagine, said shuttle is absolutely disgusting.) I haven't gone to any off campus parties. It's just too inconvenient and sounds a bit dangerous to be honest.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: On campus, it's pretty bad. But off campus, it's awesome!!! We have Boston!
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: The houses in Wellesley town are really expensive.
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: Health Services and Stone Center are understaffed.
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: The town is too expensive to live off campus.
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: Think of a college party... now Wellesley does not have that... at all. The campus parties are not very fun unless you are really drunk. Parties off campus are best. Harvard and MIT are the most convenient and tend to be really fun. Tons of free alcohol
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: I got a lot of financial aid my first year, but they're not providing as much aid this year and my appeal went nowhere.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: I know three upperclassmen who live off-campus. The off-campus housing selection is too expensive and too far for most people to live there.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: The dining options are repetitive and you get tired of the offerings very quick. I also don't think they pay much attention to cleaning a lot of the vegetables. My friend once found a caterpillar in some greens cooked in Tower.
author: Senior
name: Wellesley College

body: I think many try to paint Wellesley as an incredibly diverse place, but it's not. There is little political diversity and the racial/ethnic diversity is laughable. I will preface that last bit by saying Asian students at Wellesley are well represented, but that is it. There is little Latin@ or black representation at Wellesley. I believe the percentages are 7 and 6 percent respectively. There is a diverse representation of sexual orientation. Although I am straight, if I identified as LGBTQ I feel that I would be very accepted and comfortable at Wellesley.
author: Senior
name: Wellesley College

body: You almost always have to go off campus to party. It's what you make of it.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: We do not have Greek life, but we have many different societies and sisterhood that are big on campus.
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: Housing is extremely pricey and the meal plan is necessary for all students. The rooms are a little small and some of the buildings are starting to show their age.
author: Student
name: Wellesley College

body: No one cares about athletics, but the gym is nice
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: No one pays particular attention, but I think we all support our fellow student athletes.
author: Alum
name: Wellesley College

body: Women's college, therefore all sports are played in women's league. Athletic facilities very good, but small because student population is very small, due to Wellesley being a small liberal arts college.
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: The academics are undoubtedly rigorous, but I didn't find that there was any focus placed on improving individual performance. You were evaluated harshly and that was it; hardly any feedback or expectation that you could do better. The registration process is stressful, and a few students are not able to get into the classes they need each semester. In my opinion, the workload was a bit ridiculous; some courses had some 10+ hours of outside instruction that were practically mandatory (about 75% of the students attended them) if you wanted to even pass, let alone do well.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body:
The hours are awful, and care is rudimentary. Health services has a couple of walk in hours every weekday, usually during class time, and everything else must be scheduled over the phone. The services are really only equipped to treat minor ailments and chronic conditions. 

Counseling services are also rudimentary; I was told when I visited that they were not equipped to treat my obsessive compulsive disorder. However, my counselor was very nice. They can prescribe any necessary psychiatric medications.

There is almost no crime on campus and it feels very safe to walk around even in the middle of the night.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: Mostly too expensive to afford. Everyone orders takeout from the same Thai restaurant.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body:
A lot of my peers had to live in single rooms converted into doubles, and most of the physically attractive and historical buildings are run down and moldy. Bathrooms can get pretty gross in the older buildings. In my opinion, living on east side is just much more pleasant because the buildings are new ish and livable, with spacious rooms, even if many consider Tower to be the "best" dorm. But I can certainly imagine it being worse.

The housing process this year was pretty messed up because large groups would block together across classes and take all the good rooms. Lottery numbers are given out according to class year, with rising seniors having the highest numbers and first years having the lowest. If you knew a junior with a good lottery number as a first year, you would get first pick of the rooms among your peers, leaving the rest of us either unhoused or in a crap room.

People are a bit obsessed with being quiet in the dorms, even in the middle of the day or on a Friday night. Even as someone who hardly ever makes noise and doesn't party, listening to people whine about how they can't study because someone is talking to their friend OUTSIDE the building gets old really fast.

Students speak disdainfully about "THOSE dorms" that are located far away from the social areas of campus and whine incessantly if they get assigned to these dorms, even if said dorms are really not bad at all. In fact, most dorms are located quite close to the academic buildings, which is convenient.
author: Sophomore
name: Wellesley College

body: Financial aid is bragged about but it is sometimes more of a pain than expected
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: Some houses are old some are newer but altogether pretty livable
author: Freshman
name: Wellesley College

body: Way too much Greek Life
author: Junior
name: Boston University

body: It sucks major time. The freshman dorms are horrible. There is no space and no A/C.
author: Freshman
name: Boston University

body: the health center is terrible
author: Freshman
name: Boston University

body: It is difficult to determine the level of crime on campus because barely anything is reported to students from the Boston University police. The police are essentially on campus to protect the students, and students do not get in trouble for smoking weed or violating the law because they are "BU affiliated". This allows BU to sweep a lot of things under the rug. Campus is generally safe even at night, but the "safewalk" program that takes students home between 10 pm and 2 am are other students walking with you and they are typically snarky to do so.
author: Freshman
name: Boston University

body: The housing system is absolutely poor.  They charge thousands of dollars and jampack multiple students in rooms only meant for one.  They take old decrepid buildings, put a BU sign on it and that's it.  No renovations or even safety measures have been made.  Very disappointed.
author: Sophomore
name: Boston University

body: They don't have many scholarships for people based on academic success.
author: Freshman
name: Boston University

body: If you love not spacious and super expensive housing, that's the place to go.
author: Alum
name: Boston University

body: Greek life is dead because of the strict policy BU follows.
author: Alum
name: Boston University

body: Cops bust the parties all the time.
author: Alum
name: Boston University

body: I am quite upset with Boston University's Financial Aid System. I don't understand how a university with so much money has very limited options for financial aid. They don't have much money to help students attend and cover the high costs.
author: Sophomore
name: Boston University

body: It's Boston, it's expensive and not super close. Not worth it, just take advantage of the awesome brownstones and StuVi
author: Freshman
name: Boston University

body: You either get all the money or none.
author: Freshman
name: Boston University

body: Although I feel safe walking down campus at night, one step into Allston and I need to be in a group. Sexual assault issues are very real, just as any campus in the country. It's best to just watch your back and you'll probably be fine.
author: Junior
name: Boston University

body: Being a guy, I do not even think about being sexually assaulted or harassed. However, I have had some girl friends who have been harassed, one of them buy a professor, The school did not do anything about it, only a slap on the wrist.
author: Senior
name: Boston University

body: I am not in Greek life nor am I interested in it. Fraternities and sororities do not seem to do anything but party. Some of my greek friends are quite intelligent and nice.
author: Senior
name: Boston University

body: Rooms are very small, bathrooms are not always clean. Social atmosphere is too quiet. Food downstairs is bad. And doors shake, windows shake, weird smells from dinging hall come inside the room through the window every day.
author: Freshman
name: Boston University

body: From what I have heard, BU has a very bad reputation for sexual assault. However, you can also see that they are trying to improve the conditions with programs like SARP.
author: Freshman
name: Boston University

body: Its good that there is not much Greek Life.
author: Alum
name: Boston University

body: The people in it love it, but as someone who never had interest in joining, it continues to seem overrated at best and potentially dangerous/threatening at worst.
author: Senior
name: University of Florida

body:
greek housing is amazing and cheap

greeks are cliquish and dont make friends with anyone else

if youre not greek you hate the greek community
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: Many people who join fraternities or sororities look down upon those who do not. For some reason they believe they're better than everyone else. It's really sad to see.
author: Junior
name: University of Florida

body: cafeteria was dirty and had bugs
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: The Dorms were small dirty and  unsocial
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: unorganized and all over the place
author: Sophomore
name: University of Florida

body: Only live in a dorm if you know who you're going to be living with. Their lottery system is terrible, they'll assign to someone who you're not compatible with.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Florida

body: Getting grants and scholarships is like winning the lottery, there is almost no way to guarantee help even if you are very intelligent, active, and in need. There is no compassion from the aid office.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Florida

body: Very hard to receive financial aid or scholarships
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: Scholarships and dealing with the financial aid office is pretty tedious, but manageable.
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: I live in an economy triple. It is a room made for 2 people, and they stuck my initial roommate and I with an extra person. It ended up being fine because we all get along great, but it is extremely small. I live in Broward. Broward and Jennings are the most social dorms and are right next to classes. Rawlings is pretty social too. Murphree and Springs on the other hand are extremely far, and you have to take a bus or walk 20 minutes to get to class.
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: This is probably biased because I don't like Greek Life, but it's a huge part of campus life. You never go a day without seeing several people wearing their fraternity/sorority shirt, and their attitudes are generally cliquey and snobby. I live across from frat row and every night, there's a party. Literally every night, I hear music blaring from one of the frat houses. You have to wonder if they're actually getting anything done academically.
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: I only give Greek Life a low rating because it is polarizing and manipulative. Students are strongly encouraged to join Greek Life not only for the opportunities they offer but mostly because there is a stigma around not being involved in Greek Life.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Florida

body: The dorms are run down and most don't have private bathrooms
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: Unless you are getting off campus, extremely new, expensive and hard to get housing, the general housing options are fairly poor. The buildings are old and not renovated. The cleanliness is low and the buildings are dirty both on the outside and the inside. Where most colleges offer bathrooms inside the dorms, most of the dorms here have community style bathrooms. There are very few apartment-style or even split dorms available.
author: Freshman
name: University of Florida

body: I'm not exactly the best person to talk to about describing the Greek Life because I view it as frivolous and meaningless.  However, my attitude extends beyond that in pointing out that the fact that Greek Life is highly integrated into student government means that any policies passed have a pro Greek agenda.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Florida

body: I have never had the urge to join the Greek community and I don't regret it.
author: Senior
name: University of Florida

body: We don't have greek life, so a lot of the social scene is determined by sports teams, both varsity and club.
author: Junior
name: Middlebury College

body: There's pretty much nowhere else to live, which is why 99% of people just live on campus. I think seniors might have a lottery that lets them live off campus, but it's so difficult not a lot of them do it. It's just no worth it.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: Off-campus housing is near non-existant.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: The town of Middlebury is painfully remote, with only a few small restaurants, a grocery store, and family-owned shops. It is a safe area, for the most part, with little crime reported. The local population is surprisingly unfriendly with students from the college. Despite the fact that Middlebury donates millions of dollars each year to support the town in different ways, many locals resent the college's presence. In large part because of this hostility, students rarely venture off campus.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: There are three dining halls on campus. Two, Proctor and Ross, are open everyday and located conveniently near the center of campus. The nicest one, Atwater, is open only for lunch, Monday through Friday, and can be found at the corner of campus. The hours for Ross and Proctor are not very convenient. The halls open each day at 7, closed between 2-4p, and then closed at 8p. As an international student from Spain, this is a very difficult schedule to follow. I am accustomed to eating lunch between 2 and 4p and dinner between 9 and 10p. In addition, the course and sports schedules make it difficult to get lunch and dinner while the halls are open. I often miss meals, and not by choice. The food itself is not great. Everyone knows to avoid certain days and certain foods at Proctor, thus the lines at Ross are consistently massive. It is not uncommon to wait an hour in line for dinner at Ross dining hall. I have spent a lot of time at a number of other similar colleges and universities, and I am overall thoroughly disappointed with the food and dining at Middlebury.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: Either nonexistent or horribly run.
author: Junior
name: Middlebury College

body: Other than Mcdonalds which is only accessible by car, the only reliable and tasty option is Magic Wok, a chinese place.  Otherwise, when the dining halls (which are mediocre at best at every meal besides breakfast, which is heavenly) close at 8pm, there is no place to get food.
author: Junior
name: Middlebury College
