body: The housing lottery system is ridiculous and has not an ounce of fairness in it.  The dorms are not very clean.  The social life is horrible unless you are rich, white, preppy, elitist new englander or wanna be new englander or are one of the hippie, environmentalist, protest crazies.
author: Junior
name: Middlebury College

body: The college is strict about all the wrong things.
author: Junior
name: Middlebury College

body: A Bunch of Rich White Kids – What do you expect at a college that costs 56,000 a year to go to? There is a bit of diversity, but the black kids are actually from Africa and the asian kids are usually from asia. There aren't many ethnic kids from america
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: Not Much Going on – Townies are pretty weird, and there isn't anything to do in town unless you're 21.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: It is bad for underclassmen and only good for some upperclassmen depending on the dorm.
author: Alum
name: Middlebury College

body:
We Don't Have One. We have co-ed social houses in place of frats and sororities.

Some throw decent parties, but they are nothing special. Each house has a "type" although almost anyone can pledge. KDR for example is filled with urban-oriented kids while "the Mill" is for hipsters and ADP is filled with football players and their girlfriends.
author: Senior
name: Middlebury College

body: Not So Much – There is not much, there is a 24 hour diner on the weekend, a sandwich shop, an Indian restaurant and a Chinese restaurant, but don't go on the look out for quality ethnic food, there is none.
author: Junior
name: Middlebury College

body: High international diversity, which is also aided in senior year by the high number of students who return from studying abroad. Shockingly low socioeconomic diversity. Get used to seeing those BMWs and Audi SUVs around town...
author: Alum
name: Middlebury College

body: It's a well-known liberal arts college in the north-east but not so much elsewhere. The career center counseling was poor.
author: Alum
name: Middlebury College

body:
People here are pretty aware of sexual assault, but no one ever believes that it can really happen to them (or that they or someone they're close to can be a perpetrator). Most of the time it's not "intentional" in that people get intoxicated and take advantage of others, using drugs as an excuse. It isn't though, and the horrible drinking culture on our campus combined with a general lack of respect in the partying scene contributes a lot to assaults and a feeling of unsafeness. 

As far as administrative response, I'm not sure of the specifics of the process but the general sense is that they care more about Midd's image than victims/survivors. Which is probably why, among other reasons, when two of my friends experienced incidents, neither of them felt comfortable going to administrators. Compliance with Title 9 doesn't equal full-fledged support. Things are getting better I think, but there's till a long way to go.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: The general Midd party scene isn't really my thing, although there are alternatives (Palana, Meeker, Q/A) that are moderately better. Then again there's never a guarantee that parties will be any good here. And the atmosphere of all of them is pretty unsafe. I've had some pretty creepy experiences, and 2 of my 5 closest friends have been harassed as well. Overall things are pretty unsafe, and you'll probably have more fun pregaming and chilling with friends rather than taking your chances at a party.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: There are maybe three or four places close enough to walk to in town. There's one Chinese place you can order from until around 10 or 11. If you want to eat somewhere else or want some late night food, you either have to drive (or walk an hour if you're really desperate) to McDonalds or you're out of luck.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: The typical student at Midd is from a boarding or private school, has at least 2 houses, and speaks more than one language. Some girls take trips to St. Barths for the weekend. Its a bit much and the elitist atmosphere is in your face. I am transferring out of Middlebuy because of the people here. I was bullied for a medical condition.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: There is a lot of drinking on campus; I would argue more than at big state schools. Combine that with large male athletes and you have a problem. One that Middlebury is not trying to solve. I wil not speak on personal situations; I have had a few very very bad ones. The mentality of a lot of athletes here is that the girls are prey. Every hear the guy seniors host a "predator/prey" party where they invite freshan girls and get them drunk. And yes the school does know about this. Do not go out alone.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: First year housing is based on your first year seminars and the rooms range from extremely nice to extremely unpleasant depending on which hall you get allocated. In my case, I got allocated to the most "social" one but also the worst one in terms of amenities. It's all based on luck.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: Very few restaurants to choose from, not much on the menu. Customer service not great. Locals don't really love the students, as in some college towns.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: I chose a cold school because I really didn't want a warm school (general sweatiness = gross), and like cold winters.  The problem with Middlebury is, winter never really goes away.  Even when it warms up, there are sporadic freezing days, which can get depressing - the fact that winter never goes away.  The bigger problem is at night though.  Drunkenness/cold are not the greatest mix, and jacket-weather while going out = decent chance of walking home from a party in the cold without a jacket.  There's also a pretty serious ice problem in the spring.  We'll get rain/snow during the day, have it melt, and then refreeze at night, so the paths late at night/the next morning are dangerously icy.  Lots of people fall, and a few people get hurt every year from it.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: It is possible to get off of campus, but unless you have a car, it's not easy.  There are school run shuttles to the airport for breaks, but they're typically pretty inconvenient with when they're run.  The same goes for shuttles to the snow bowl.  To go anywhere else requires booking a car service (expensive), or having a car.  There are zipcars on campus (I think), but they're pretty much unused (really not sure why).
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: 1 coed frat. Some fun thursdays, not much else
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: While the use of hard drugs like cocaine and heroin is more out of sight (you have to seek it out but there are plenty of people doing it), the use of Marijuana is EVERYWHERE.  The smell is horrible and public safety never does anything about it.  The administration is stricter on alcohol, both those under and over 21, then any kind of drugs.
author: Junior
name: Middlebury College

body: Negative temperatures are a regular occurrence in December and January.  Spring doesn't really being until May, by which point there are only two weeks of school left.
author: Junior
name: Middlebury College

body: Transportation to and from the airport is extremely costly, and Burlington is hard to get to without your own car.
author: Senior
name: Middlebury College

body: Lots of alcohol and some drugs, but its easy to avoid both.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: It is very hit or miss, but nothing is terrible. No off campus housing. Freshmen and sophomore dorms are linked and generally the worst freshmen dorms get the best sophomore dorms (i.e. Battell to Gifford), which is at least fair.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: People here love being on sports teams. Sucks if you're not. You learn to resent the kids on the sports teams. Does not make for a healthy happy environment.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: Most of the social life is focused on drinking.
author: Alum
name: Middlebury College

body: As a part of the racial and socioeconomic majority on campus, I feel safe. However, many minority friends do not.
author: Alum
name: Middlebury College

body: Small rooms and noise travels far.
author: Alum
name: Middlebury College

body: You can can find parties every Saturday night going down in either Atwater or Palmer as well as a few other houses on campus. Friday nights can be a little more dead but still usually happening. Thursdays and Sundays can also be fun, depending on the week.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: I know there isn't much.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: When it's good it's good. When it's happening.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: A couple of pretty good joints but that's it.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: If you're into preppy New England white folks you're set. If not, you still have some options. Everyone who attends this school is weirdly attractive, and if not by whoever's standards, they have personalities/passions to more than make up for it. People here aren't particularly into relationships but things are so busy and fast-paced that it's less of an aversion and more of just literally not having the time. If you're into the hook-up scene, whoever you are, it'll be fairly easy to find someone who wants your body. it's much harder to find a commitment though.
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body:
Housing is pretty good overall. Freshman year I ended up getting one of the best dorms (Allen) so I had a pretty good time. But god help you if you get stuck in Battell...Overall though all of the dorms are decent, although things can get pretty grimey Friday and Saturday nights what with all the partying. Also be warned, if some drunk bros decide to break a window or something, your entire floor is paying for it.

Some dorms like the one I was in area bit farther away from the main part of campus, but everything's pretty walkable. The social atmosphere really depends on the type of person you are. If you fit in well with the dominant Middlebury culture chances are you'll have a good time (and if you're not sure what that is I'll break it down in 3 words: Patagonia, PolySci/Econ/Neuroscience Majors/Nalgene Water Bottles).
author: Freshman
name: Middlebury College

body: Middlebury is diverse in the sense that its vvery international and welcomes students of all tongues. But I have found that most come from a priveleged background. Those who don't stick together in small groups.
author: Sophomore
name: Middlebury College

body: Bates has never had Greek organizations, so this section does not apply.
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: We don't have greek life on campus.  Greek life fails to affect the social atmosphere on campus because there is none.
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: Lewiston.  Too small to be a city and too big to feel as if you could walk somewhere with a nice view.
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: The new administration is quickly changing the culture of Bates College.  The way things are going, we will be the place "where fun goes to die".  Security is very strict and for student-athletes (one-third of Batesies) there is a special system in place where write-ups for alcohol will get you suspended from your sport.  In the past two years, two Bates traditions (trick-or-drink and throwback night) have been cancelled by the new administration, and more will follow.  If you are looking at this school and care about the social scene, I highly recommend you stay overnight first.  The scene on the weekends is good sometimes, but overall very bad.
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: Diverse on Paper, Not in Practice – There are people from many different countries at Bates, but usually only one or two per country. This results in a wide diversity on paper, but in actuality, the overwhelming majority of students are white, upper class, New England students. Being African-American, and coming from a diverse high school, it was a little shocking to first witness this. However, a lot of friendships are based on what activities and interests you have in common with people, not your race.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Bates told me they would help me get home, which was supposed to be included in my scholarship, but I ended up paying for myself. Then I still needed to take out a loan.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Administration is sucking hard core this year. The students are having a hard time tolerating them. Cancellation of Trick or Drink, firing or "retiring" of most of the professor who are willing to support the students, and the overall "Harvardization" of the school is killing the culture that I have heard so much about but seem that I will never truly get to witness. They are causing security to crack down on parties too, but policies are still decently lenient in comparison to many other schools. I just wish we could see a true representation of the students wishes taken into account by administration. It's sad to see the inclusive culture of the school disappear before my eyes.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: This is NOT a party school.  Also, the new administration is determined to get rid of the drinking scene, making an already stale party scene even more boring.
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: Most students are white and upper-middle class.
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: During the months of late August up until late October, the weather is great. There is great scenery and Maine looks pretty nice. When spring comes around (usually late March/early April) the Bates campus is beautiful. However, once it hits mid November it begins to get very cold. It is very cold from mid/late November until around March. January and February are the coldest months, considering it can be 1 degree outside when you wake up for class. It is also pretty windy on campus which can be very annoying when it is already 10 degrees outside, (possibly snowing) and you have to walk down Alumni walk to get to class or Commons. With that being said, you need to prepare for harsh winter weather in Maine.
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: It's Maine. It's cold. It snows a lot. Winter is really, really long. But presumably if you're going to Bates, you know that you're going to Maine and you're not expecting California weather. On the bright side, spring seems so much better when the last 6 months have been sub-zero. And the fall is simply beautiful with the changing leaves.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Mostly only live off-campus senior year, and only a select numbers of seniors can do so.
author: Junior
name: Bates College

body: There's a "Bates Bubble." Students don't really venture outside campus.
author: Junior
name: Bates College

body: You'll realize that the groups at Bates aren't exactly diverse. International students tend to stick to themselves, and same with non-international students.
author: Junior
name: Bates College

body: Hard to get a permit, even harder to find parking in the winter. Lewiston has a city wide ban on parking during snow storms... where do they expect you to put your car??
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: Housing is guaranteed all four years and the neighborhood around campus isn't that great
author: Junior
name: Bates College

body: COLD!! Snow and cold, even though the sun is shining, just great!
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Who Cares – No the titles says it all...they don;t care about you smoking drinking having sex just don't get caught by security. The one issue they do have is the fire alarm, if no one owns up to it they make everyone pay for it.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Internet Access – the internet is really slow and the connections in buildings is not good
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: I like how the athletic department focuses on making sure student-atheletics have time to invest in their studies. They make an active effort into seeing that their atheletes are sucessful outside of the classroom
author: Sophomore
name: Bates College

body: Usual for a NESCAC school.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: No real threat of hard drugs but weed and alcohol have a good presence.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: I haven't been much in Athletic buildings, but they seem to be adequate for a Division III school.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: I want President Spencer impeached. The deans are generally pretty great, though.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Some restore ts the in the town of Lewiston and auburn but again there is no need to go there with all the good food that commons+den provide.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Parties can get crazy here baby, but if you don't feel like partying no need for that no reall peer pressure for partying and drinking is present in bates. If you like partying you can find the right place for you easily, if you don't feel like partying no pressure, and if you don't like partying at all there are a lot of chemfree dorms/houses on campus.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Thursdays are pretty dull, hanging out or the Goose. Fridays are hit or miss, could find something fun in a house, or could end up stuffing your face at the Den. Saturdays are the best night for houses, you'll most likely find something fun. Easier to find things to do if your on a sports team.
author: Freshman
name: Bates College

body: Alcohol is a huge problem here.  There are hospitalizations every year.  I believe it is a result of the stressful workload and  lack of healthy social events.  People work really hard during the week and only get Saturday night off so people let loose.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: It's cold from October/November to late April.  Winter is cold and dark :(
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: Off Campus dining is good if you're from small town Iowa and have no other options but if you're from anywhere else (any real college campus) you would expect some more diversity.  All ethnic foods here are awful.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: There are very few restaurants around. The college even lists the grocery stores as "restaurants" on their handouts!
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: There are no frats. Students create fun wherever they are.
author: Junior
name: Grinnell College

body: Definitely There – Man, Grinnellians love their illicit substances. Pretty much every party will have alcohol available, and it's not uncommon to see people carrying around huge handles of Jack on a Saturday night. Sometimes the loggia will be littered with beer cans and cigarete butts At least occasional weed smoking is pretty expected of you if you're on South campus, less so for the other campuses.  In my experience, some hard drugs are pretty available and semi-openly discussed, but you sort of have to know people. People aren't just snorting coke off of toilet seats. If you're uncomfortable around substance use, there are definitely options for you. Sub-free is pretty established here, and East campus is generally pretty tame whether you're in sub-free housing or not. But if you want to party every night of the week, it's not hard to find people like you.
author: Alum
name: Grinnell College

body: Grinnell is about 2/3 middle class kids from extremely liberal backgrounds.  There is virtually no diversity of opinion on campus, and criticism of politically correct views is not tolerated.   The remaining 1/3 are split between internationals and minority students, some who integrate and others who form tight cliques.
author: Junior
name: Grinnell College

body: Can't Get Away – Nearly impossible to get away, even for break. The college runs 1 or 2 shuttles per day to DSM, none to CID. Flying anywhere will cost close to $400 round trip. One Greyhound line runs through town with infrequent and slow service.  No train available.
author: Junior
name: Grinnell College

body: Tiny Town – Tiny town, but most of what you need.  Transportation anywhere else is almost non-existent.  Shuttle once or twice a day to DSM for break.  Hard and expensive to get home.
author: Junior
name: Grinnell College

body: Not Much – There is very little parking at Grinnell because most students live on campus. Parking permits are ridiculously expensive. There is usually visitors parking by the athletic building and library. Other wise there are no good parking places. If you are really lucky you can get a streetside spot.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: Amount of School Work – There is an ungodly amount of school work each night and even over spring break! It's really tough but what sets Grinnell apart is that most students are ok with all the work and do most of it.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: Quite remote, although the town is quaint and nice
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: There aren't many choices for off campus dining. Students can go to few fast food restaurants and some chain restaurants, however they still feel that there should be better options.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: Shuttles only run around breaks, so you usually have to find a friend to drive you, which is fairly inconvenient. But rarely do you need to go somewhere outside of Grinnell.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: It's a quiet town but you won't notice that because you'll be so busy working you'll have no time to adventure out.(depends on major)
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: If you have need-based financial aid they love to help you, if not you get f***ed over
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: There is quite the stigma for drug use on campus because it is very visible. There however is no peer pressure to partake. The policy is self government so no one really messes with the people who use drugs.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: Most of the available off campus housing is through the college. The prices are pretty decent and they are certainly cheaper than regular room and board. But you have to find at least 2 other people to live with you to make it affordable. These houses are close to the campus so it doesn't take a lot of time to get to campus. Food is also cheap in Grinnell so the cost goes down a lot when living off campus. Finding apartments that are not college owned is tougher because the availability is not great, and their condition is not the best. They are also more far away from the college. Yet, they are the cheapest option.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: There are lots of available computers, but they are very slow and the labs are understaffed. Printers are often out of paper and toner, sometimes for days at a time.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: No Spirit – The teams are always together, but the games are not that great. The teams lack spirit and the only good team is the basketball team.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: Fun but Limited – There is little to do in the surrounding town, but there are a few nice restaurants and a cinema.  If you attend this school the campus community is all you can depend on.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: Not Great During Winter Time – There are not that many options and it is difficult to get permission to live off campus. The convenience of living off campus is not that great, especially in the winter time. Most students prefer to live on campus because of the proximity to academic buildings and the availability of information on what is happening on campus. Grinnell is generally a very safe area.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: There aren't a lot of options as far as majors go, and although the school flaunts students' ability to create independent majors, these are strongly discouraged and support is minimal.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: Residential Campus – there is no need for a car or even a bike. Classes and dining options are all walking distance
author: Junior
name: Grinnell College

body: Hipster Haven – The greatest conundrum of Grinnell is how much effort students put into being unattractive. Hipsterdom is, unfortunately, pervasive. The students try so hard to be "alternative" and artsy, but they end up just smelling funny and looking disheveled. On top of that, so many of the students are so insanely idealistic and sensitive to any hint of un-political-correctness that its difficult to enjoy their company.
author: Junior
name: Grinnell College

body: The Weather at Grinnell is very unpredictable. It could snow one day and then be super warm the next with everyone wearing shorts. The wind is especially chilly.
author: Junior
name: Grinnell College

body: The town has a population of 9000--including the college! There are a few bars off campus that students go to, but they are fairly dive-ish. However, with Grinnell's self-governance system it isn't difficult to get alcohol on campus, most of the parties and such occur in the various dorms. The school also sponsors Friday and Saturday parties at concert venues around campus--notably, Harris parties.
author: Junior
name: Grinnell College

body: Grinnell doesn't offer any athletic scholarships. Most people I knew took pride in how bad the football team was.
author: Alum
name: Grinnell College

body: The athletic building is actually quite lovely and offers a variety of machines to all students. We even have our own rock climbing wall, a sauna, and jacuzzi. Except none of this is really used by students who are not athletes. So if you're into physical fitness, you can definitely accomplish that here at Grinnell. Also, the varsity games aren't that well attended, but there is support for the athletes.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: Alcohol and drug use is relatively prevalent but there is little pressure to partake if you don't want to
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: For the most part, the housing isn't exceptional, but many people befriend their neighbors and enjoy themselves. The people are the important part.
author: Sophomore
name: Grinnell College

body: Lately, there have been a couple sexual assault cases on our campus which are always quite scary, so I kind of feel safe, but I'm also scared sometimes. The security try to do a good job of keeping us safe though.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: There are not a lot of jobs on this campus which sucks, but the jobs that they do have available to every student are pretty decent.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: I don't typically attend any of the games at my school so I don't have much to say about the athletic life on campus.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: I don't really look into it
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: I enjoy South its like a community.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: It's not that important here.
author: Freshman
name: Grinnell College

body: Another key component to fulfilling the "successful" Pitt student image.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: The students accepted to this school that live in on-campus housing are rowdy and unintelligent.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: All anyone cares about is sports.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: DO NOT COME HERE FOR GREEK LIFE. Yes there are greeks but a) they are seen as total douches, b) most, if not all, greek housing is off campus and c) you can find plenty of better parties elsewhere. Not worth the time, commitment, or hazing
author: Freshman
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: People party starting on thursday, usually at the frats or sports parties. The only enjoyable parties I've been to have been for student organizations, the others are pretty boring, with sleazy frat guys and bad music.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: It's great if you want to drink in a grimy frat basement. If you're underage and don't have a fake, there's not a lot of events on campus besides the typical overcrowded parties that usually get busted.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: Pitt is not a diverse school. People may think that it is because they come from even less diverse places, generally suburbs in Pennsylvania, so to them any city area seems "diverse". The vast majority of students are white, middle class people from Jersey, Long Island, or "Outside Philly". We have a significant amount of international students, but they're essentially all from China, so not much diversity there.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: Not many parties. When there are parties they are easily busted and extremely crowded
author: Junior
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: International students do not qualify for any kind of aids or scholarship
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: It's honestly pretty disgusting. There are very few options and no variety in the dining hall, Market Central. The thought of going to Market actually makes me feel sick sometimes. Also, everything closes really early.
author: Freshman
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: Oakland has all of 5 bars and they're pretty heavily segregated PITT/CMU.  Students sometimes interact, but typically don't.  There's a few neighborhoods in the area that are accessible by bus.  Those have significant student populations where students mix better, but volume and excessive drinking are a problem.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: There is Greek life on campus, but you do not have to join Greek to have a social life. I am not Greek and after being on campus a year, nothing draws me to join Greek at Pitt.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: Greek life events are definitely not the safest place for women to venture, especially if they are by themselves or have had to much to drink. Sexual assault is a problem at universities around the country, and university administrators do not like acknowledging this fact because it gives their universities bad publicity. Pitt is not the worst when it comes to addressing sexual assault on campus but there are definitely steps the administration could take to enhance their dealings with sexual assault and violence.
author: Alum
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: Tiny, outdated rooms, for an outrageous price. I'm now staying in a furnished 1bd apartment for less than I paid for a room in towers. Ridiculous.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Pittsburgh

body: We don't have a Greek life at Brigham Young University.
author: Freshman
name: Brigham Young University

body: Greek life is basically nonexistent here. I haven't heard of a fraternity yet...
author: Sophomore
name: Brigham Young University

body: We don't have Greek life
author: Sophomore
name: Brigham Young University

body: No Greek Life. Instead there are lots of clubs!
author: Junior
name: Brigham Young University

body: We don't have it so I"m not sure how it is to be honest.
author: Sophomore
name: Brigham Young University

body: Uh, we don't have Greek life at BYU.  We don't have frats or sororities either.  There are honor societies and tons of clubs to join though.
author: Sophomore
name: Brigham Young University

body: As far as I know the Greek life on my college campus does not exist.
author: Freshman
name: Brigham Young University

body: There isn't Greek Life here.
author: Junior
name: Brigham Young University

body: We don't have greek life.
author: Junior
name: Brigham Young University

body: We have no Greek Life.
author: Sophomore
name: Brigham Young University

body: We don't have any sororities or fraternities.
author: Sophomore
name: Brigham Young University

body: I didn't have the best experience in the dorms. My hall was not as social as I hoped it would be. I also did not get to choose my roommate so that was the worst experience I have ever had to deal with. I was stuck with a roommate who had qualities I was praying my roommate would not have and it was extremely difficult to deal with. I was unable to switch roommates but my roommate ended up moving out so it kind of worked out, but it was super stressful. But I did make some friends in my hall and have been close with them for the school year.
author: Junior
name: Michigan State University

body: I hated living in a dorm. Its so small and cramped and you can't get away from your roommate if you need space.
author: Freshman
name: Michigan State University

body: I'm a huge fan of combo exchanges! Sadly, I am unable to say the same as far as cafeteria food. As said previously, I very much enjoy cooking so when I come to the cafeteria and have mediocre cooking it doesn't set well with me or my stomach.
author: Freshman
name: Michigan State University

body: Coming from a student whose parents are no longer supporting him through college, I find it upsetting that I can't get any form of financial aid based off of my parent's income. My own income is close to nothing and I do not qualify for subsidized loans which makes paying for college even more of a hassle than it already is. If you really want financial aid, pray that your parents get a divorce, are from a minority group, and/or come from the lowest-income neighborhood in the country.
author: Sophomore
name: Michigan State University

body: If your an out of state student don't go here unless you have scholarships because MSU doesn't care about you and even if your parents don't make that much money they still will want you to come out of pocket. Financial Aid here doesn't help you at all.
author: Freshman
name: Michigan State University

body: The cops are really strict even if the problem is small
author: Sophomore
name: Michigan State University

body: I did not receive any financial aid.
author: Freshman
name: Michigan State University

body: I applied for financial aid, but didn't get it. Its frustrating because my parents are not helping me with paying for school.
author: Freshman
name: Michigan State University

body: The only students who seem to get assistance with financial aid are of minority races and ethnicities. Students like myself, are also in need of financial aid and scholarships to help cover the cost of tuition, books, transportation, and food. It would be helpful if ever student was required to meet with a financial aid consultant at least once a year and were shown scholarship opportunities and options. At Michigan State, students are mostly expected to search out scholarships and financial aid without assistance.
author: Sophomore
name: Michigan State University

body: Greek life on campus is seen as a waste of time. Those who join are often asked why they do in the first place. Most of the time all you hear from those affiliated is about their personal drama, and not what they are doing for their community. Greek life at FIU is just a scam in Non-Greek's eyes.
author: Junior
name: Florida International University

body: They all use their brothers and sisters to cheat for exams....
author: Junior
name: Florida International University

body: I think they are all stuck-up, "better than you" air heads, who only care about how they look and what people think of them, and the guys are disrespectful and only care about getting with girls, and who looks "bigger"
author: Freshman
name: Florida International University

body: There is no school spirit. The stadium for football games is empty, and the basketball arena is even more empty. Many people chose FIU as their safety school out of convenience, so many people feel bitter to be attending.
author: Sophomore
name: Florida International University

body: if your not with the in crowd then your a loser so I don't really care for the greeks
author: Student
name: Florida International University

body: Our athelicts do not get much support from the general student population. Most students complain that our teams "suck" so they do not waste their time going to games.
author: Senior
name: Florida International University

body: Yes there will be times where some students get sexually assaulted and that is not okay. there should be emergency call boxes visable in areas where student will be able to use them.
author: Junior
name: Florida International University

body: Not many people attend sporting events but you will meet the occasional student who goes to games and plays in intramural and varsity sports.
author: Sophomore
name: Florida International University

body:
If are football team has all the support of there school behind them they just have to win for the love of God. People are proud to be panthers but it hard to show it when you lose all the time. 

P.S. I'm just talking about football
author: Sophomore
name: Florida International University

body: The overall quality is great, but the prices are ridiculously high
author: Freshman
name: Florida International University

body:
I don't live on campus but Ive heard the current housing situation on this campus is pretty limited and the buildings are old. 

They are currently building more housing options but it wouldn't be something I would ever consider due to the high prices. Id rather drive the hour to get to school.
author: Alum
name: Florida International University

body: There is basically no Greek housing available. Since chapters are allowed to be so large at FIU, many people are Greek and if you're not, it's hard to feel a sense of community at this school.
author: Sophomore
name: Florida International University

body: Greek is very hard to understand and I do not prefer it.
author: Student
name: Florida International University

body: Once they become a D1 school I think FIU will be a top competitor in the nation. Until then, its very mediocre.
author: Alum
name: Florida International University

body: theyre awful people and they do awful things to other people at parties
author: Freshman
name: Florida International University

body: The Panhellenic Council is extremely cliquey and surprisingly unwelcoming for the number of frats on campus.
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: If you are a white, Christian, or preppy student then you are at the right school. As a mixed race, less religious, nerdy student I often feel very out of place and find it hard to fit in. This also makes it very hard to make any friends
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: Campus food is absolutely disgusting. You will like it for about 3 days and immediately get tired of every restaurant on campus. The dining all food can barely be called food and the "restaurants" at talley are very tiresome and boring.
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: The science majors and engineers have it the worst. The classes are definitely challenging
author: Junior
name: North Carolina State University

body: Pretty bad. Its overpriced and s****y quality. Parking is horrible everywhere and you are guaranteed to get towed if you don't have a parking permit or are in one of the 10 visitor spots per complex, which fill up every single night and weekend. Most are far from campus (not walking distance) and getting to campus without a car is a chore.
author: Senior
name: North Carolina State University

body: I HAD MORE FUN IN MIDDLE SCHOOL. Few people leave their little dorm rooms on a Saturday night and those who do, probably still won't drink or do anything actually fun. Frat parties are the biggest waste of time and usually get broken up before they could even try to become fun, and being a northerner, the clubs are more than pathetic with only like 50 people in them awkwardly dancing for a few hours and then leaving by 2 (when the clubs CLOSE....).
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: They do not inform you of when you are running out of financial aid and let you figure it out on your own. My financial adviser is dumber than a box of rocks and was completely unhelpful. Just know that you only get $31,000 worth of federal loans and after that, you have to get private loans. Not like they ever told me that though!
author: Senior
name: North Carolina State University

body: The parking cost is outrageous especially because they give more parking permits than can fit in the parking lots they provide. It is not worth the money.
author: Junior
name: North Carolina State University

body: PARKING SUCKS. The enforcement officers are all jerks and legit walk around and ticket people who are parked in different spots then their permit allows but there is never any spots with the pass they have. Also I normally have to park out in the middle of nowhere when I get back from practice late at night and it's sketchy as hell.
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: I find it really annoying how much attention the varsity sports get. They have their own dining hall and it's not fair to the rest of us that they get to eat there and we don't. Also they get fancy matching backpacks which is annoying. The school should get a varsity lacrosse team and then I'd be happy.
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: The housing at State is a disaster overall. The methodology that they use to pair people is sub par to say the least. Just because people go to bed at the same time does not mean they are compatible. Furthermore, University Housing favors students that are more like the "typical" college student, i.e. drinkers and partiers who are inconsiderate. They also lie concerning different halls, maintaining that all halls are essentially alike in terms of quiet. This is very untrue. There are definitely "party halls" and "study halls," and you need to know where to go if you are going to be happy. There will be some people who will tell you that you should go to a certain hall and that it will be quiet because "ROTC members and student athletes live there." Right, the two groups that have the worst reputation for raising hell when there is no one there to look. There is a lot of pandering, and you need to live where YOU will be appreciated for why you are in college.
author: Senior
name: North Carolina State University

body: Despite being a very qualified student and going after many merit based as well as financial need based scholarships, it's impossible to receive the help I need and I get very little from financial aid. Looking forward to a decade of paying off student loan debt.
author: Junior
name: North Carolina State University

body: Housing staff does not do much to make sure students are comfortable in their living situations. Only puts enough effort in to avoid lawsuits....Wolf Village staff in particular.
author: Senior
name: North Carolina State University

body: The dorms are super old and need to be renovated soon.  In my last dorm there was a huge ant problem, like it was an infestation.  Then following the ants were spiders (the ants are food) and that was awful.
author: Sophomore
name: North Carolina State University

body: has a bad reputation here but many seem to join.
author: Junior
name: North Carolina State University

body: My bad experiences may have been mostly due to my sound sensitivity, but I had an absolutely horribly time.  The doors slammed loudly at the ends of the hallways, and in the middle of the hallways people would stomp around and shout a lot so that I had literally no quiet time.  It was extremely bad for me.  The RAs did little to stop it and often partook in making things louder.
author: Sophomore
name: North Carolina State University

body: There are always people getting drunk
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: There really are not many places to go
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: Not very much greek life
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: I don't really like Greek Life
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: Trying to find a place off campus is absolutely ridiculous! The price to live in a one-bedroom apartment is constantly going up in price, and is really unaffordable for a college student. Even living with roommates is difficult! Pricing and availabilty is so crazy, I feel as if more financial aid should be considered for students living off campus!
author: Junior
name: North Carolina State University

body: If you are over a certain point you will not receive any aid. If you think you won't get aid, you're probably right. If you are under a certain point you are forced to send in a large amount of paperwork to verify this. The process is absolutely horrible. However, If you really need aid you will recieve it.
author: Freshman
name: North Carolina State University

body: Campus crime, rubbery, sexual assault frequently occur... School should put more efforts in preventing them.
author: Sophomore
name: North Carolina State University

body: Sexual harassment frequently occurs in fraternity groups...
author: Sophomore
name: North Carolina State University

body: I really, truly abhor the food options -- but I'm a little biased because I live in the house with the blandest of dining rooms, Tyler. I wish it were easier to cook on campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body:
The party scene is awful. There is nothing to do on campus unless you want to go to a "house party" that has about 5 cops, you wait outside freezing, no matter how drunk you are, and sometimes you don't even get let in until the very end. It all depends on how many people actually leave the party. The house parties are basically really drunk people with people looking to hook up and very creepy guys. 

If you want to "party" you'll be drinking in someones room just talking. If you're looking to play card games, beer pong, have rages you won't. The party scene is the worst! That's why I am transferring to a bigger school that actually has somewhat/has a party scene.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: Coming from a big city it is still hard to live in such a small town. There isn't much to do in Northampton because places close around 7 pm.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: You have to enter a lottery to live off-campus since Smith likes to keep all of its students on campus. Which sucks, because living off-campus cuts about $7000 off of your semester bill and there is abundant housing nearby. They let a very small number of seniors live off-campus if they have good reason.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: Completely academic focus and really no social life. People are cold, miserable-looking--rare to see people smiling or laughing. Most conversations are academically focused. Parties are really really bad. The school does not sponsor events for students such as concerts or dances or anything.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: Don't live off campus. Almost nobody does because it is super expensive, places are hard to find, and you are guaranteed 4 years of on-campus housing anyways.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: Not Great – Not many local bars or clubs in the area. Parties on campus are not wonderful, either. Luckily other colleges are nearby, but the public transportation makes it more difficult to go to them.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Poor parking is always going to be a downside to living in a larger city like Northampton. Parking tickets can be a hassle. Good luck even winning a permit in the lottery.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Overpriced and overrated. I've never understood what the big fuss over Northampton was. If you like to party and shop, I guess it can be okay. But if your interests are outside of those boundaries, be prepared to venture to another town to be entertained.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: You can't live off campus until you're in your junior or senior year (I can't recall which). Smith tries to keep you on their campus all the time so they can get your money.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Campus parking is horrendous.  Public safety is ticket happy despite having less than ample parking availability.  Even with a parking sticker, parking can be difficult.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: Off Campus Is Practically Impossible – There is little to no off-campus living options for students, and on top of that, only a select number of seniors (selected by lottery) are allowed to live off-campus. The Friedman Apartments are suite-style apartments and are the closest thing to independent living available for the majority of students. The housing available in Northampton is limited as well, because the area is pretty wealthy and historic.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Too Many Tickets – There aren't enough spots for all the student parking stickers they give out, unless you want to park a mile from campus. And if you dare park in one of the white-lined spaces, be prepared for a parking ticket within 30 minutes that requests your check to kindly be sent to the "Smith Scholarship Fund" (they need money from somewhere). Luckily, most students don't leave the Northampton bubble, so a car isn't necessary.
author: Senior
name: Smith College

body: Yeah....About That. Smith dining is very traditional. You sit down and eat in a dining room three times a day and eat whatever they decide to serve you. You're at the mercy of the menu and there ARE NO STAPLE FOODS (except maybe the salad bar). Terrifying? It can be. You can pretty much guarantee anything mom makes will be half the quality at Smith. Convenience-wise, it just gets more depressing: Meals are served during the time slots of 7-9:30 a.m., 11 a.m.-12:30 p.m., and 5:30-7 p.m. I'm sorry, were you hungry at 3:30 and ready for a little mid-afternoon pick-me-up? Well, too bad, buddy. You should have thought of that before you DIGESTED YOUR LUNCH.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Nope, Nada, Never - Don't Even Try – This DOES NOT HAPPEN at Smith. Smith WILL NOT let you live off campus. Seriously. You're required to live at Smith until at least sophomore year, and then afterward it's almost impossible to leave. You don't have a chance.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: You can pay to have access to a limited number of ill-defined Smith College parking spots outlined in green or to have access to a parking garage that is exclusive to Smith personnel and students but is really far away from anything else on campus. Or you can park for free on residential streets, but you have to be super careful not to make homeowners irate because they will not hesitate to have your vehicle towed.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: The Smith party scene is virtually nonexistent except for Convocation night. Luckily there are great options for going out dancing in town -- Diva's, Pearl Street Nightclub latin night, Iron Horse, and so on. And to be honest, who wants to go to a college party anyway? Go dancing, it's way better!
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: Overall food is bland and not a lot of meat eater options
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Smith "parties" are pathetic excuses for awkward white girls to "dance" -- this means flailing around until they bump into someone to inevitably make-out with.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Pricey, limited in options, plus Smith residential life only allows seniors to live off-campus, and you have to apply for permission.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: Basically if you're not an athlete participating in a school sport, you'll almost never hear of anything going on in the athletics department.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: Our parties are pretty regulated, which means: no alcohol, low-set dancefloor person capacity, long lines. There are usually random UMass guys who show up expecting to have Smithies swarm over them.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: People generally go elsewhere for parties. Ours tend to be small and rather awkward since most of the people there already know each other, except for the random guys from town who lurk by the walls and watch the girls make out. The best parties are small gatherings of 4-10 friends in someone's room with a CD player and maybe a bottle of wine. ResLife is usually pretty relaxed (or at least ignorant) about those kinds of parties, even if there is underage drinking going on, because they rarely get out of control.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: House sponsored parties are usually pretty lame, I don't know why people get so excited about them.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: It's wonderful if you are lesbian, since you'll have a lot of dating options. However, it is not so good for straight people. There are barely guys on campus. It is quite hard to find guys on campus. A lot of people use Tinder and OkCupid; however, there are lots of freaks on it. Students here looks good, we don't really have a dress code.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Depends on the dean of your class and your RA's. It could be a hit or miss. A lot of the deans are not helpful at all and rude, but where I find the most help is in a different building where there are people who genuinely care about the well being of a student and will help you with other things and also put a word into the dean so the dean will be more helpful/nicer.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: No one seems to care about any of the sports. You will barely see any students at any of the games. About 10 people, at most, will be at a game.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: The school generally tries to prevent students from moving off-campus, for obvious tuition reasons. It is cheaper than living on campus and more convenient in reaching the downtown area generally. Also, because it isn't popular, finding friends to share rent can be difficult.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: I haven't had to engage with it luckily so I guess it's pretty safe
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: I'm on the rugby team, we work our butts off but we're a club sport, school spirit is very minimal, we don't get priority for field space so we have to practice on horse fields for out offseason
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: Health services will give you an appointment if you need it. They close during breaks which is annoying if you stay on campus.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: Students aren't as interested in athletics at Smith. The campus gym facilities are quite nice.
author: Junior
name: Smith College

body: Most students do not come to Smith for the sports scene. There are students who have been recruited to the Division III varsity teams, but most of them chose Smith over their other athletic options because of Smith's academic reputation and other characteristics, rather than the sport. The most popular sport is likely Rugby, a club sport, which has it's own intense following. The Houses also compete in several intramural sports competitions. There is a March Madness basketball tournament and a House Cup soccer tournament that all the houses compete in.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Times are not always convenient.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: Some sports are praised more than others.
author: Sophomore
name: Smith College

body: Quad but rare. fun when they happen.
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: Great transportation to other colleges for parties because they rarely happen here
author: Freshman
name: Smith College

body: I dont think we have this.
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: So far I haven't heard anything about career services
author: Freshman
name: National University

body: There are none that I know of.
author: Junior
name: National University

body: Not sure there is a career center, however I believe there is an alumni network.
author: Senior
name: National University

body: We don't have a career center
author: Senior
name: National University

body: Subpar teachers, late in posting grades, unqualified clinical instructors.
author: Junior
name: National University

body: For a private university with a very high tuition it is a poor place to get an education. The teaching staff is unimpressive and scheduling/administration staff is inconsistent. I wouldn't recommend anyone attend this university.
author: Junior
name: National University

body: This year, National University changed to a new automated information system and my school year (began July 2014) financial aid was not received until March 2015.
author: Senior
name: National University

body: Financial aid office won't help a bit. They should orient studenta not just tell you if you'll have the money or not.
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: My advisor it's absent. Hard reach by phone amd takes long to reply for urgent e-mails.
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: We do not have any
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: Everyone pretty much already is an LVN or have more college background than I do and I feel dumb at times.
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: I don't think we have any.
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: I don't think this is offered.
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: The financial aid does not help students at all! I have been trying to get assistance for loans and grants and they keep giving me tedious answers!
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: I was unable to apply for the school's scholarships which I qualified for because of time limits set on them that I was not told about. This is unfair to deserving students. Financial aid should meet with prospective students to let them know what they should do in this area before beginning classes.
author: Junior
name: National University

body: The courses were easy and the information minimal. I did not attend the school for the online courses. Some of the tests were poorly designed, did not test content presented in class or the text, and brought my grades down. In this school classroom participation is far superior to the online classes.
author: Junior
name: National University

body: I have had to petition a few classes that I felt should have transferred with no questions asked. I often feel that co requisite classes are required only for financial profit for the institution, which is disheartening for a student.
author: Junior
name: National University

body: Since National University is a private school, it doesn't yet have social student centers or an athletics department. To be honest, it doesn't really make a difference to me. However, I do think it would be nice to have a campus library.
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: Classes are expensive, though it's fast paced and you get into the class fast. But my A&P teacher is rather boring and almost like they're forced to be their making the class even more challenging as it brings a bad feel to the class, sucking the interest and fun out of learning.
author: Sophomore
name: National University

body: The facility was super slow on getting back to me when I sent emails and please be careful cause my trans scripts got lost the first time I handed them to my adviser. I had a not so good experience with them so far
author: Freshman
name: National University

body: It was cold. The RA's did not enforce the rules evenly (i.e. my neighbors played music and Grand Theft Auto all night long and I could never sleep. The workers of the building smoked in front of the air vents that circulated through the entire building even though the campus was tobacco free.) Everyone was rude. The bathrooms were nasty. No one ever cleaned the kitchen area. You could only have Micro-fridges which shorted out all of the time. Save yourself and don't live on campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Clemson University

body: Barely any diversity whatsoever. The athletes are the extent of diverse students
author: Sophomore
name: Clemson University

body: Dorms and on campus apartments are costly and not worth the price at all. Move off campus as soon as you can if you want to save money
author: Sophomore
name: Clemson University

body: Greek life is life on campus
author: Freshman
name: Clemson University

body: All of the ones I have met are snobbish and feel superior to their peers.
author: Sophomore
name: Clemson University

body: RAs are cool, so campus housing is great. Campus police lives to give out MIPs like candy. Parking services are children of satan.
author: Alum
name: Clemson University

body: Do not come here for the food. Don't judge the school on it's food either.
author: Junior
name: Clemson University

body: It needs to be reformed, but Clemson has ben working on it.
author: Junior
name: Clemson University

body: Greek life is as cliquey as it gets. Girls in top sororities even exclude eachother. Rush is dirty and without connections you have little chance.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: No student fan section. its bad.
author: Freshman
name: University of Richmond

body: The financial aid office fought the process with me and denied my request to waive the non custodial parent information which immensely hurt my financial aid eligibility.
author: Freshman
name: University of Richmond

body: Makes the university seem more so like high school
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: Bottom line: the diversity at UR is a joke. The majority of the campus is comprised of rich, spoiled, conservative, racist clones. Seriously, i'm so sick of seeing guys wearing salmon-colored khakis and girls dressing like 40-year old trophy wives. ENOUGH WITH THE LONGCHAMPS AND JACK ROGERS. All my friends who belong to a minority basically want to transfer schools, myself included.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: You will get a ticket. You have no hope. Assigned lots are very far from dorm.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body:
If You Don't Have a Car, You're Poor – It sounds terrible but this campus notices these things. Furthermore, without transportation you're forced to order supplies or stuff for your room either online or bum a ride from a friend. They won't be your friend for long if you keep asking for rides. 
That being said, if you have a car you're the star of the show - because of the reasons listed above. 
The university recently got zipcars so that's good, but no one and I mean no one takes Univeristy provided transportation... Unless you're "poor"
Oh, and parking on campus sucks. Follow @URparkingguy
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: Most of the housing in the area is very expensive, and because most of the excitement happens on-campus, off-campus students miss out on a lot of fun experiences.  However, it is cheaper than living on-campus if you don't have financial aid, and you don't get sucked into the campus bubble.  If you can afford it, I recommend it.
author: Alum
name: University of Richmond

body: Parking at Richmond can be a nightmare, not only is it difficult to find a spot, but the parking police rack up many tickets when students do not park in their correct lot.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body: Students don't support the football team, which is the best team won campus and it's annoying.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: The facilities are good, and the teams experience modest amounts of success. However, from the view of a fan/student, it can be very disappointing. First off, not many people show up to events and games. Second, there is almost no student tailgating before most games. Third, there is very little school spirit. From the lack of a pep band at football games to the low attendance to people not wearing colors to support their team, there is just not much atmosphere.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body: The police are fine, but the students often get so drunk that they damage property and make fools of themselves. I am fine with lax enforcement of alcohol policies, but they are so unenforced that people get really drunk and run around the dorms breaking things, often with little punishment! It is known that sexual assaults/harassment are not taken all that seriously.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body: People here go hard and make themselves look like fools. I've never seen anything like it anywhere else. They get destructive and act like idiots. They go hard like it is some huge party school, but there is actually nothing to do.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body: The lodges are disgusting. You really just want to get off campus to do anything. Greek life goes hard, but it does not seem very fun. They just get destructive and foolish.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body:
You have to get off campus to do anything cool. Two stars because at least you can get off campus.

The lodges are disgusting and not very good party places.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body:
Not as incredibly white as it was. Still very rich, very Northern, apathetic towards people aside from themselves. 

Politically extremely apathetic. 

Pretty good on LGBT issues. 

The Coordinate College System is an issue though, and is condescending towards women. For some reason, only social fraternities get "lodges" (read: Party spaces)
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body:
I think it is really dumb that there are no Greek houses. Other schools have these nice areas where they can throw parties at the houses, while Richmond has disgusting "lodges" that never get properly cleaned because they are just for parties. Houses are much better.

 The Greek people, especially guys, tend to get so wasted that they get destructive, and the dorms have indications of this. 

Generally Greek life is very visible on campus, but they are also worse at this school than they are at others. If you really want good Greek Life, go elsewhere.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body: Everything is too expense for colege students to rent so the closest places to rent are a good gift eve minutes away. Plus, since everyone lives on campus you miss out on top much if you live off campus.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: I haven't heard of many people living off campus, except when coming back from abroad in the Spring. It is not ideal.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: For some reason there are far more sexual assaults on campus than I thought there would be. The Health center is great if you ever have an issue with your personal health.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body: Because its lottery based, you can get really lucky and get an awesome dorm, or be f&cked over. Some building are beautiful, others are far from it.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body: Nobody really cares about our sports teams - basketball gets some hype at best. The gym on campus is awesome, if thats important to you.
author: Junior
name: University of Richmond

body: You get the whole college experience, ya know, cockroaches and all.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: Everything is surrounded by Greek Life.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: They are fun to watch and are good at what they do.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Richmond

body: People don't come to Richmond expecting a huge sports school. For a small school though, there's good athletics. Games are almost always free for students, and the school pushes spirit and attendance. I know the athletes feel gypped about not getting enough worship and cred as they wish. But it's an elite school, students are more focused on their academics, and behind that, partying.
author: Freshman
name: University of Richmond

body: Each sorority has a certain stereotype, which I found annoying. However, after joining a sorority I am much happier on campus because I know so many more people. Fraternities throw all of the parties on campus and it is hard for guys who do not rush to get into those. Girls do not have a problem. There are no greek houses on campus.
author: Freshman
name: University of Richmond

body: PHILIP MERRILL COLLEGE OF JOURNALISM SUCKS! NOT ALL UNDERGRADUATE BROADCAST JOURNALISM STUDENTS ARE ADMITTED TO CNS-TV AND THE VIEWFINDER. THE GRADUATE STUDENTS GET ALL THE FREEDOM AND BENEFITS. IF YOU ARE AN UNDERGRAD, YOU ARE TOTALLY SCREWED IF YOU DO NOT GET INTO CNS-TV AND THE VIEWFINDER. PHILIP MERRILL COLLEGE OF JOURNALISM SERIOUSLY FAILS THEIR UNDERGRADUATE BROADCAST JOURNALISM STUDENTS.
author: Alum
name: University of Maryland - College Park

body: PHILIP MERRILL COLLEGE OF JOURNALISM SUCKS!
author: Alum
name: University of Maryland - College Park

body: The dorms are of terrible quality unless you are lucky enough to live in one of the two new constructions. The process of dealing with problems when they arise in the dorms is impossible. The department of resident life is ignorant in their approach to problem-solving, and I have been convinced never to live on campus again.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Maryland - College Park

body: There are 8(/9?) pizza places. The only vegetarian is extremely greasy (I'm not even vegetarian, but sometimes I don't want a bar food burger). There are no delis or anything like that outside of 7-11esque campus stores to buy small servings of fruits or vegetables or a la carte food. Good cheap produce is hard to find. No real ethnic food (no Indian/Punjabi, Mexican, Italian, Lebanese, ...) around campus. A few decent Indian and Salvadorian places in Langley Park, accessible by car. Even the grocery choices are kind of skimpy, though there is a metro to DC which goes right to Trader Joe's - which has better food than almost every place in CP. I've gotten food poisoning from every major bar in the area. That said, DC and Silver Spring have some amazing Ethiopian.
author: Freshman
name: University of Maryland - College Park

body:
If you're a big or picky eater, a buffet style dining hall suits you best. There is only one on campus and your dining plan only allows you to eat there once per week, it's only open M-F 5:30-8pm and closed on the weekends. If you dare to eat here beyond your allotted once/week plan, it's $19 per meal. 

The only other dining hall is an a la carte style, and crazy expensive too. Mostly junk food. I had 2 pieces of pizza, a salad, a soda, and a piece of cake, and IT COST $26!!!!!!!!!!

I realize this is the DC area, but UMD is seriously taking advantage of their students with these prices. 

Oh, and they hit you other ways too... like $281 PER SEMESTER FOR PARKING!!!!!
author: Junior
name: University of Maryland - College Park

body: I was put on academic probation and i lost my financial aid. They say since there was no "extenuating circumstance", I can never get it back.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Maryland - College Park

body: The greek life at my school is really cliquey. Some of them require that you be in the frat to get inside their house
author: Junior
name: University of Maryland - College Park

body: There have been multiple occasions where sexual assaults happen and "peeping tom" situations.
author: Junior
name: University of Maryland - College Park

body: Greek life is not viewed in a positive way by most students, myself including. I've had nothing but bad experiences regarding the attitudes of greek members at the U of M campus.
author: Freshman
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: Again, save yourself the trouble and go somewhere else.
author: Junior
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: If you do end up going here, at least living off campus is enjoyable.
author: Junior
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: They strive to make the financial aid process as difficult as possible.
author: Junior
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: If you like to be treated as nothing more than a paycheck, this is the school for you. The University of Minnesota has little to no concern about your student life or you as a person in general. When they look at you all they see is the money they will be making off of you. Their billing system is horrible and purposefully as confusing as can be. They will commonly make mistakes in their billing and offer little to no help in resolving the situation. As an institution they will find every way possible to make your college experience as stressful as possible and make sure you cannot fully enjoy your learning experience.
author: Junior
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: The prices are insanely high because we have no choice but to pay them if we don't want to live in the dorms. Getting price quotes are a hassle and often they will make you tour before telling you the price. Places like University Commons often tacks on extra electricity bills. Parking is very expensive (hundred/month) and it is a far walk to campus in the cold weather without a bus route available in those areas.
author: Freshman
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: No choice, overpriced and gross. No lactose free.
author: Freshman
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: Do not expect easy access to assistance of any kind (registration concerns, advising suggestions, advice for dealing with extenuating circumstances etc). In order to get anything done, a student must be highly motivated and willing to jump through numerous "hoops."
author: Alum
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: Extenuating medical circumstances are unacceptable. If you have an extenuating circumstance medical issue that impacts your academic career, be prepared to submit multiple petitions with extensive medical documentation, only to have them rejected. If you choose to file an appeal in response to these rejections, be prepared to stand in front of a panel of several board members to state your case. Despite all your efforts, the decision handed down by the committee may not be just (in relation to the circumstances and provision of proper medical documentation fully supporting your claims).
author: Alum
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: Well, compared to my hometown, this place is like a village!
author: Freshman
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: did not receive any scholarships or aid
author: Freshman
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: Parking is not the best, very expensive and hard to find a spot. I would prefer not to have my car on campus.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: It's kind of nice because they all dress the same and you know who to avoid.
author: Junior
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: Greek life does not feel inclusive, and I find it difficult to go into fraternities or sororities.
author: Junior
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: Its incredibly cliquey. As soon as a person from a different fraternity finds out a potential friend is apart of another fraternity, they blow them off completely. Its incredibly insane and I stay away from it.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: I don't really want to go back, but I would if I had no other options. I somehow managed to stay the whole spring semester without ever meeting my RA (or CA, as they call them here). I knew the RA's name was Skylar, but I didn't even know if it was a boy or a girl. I should know an RA a little bit better than parents would know a child in the first trimester of their pregnancy. There was absolutely no sense of community. I only met a select few other people in the building (not including my roommate) and only in passing. My roommate was a stoner, vaper, had alcohol in the room despite being underage, etc. and was never caught...probably because the RA never came to the rooms (I'm no tattletale; I have a reputation to maintain, thanks). However, a redeeming factor for me is how good the study spaces in the dorms are. I spent many an hour in the up-to-date computer lab when my laptop was in for repairs in March, and it came in super handy. The printers are easy to use and the price to print is only $0.05/page in Gopher Gold -- not bad. Overall, though, I can't say I recommend the on-campus housing. Maybe it was just my building: Yudof Hall.
author: Sophomore
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: Drugs are fairly abundant on campus
author: Freshman
name: University of Minnesota Twin Cities

body: It is over the top, lots of rich kids and they are not very friendly to those that are not involved in Greek life.
author: Junior
name: Southern Methodist University

body: Nobody has school spirit here because we do not have good sports teams
author: Freshman
name: Southern Methodist University

body: The police here do not act like they are genuinely concerned with the campus safety as they should be. Instead, they troll the campus looking for drunk girls and guys they can bust and get in trouble.
author: Freshman
name: Southern Methodist University

body: I lived in a centrally located dorm, but it was horrible living accommodations. The elevator constantly reeked of throw up from the night before each morning. Also, people would damage the building, by punching out sealing tiles or ripping out the rails on the stairs. Instead of the vandalizers being held accountable, each student was billed for the collective damage, which really added up. Also, my dorm was small, narrow, and very dated. I was in a "double," but the size was more appropriate for a single.
author: Freshman
name: Southern Methodist University

body: they say they give out a lot of aid, but I am now almost 300k in the hole debtwise...
author: Alum
name: Southern Methodist University

body: The one thing I hate about SMU is the administration. I have had two huge conflicts during my time at SMU, and despite my hardest efforts, the administration had no interest in helping me. They treat the students much more like employees than they do equals.
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University

body: I hate it, I dont want to live here next year
author: Freshman
name: Southern Methodist University

body: Not open to anything other than white and rich people.
author: Freshman
name: Southern Methodist University

body: If you dont get a house you might as well leave the school. Girls and guys wont talk to you unless you are in a sorority and you can say goodbye to your social life. Most people transfer if they dont get a house. It really runs the school and there is no way to get away from it.
author: Freshman
name: Southern Methodist University

body: Parking is a 45 minutes affair sometimes.
author: Freshman
name: Southern Methodist University

body: The wifi around campus is totally unreliable. It is never wise to wait until the last minute to do something because the wifi may be down.
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University

body: For the most part, I do not enjoy the Greek system and I tend to feel a lot of resentment towards members of the Greek community.
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University
