body: I was very frustrated to discover the new two-year on campus rule. Sophomores now have to remain on campus, and all on campus residents must purchase the standard meal plan which is very over-priced. I moved into the Service House so that I could avoid paying for a meal plan.
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University

body: Everyone knows someone who does or has done drugs beyond alcohol and marijuana
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University

body: Just this year, at least 2 girls have reported sexual assault that made it to mass emails amongst campus in awareness.
author: Junior
name: Southern Methodist University

body: The overall academic system at SMU is poor.
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University

body: SMU does not peovide students with adequate support and connections.
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University

body: Greek life is a huge part of the social scene at SMU. Walking around campus it is clear who is in a sorority and who is not, and more often then not cliques are developed because of these varying sororities and fraternities which makes it difficult for outsiders to become a part of the community.
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University

body: Not very helpful or attentive financial aid department. Very confusing.
author: Sophomore
name: Southern Methodist University

body: Worst dorms I've seen, overpriced and they stuff as many students as they can into one room, not safe, definitly a fire hazard
author: Sophomore
name: George Washington University

body: No one pays attention to any of the sports, even when the Mens basketball team won the NIT and the womens basketball team was doing very well
author: Sophomore
name: George Washington University

body: This is the absolute worst part of living at GW. The dorms could not get worse, unless you want to pay an absurd amount of money to live in ivory or Amsterdam.
author: Freshman
name: George Washington University

body: I'm not big into school spirit but the unfair advantages that are given to student athletes reflects poorly on the administration. There is a clear leg up for them at GW.
author: Sophomore
name: George Washington University

body: My building, Mitchell Hall, is okay because it was recently renovated. But most of the housing for freshmen is in Thurston Hall, which is disgusting. Neither Mitchell not Thurston is conveniently located and it's a pain to get anywhere you need to be. If you're on the Vern, get ready for the worst year of your life. It's impossible to have a social life because you're never on foggy where all of the fun is, you'll have to get up early for all of our classes, and your food options are extremely limited.
author: Freshman
name: George Washington University

body: No one attends any sporting events except for the Men's Basketball Games. Clubs sports are very popular and intramurals are popular within organizations ans Greek Life.
author: Sophomore
name: George Washington University

body: The men's basketball team won the NIT this year. However, while most of campus watched the game, not many people will go to the actual home basketball games. We don't have a football team so men's basketball is the big sport. Women's basketball is usually ranked in the top 25, however not many people go to their games either. Club sports are big enough on campus, but they don't dominate the scene.
author: Sophomore
name: George Washington University

body: Unless you're in a new building, the buildings are old and gross. They paint over mold and there are bugs.
author: Junior
name: George Washington University

body: GW men's basketball is kind of big but that's really it.
author: Junior
name: George Washington University

body: Greek life is ruining the culture of our generation.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: I absolutely hate Residential Life. They are terrible at maintaining the buildings they do have and they don't provide any amenities or perks to living on campus. They don't respect Freshman living on campus (presumably because we are required to live on campus and they don't actually have to care about our concerns). I have called three times for roaches and twice for bed bugs. I have asked to be moved to another room and they refuse to move my roommate and I despite having open rooms.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: for the average college student like me the off-campus housing is extremely absurd, if you don't have a big budget you will likely have nowhere to go. most places are not within walking distance and cost more per month than the average students make total. I fortunately found a place to stay, but it's not he best, but it is cheap
author: Junior
name: Oklahoma State University

body: I don't party so I wouldn't know, as far as I can see the parties are not very diverse, being that my college is predominately white kids who have never been around people of color
author: Junior
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Friendly people but it's in the middle of nowhere. If you don't have a car or if you're a city-person, you are screwed
author: Senior
name: Oklahoma State University

body: There are no student discounts available, it is very difficult to find organic food.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: I wanted to live on campus but when I found out how bad it is, I would just rather live alone in an apartment.
author: Sophomore
name: Oklahoma State University

body: The town of Stillwater is horrible for dining options. Very few places are open late, (usually not past 8 or 9). And the places that are open are bars and that's it. This town sucks for food.
author: Junior
name: Oklahoma State University

body:
The wind is TERRIBLE. I don't know if our location has anything to do with it, but I can not get over how awful the wind is. It seems to never let up. 

Also, when it snows, doesn't matter how much we get, they never cancel school and I know of multiple times when people have broken bones from slipping on the ice walking to class.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: The Greeks are very irritating. They act and speak in a very unintelligent manner, and are very aggressive and dominating on campus. There are enough students where you can find your own niche away from Greek-dom, but it IS a large presence at this university.
author: Sophomore
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Initially when appllying I had high hopes.  UNFORTUNATELY NO FUNDS! :(
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Campus parking enforcers are everywhere and God forbid you have to go into a building for 5 minutes without having to walk a mile or pay a fee. I heard they sell 5 permits per parking space, and no wonder there is never a place to park.
author: Sophomore
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Its terrible even if you had a parking permit you would still have to fight for a spot everyday.
author: Student
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Its frezzing for a few days then it summer hot the next.
author: Student
name: Oklahoma State University

body: I absolutely hate Greeks. They are snooby and look down on everyone, but in reality have no clue about life beyond daddy's pocket book.
author: Sophomore
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Greek life is way overrated
author: Sophomore
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Housing is way too expensive and many options are a 20 minute walk from all the classroom buildings.
author: Senior
name: Oklahoma State University

body: I've only ever heard of Greeks when they are throwing parties. They aren't very nice to non-Greeks.
author: Senior
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Greeks think they rule everything.
author: Sophomore
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Some roommates need to respect the others on the same at night instead of being really loud while they ate trying to study or sleep
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Greek students seem stuck up and self-centered. I constantly feel judged by Greeks.
author: Sophomore
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Campus Police (CamPo) kinda suck. Don't do too much.
author: Sophomore
name: Oklahoma State University

body: We have had bed bugs, roaches, infestations of fruit flies, my bed has been broken for over a semester, and this housing is 20$ cheaper that if i were to live off campus with my own room and full kitchen.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: There is a large cost to the students that DON"T play sorts, to cover for the wasted energy and efforts of the football program.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: I don't know much about Greek Life because it isn't something I'm much interested in. I know that Greek Life does important things for the local community. However, Greeks act very snobbish to non-Greeks and generally don't acknowledge our existence if we aren't a part of their sorority or fraternity. Non-Greeks dislike Greeks because of their attitude and stereotypes about Greeks.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: The dining hours are awful. None of the food is healthy which makes me end up eating off campus and having a ton of meal plan left over at the end of the semester which doesn't all roll over. Also the food is very expensive.
author: Student
name: Oklahoma State University

body: The quality of the food is average and I would not mind it if I didn't have to sacrifice my first three children in order to pay for it.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: I have one scholarship that took me a long time to earn and not much time to almost lose. I was crammed into a lot of very hard classes and now it's hard to keep it and get new scholarships because my GPA has gone done because of the difficulty of the many classes I took.
author: Freshman
name: Oklahoma State University

body: Housing on campus is poor. Many dorms do not have air conditioning or heating. Those that do are controlled by a central system. Bathrooms have no ventilation. Students are loud and disrespectful of sleeping times. Rules and regulations are rarely enforced. The Rutgers department that handles room swaps and room transfers are incompetent in doing their jobs. I applied for a room transfer last December and never got a response. I also applied for room swaps, none of which were enforced. After the second room swap failed, Rutgers made several mistakes in correcting their records. This mistake could potentially have incurred additional, unjustified charges on my bill, as the other party I was trying to swap with was known to be disorderly, careless and not well-liked, increasing the chance that damage had been done to the room. I do not intend to live on campus again.
author: Sophomore
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: Not good at all. The housing situation has it's up's and downs. Either you love it or you hate it. Most students typically dislike their dorms, they claim it as being too small. Also the lottery system is not so favorable.
author: Alum
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: campus crime has a horrible rate. get crime alerts of robbing, sexual assault every single day. drugs and cases of rape fill the dorms. the faculty pretend to do a lot while actually not doing anything.
author: Sophomore
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: revolved around bullying, hazing, accusations of rape, sexism, alcohol and drug abuse. should definitely be eliminated to save the future of this university.
author: Sophomore
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: the athletic teams take all the money which should go to other facilities and financial aid, and regular non-athlete students have to settle for smelly and busy gyms only.
author: Sophomore
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: Where is the money going?
author: Freshman
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: meal swipes should be able to be used at the student activities center as well as other mini marts
author: Sophomore
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: I do not know much about Greek life on campus, but from what I have heard, despite the pledge not to haze, many fraternities and sororities still do so. I do not take part in much of Greek life, but it is prevalent on several campuses.
author: Sophomore
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: School spends too much money on athletics.
author: Sophomore
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: I get crime alerts all of the time. I feel safe during the day.
author: Junior
name: Rutgers University–New Brunswick

body: No one goes off campus because it is too dangerous and, quite frankly, not desirable.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: I would absolutely never live in Colorado Springs I cannot wait to get out of here. I hate this place so so so so much. It is horrible. I feel sorry for anyone who has to experience this place.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: It is SOOOOO HARD TO GET OFF CAMPUS WITHOUT A CAR!
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: There are a lot of drugs. Alcohol and Marijuana are all over, you just gotta know a few people and it's easy to get. Dorms smell of weed all the time, which is not wonderful.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: CC is extremely homogeneous. The visible majority of the student body are white, upper class, heterosexual, and democrats. However, people tend to be accepting of differing race, economic background, religion, sexual orientation, etc. Students and professors alike claim to be open-minded, but conservatives are received poorly. People stick to what they know, i.e. international students tend to hang out together. It takes effort to break the bubble within the CC bubble.
author: Junior
name: Colorado College

body:
The Crackdown has begun – CC used to be a liberal atmosphere with an administration which rarely concerned itself with open drug use. Just a little slap on the wrist and you were on your way. But now that CC has topped Princeton review's reefer madness list, the administration has set it sights on wiping the college completely off the chart. The campus cop got put on probation for hitting on girls in their dorm rooms and not following his conduct bi-laws as the rest of us have to. Since that point he has made it his personal priority to bust all drug dealers on campus, with the thought that if they are gone then nobody will smoke cannabis. In reality though, these kids will always smoke pot and do hard drugs, but that now they will have to go to Colorado Springs "townies" in order to acquire them. This might be a good time to add that there were three separate incidents of on-campus beatings and violence that occurred last year, which were delivered by some "townies." Are these the people you want to buy your cannabis from? 

Other than that, most students are unable to see how their drug use affects them, for it is bolstered by those in their clique. Since they rarely associate outside of that clique, they tend to use more frequently. There is heavy, HEAVY cocaine use by wealthy east-coasters, equally heavy psychedelic use by the majority of the campus, and I haven't met a single student who doesn't smoke. I'm sure there are those who don't use drugs, but I haven't found any.
author: Junior
name: Colorado College

body: White Wooks – If you don't know a wook is: a hippie without any ambition, motivation, or drive other than drugs and image, depend on an income other than their own, travel in packs (cliques). They differ from hippies in that hippies are generally seen as politically active, somewhat beneficial members of society; whereas a wook entails everything that people used to hate hippies for. (Above sampled from urban dictionary) There's no better way to describe them. There are rich east coast kids who blow cocaine every day while the rest smoke pot every day. The international students and other like myself seem to gaze upon these hedonistic people with contempt, asking why they are wasting $50,000 a year to do something they could do anywhere else.
author: Junior
name: Colorado College

body: I Need Some Explaination – There is a three year on campus living requirement, which, I believe, allows this money-hungry school to take more of your's. The residential coordinator is extremely unhelpful and closed to alternative possibilities. They have a mission, and expect you to follow along regardless of whether you agree or not. Most seniors this year decided to live on campus, consequently forcing juniors like myself out of apartment living, and into freshman dorms. Why? That I do not know. Perhaps they are not ready to assume more responsibility. I am assuming now that most freshman will be living in forced triples.
author: Junior
name: Colorado College

body: Why Bother? As I have now gone through two years of CC, I am strongly considering whether I should return or not. Frankly, it would not be for the social scene or the people there. The sororities hook up with the sports teams, which aren't even halfway decent to begin with. Those like me, the introverted, get singled out and shunned away from mostly extroverted people on campus. My close friends and I have found absolutely no woman worth our time. If you're out there, please tell me you exist behind that superficial image you project.
author: Junior
name: Colorado College

body: CC is not the most diverse place. Most are wealthy, white, liberal atheists. However, there ARE students who do not fit into those categories, and you can find them, although it may take awhile.
author: Senior
name: Colorado College

body: Nonexistent for the Most Part – There is no convenient public transportation in Colorado Springs, but there's not a big need for it. Almost everything you need you can get on campus. Shuttles from CC to the Denver airport are around $50.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: Dorm is small and definitely not worth it. Unfortunately it is required.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: We have a very white school without much socioeconomic diversity. That being said, no one is antagonized due to their background.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: If your parent's combined income is six figures, they will not give you any financial aid. It is incredibly hard to get a merit  based scholarship at my school. You have to be a genius-- a 36 on your ACT and a 4.5 gpa to get any awards. Other colleges offered me a substantial amount of merit based scholarship. Luckily, my parents have saved enough money to pay for all my tuition but I do not want them to have that financial burden. I'm trying to help my parent's with the tuition cost by applying for external scholarships and having a job.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: It is nearly impossible to receive merit based aid at this school.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: This school is great for liberal arts, but I don't know how much this will help me in the real world.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: I would never live in an off-campus house. Most of the houses are gross and not very well taken care of. I hear it is quite difficult to secure off-campus housing, but I have never personally tried. I love living on campus, and while you can save money on living off-campus, I love the dorms, small houses, and apartments and see no problem staying on campus as the quality of housing is great!
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: There are many foreign exchange students, especially from China, but not many minority Americans. Our campus is mostly made up of very liberal, rich, atheist, Caucasians.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: There aren't many options, and unless you're 21, there aren't any nearby clubs to go to except one country bar on Sundays.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: Not a really big community. They aren't snobby at all, mostly all about philanthropy. Not many kids are involved but the community is there if you need. Greek students are able to have friends outside their chapter too.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: Unless you plan to party at the houses you are out of luck
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: It is too hard to own a car and keep it unless you are rich.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: Colorado Springs is kind of a pain to get around without a car. I never had a car at CC, but thankfully my friends did - which made ski trips, buying groceries, going to interviews, etc actually possible.
author: Alum
name: Colorado College

body: Greek life is available if you want it, however I would say that it plays a really insignificant role on campus and in campus life.
author: Alum
name: Colorado College

body: Predominantly upper class white. The school is trying to address this (it was better this year) but lack of financial aid the school has at its disposable makes it a difficult and slow process
author: Senior
name: Colorado College

body: The students exist in a bubble and this can be very frustrating. Many of them are very disconnected from reality and closed-minded to the opinions and ideas outside CC. One-on-one they are insightful and honest thinkers, fun to discuss with. But in groups they are very obviously entitled and unintentionally judgemental.
author: Alum
name: Colorado College

body: Drug use permeates the campus, but many choose not to participate.  Almost any drug can be easily acquired.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: If you get caught there'll be some punishment including, fines, talks, and letters sent home. However, usually people don't get caught as long as their not being stupid.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado College

body: I feel as though a lot of students here get a liberal arts degree and don't end up using it.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: I don't know much about the Greek life, but they throw the most parties along with the sports houses.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: I don't pay much attention to sports at my school, but the workout facility is great.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: I personally feel relatively safe on campus. I have never been in a situation where I feel unsafe, however, I know many students who feel unsafe a lot of the time.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: Greek life is not big on campus, therefore many people do not know much about it. The people involved in Greek life put an emphasis on it and promote it, but other than that, it does not play a big role throughout campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: Some students are heavily involved with athletics, whether it be varsity sports or intramural teams, whereas other students are not involved at all. There is also a range of in between students. Athletics are not heavily promoted or pushed down the students throats. It is a very "come if you please" type of environment.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado College

body: Greek life is not a big part of campus life at our school.
author: Alum
name: Colorado College

body: Alumni network is thriving and those who know about CC have only good things to say about it. However, still not a ton of people know about the school and its demanding academics
author: Senior
name: Colorado College

body: We have a few division 1 sports and the division 3 sports are also popular. However, they are not a huge part of campus life and not going to games or not being interested is not uncommon.
author: Senior
name: Colorado College

body: The administration has way too much red-tape and has no idea what's going on, on campus. The school might actually run better without them.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: I went back to school after taking time after high school to work. This school is not helpful for people who transfer in from 2 year schools. Right now I'm fighting with financial aid to be able to borrow the money i need to get through this year. I graduate in 1.5 years, and yet the school is telling me I might need to take an entire year off and cross my fingers that there will be more money available next year.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: The administration is horrible because they are unaware, or ignore, the huge disconnect between what the school says it does and what it actually does. It says it gives the best engineering education in colorado. In reality, it encourages cheating over learning, and actually penalizes those who refuse to cheat.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: This school is set up for rich kids who at the drop of a hat can have thousands of dollars put towards their education. They offer kids who start as freshmen straight out of high school special grants etc. Meanwhile, non-traditional students get about 60% of their financial need met. After that they're on their own. Sometimes special loans will come out but for the most part the school doesn't care whether you can afford it or not because they know so many other richer people are clamoring to get in.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: This school is very bad at educating and teaching engineering students, but is also very, very good at marketing and leveraging its reputation as a good school to attract students. I ended up going here because I had heard and read that it was the very best engineering school in Colorado. As it turns out, I've only had two or three professors who I think were good professors. All of my other professors were very sub-par. Not only that, but the school has an unspoken policy of drowning students in excessive homework assignments. This forces students to strive for good grades and shirk understanding the concepts. This leads to mass cheating. When the institution throws ridiculous assignments at the students and sees completed work come back, they decide to make things incrementally harder. If you are not part of a group that cheats, you end up spending all of your time working your hardest and only earning C's and D's. The administration is too proud to accept this reality.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: I have never been to one.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: Only freshman housing on campus is available
author: Freshman
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: The administration at Mines is absolutely horrible, they all are very snotty and unhelpful. The RAs in my dorm were also not very good as mine didn't even know my name and falsely accused me of my life habits.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body:
Not enough parking spaces. Parking passes continue to increase in cost while the number of available spaces decreases. The largest lot, a gravel lot, is not well maintained and is full of huge sinkholes.

There are few-none security cameras. Parking fees are huge if you park in a space which you don't have the right permit for.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: Chemical engineering is infamously the most difficult major at CSM.  We work our butts off, and the time spend on school work can be quite overbearing.  If you want an easy life, be an environmental engineer.  Our classes are the most difficult at the school, and a lot of people switch out.  Our female percentage is slightly higher than the school average, so there are not very many creepy lonely men, like in the mining engineering department.  It does pay off in the end though, because we make ungodly amounts of money upon graduation.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: Financial aid is not one of Mines' strong points.  According to my FAFSA, I shouldn't be paying anything for school, but the financial aid office won't give me enough loans or grants, or point me towards any scholarship opportunities.  Most loans have to be co-signed by a parent.  So if your parent wants you to be independent, you have to go through a bank and deal with ridiculous interest.  My boyfriend went in to financial aid once a week for about three months to bug them before they would even give him a loan application.  The financial aid counselors are unhelpful and insulting, and people drop out of school all the time because they can't afford tuition.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: If you don't get financial aid when you apply, you're not going to get it after you get in the school. I am personally in the top 2% of my class, but because I didn't get a scholarship from high school, I am still receiving no financial aid despite trying constantly. If you get aid when you apply, you're set.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: Although Mines is located in Colorado the weather hardly ever affects classes. It is a miracle if classes do get cancelled so be prepared to tread through snow! The only downfall is exams may be scheduled around 6pm and driving/walking through the snow or rain at these times may be difficult. This campus is located on a hill so be careful when it is icy outside!However, when it is summer the weather is perfect! One can enjoy the sun at Kafadar commons which is where many students hang out, slack line, and play frisbee.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: If you want to park closer than a 10 minute walk to your car, you won't find a spot after 9:15. I have to leave 30 minutes before my class to make sure I get a spot, and I have a 5 minute drive to campus. There just aren't enough spots  close to class buildings, and sometimes not even enough spots at all. It can be faster to walk to class.
author: Senior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: There are very few places to park on campus - mainly because campus is so small for the volume of traditional and non-traditional students it harbors. Parking is near to  impossible to find, and they partition it based on types of parking. If you ever want a parking spot, you have to buy a General pass (most expensive), and get to class at least 30 minutes before if you drive. If you leave your car parked illegally for five minutes - expect to come back with a ticket. Driving isn't worth it - take the bus or get a place near enough to campus to walk.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body:
They Throw a Couple Ragers, but It's Nothing Like at Other Schools – Fraternities are either VERY geeky, or full of a mentality that women are just to be trophy wives and you're weird if you don't drink like a sailor or hook up. There are very kind and unique individual guys in Greek life as always, but it gets drowned in the overall vibe that they expel.

Sororities are not laid back at all - very stuck up, very bureaucratic, very political. It's a money suck: They'll fine you for anything, and the girls more often than not are friends by proximity and convenience than true friends. Granted - it's what you make of it, but from experience (I joined and quit), I can say that it's a poisonous environment.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: There is not enough parking at this school.  Freshman are required to park on campus, and so their cars take up all the spots.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: Transfer Students will not get any help other than students loans for the 4 years of study. One week before starting classes they raised Student Health Insurance according to the students age. If you are in the 40's or 50's you have to pay for you and your wife about $10,000 per year only in student health insurance which makes it in 4 years a total of $40,000 only for health insurance.  Financial Aid Office is arrogant and not helpful.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: No Scholarship or Internship for International Students. No scholarship or internship for international students.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: There are bus routes near the campus, but no way closed to the dorm.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: Unfortunately, my school isn't really known for the athletics. Most people are too stressed out with classes to attend events, but that doesn't mean the school tries to get people to come. I know other schools in colorado have a much better athletic program.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: eh. good greeks are few and fair between.
author: Senior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: the greek life is weird. its so small, and the school makes them do a bunch of random garbage. They have to be completely academic and a lot of the times are dry. The parties suck and aren't worth going to.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: Since Golden is a really small town, it can be hard to find housing close to campus AND at a decent price. It is not uncommon to be paying $700 dollars a month for rent, for a house that is 15 minutes driving distance. There are, although, a few great houses nearby that (if you are lucky enough) can get them if you know the people living there.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: The dorm that I stayed in had very lenient policies on drinking; or at least, that's what it seemed like to me because my neighbors would constantly get drunk and even though the floor assistant saw them drunk, they wouldn't do anything about it. This affected me personally because I don't like being around these kind of people, but nothing aggressive or super bad ever happened so it's fine.
author: Sophomore
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: The school consists of mostly young students, so there's nothing going on for the older more mature community.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: It's hard to get healthy cost-effective options.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: The off-campus housing scene is challenging because there are so many working professionals here and so many rich kids here. The prices have sky-rocketed so it's very very difficult to find a good place at a good price. It's not uncommon to pay $3,000/mo for a house or $1,000 for a single bedroom.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: I hear from traditional students that the party scene is mostly non-existent. Many kids are into video games and that sort of thing, and plus everyone's weighed down with homework so it's hard for them to have any real fun.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: there is something going on on the weekends if you know who to talk to, but the the bars are the best place to go for hanging out.
author: Senior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: it's pretty bad but the shining glory are Einstein's bagels in the morning, and digger den at late night, but they shut that down contrary to what the students have requested. It is nutrition and thats about it
author: Senior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: You easily forget that there is Greek life.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: The degree programs they've put together are restrictive and impossible to work around.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: The food is not bad, but the number of locations where it is available are very minimal and have poor selection. Subway is the only useful option.
author: Junior
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: It is a lot of work to find off campus housing and it is usually quite expensive.
author: Freshman
name: Colorado School of Mines

body: There are only a handful of varsity sports teams at Emory and no one pays attention to them. The majority of Emory students graduate having never attended a sporting event. The intramurals are relatively well participated in, especially considering how anti-athletics Emory is. There's no football team which really is sad. The lack of interest in sports makes for a absence of school spirit on campus.
author: Freshman
name: Emory University

body: After being here for 2 years, the administration has taken all the fun out of being in a fraternity, from restricting beer pong, to basically doing anything that would be deemed fun. It is sad to see the social culture of Emory go downhill because of restrictions by the university. The only thing that makes Greek Life worth it is the people, but without the ability to express yourself and do things in your own house, the entire idea of being in a fraternity becomes pointless. Emory Administration get that stick out your a$$
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: It changes frequently without any warning.
author: Freshman
name: Emory University

body: Parking is a pain. The yearly pass is well over 700 at this point, parking in some "unmarked" spot is risky, there are boot-ers all over the place and common areas- even local restaurants. Your best bet though is to pay for the parking, or leave your car off campus and use the emory shuttles.
author: Alum
name: Emory University

body: Parking is horrible...you must get there 30-45 minutes early because you have to take a shuttle ariund campus
author: Alum
name: Emory University

body: I received much less financial aid than expected this year. My expected family contribution increased by $12,000 and my financial aid adviser was hard to get in touch with and extremely unhelpful.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: way too expensive. Should be free considering how much we pay for everything else!
author: Senior
name: Emory University

body: Emory's cuts this year are ridiculous. They've cut majors lots of people were interested in like journalism, educational studies, visual arts, etc... There's so much focus on science and business here. Be careful if you're looking for anything else
author: Freshman
name: Emory University

body: Emory students have license do whatever they please.
author: Freshman
name: Emory University

body: Parking on campus is ridiculously expensive on top of the total expense to go to Emory. It is also very limited, so you can end up with a parking space on the Clairmont campus even if you don't live on Clairmont, causing you to have to park and take a shuttle back to main campus.
author: Junior
name: Emory University

body: Why So Expensive – Emory is expensive enough as it is.  Freshman year you cannot even have your car on campus.  Parking is 660 per year and sometimes you cannot even find a parking spot.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: WAY overpriced. I feel taken advantage of. When costs are this high it does not seem fair that so many people seem to get away with parking in lots where they are not permitted to do so.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: I majored in Neuroscience and Behavioral Biology and my degree means diddly squat. I cannot get any jobs with this degree. I have to get a masters in Neuroscience to get a decent 6 figure job. After I graduated, I had to settle for a job as a medical scribe, but I am going back to school to get my Masters in Global Public Health.
author: Alum
name: Emory University

body: On campus parties are lame. Better to go off-campus.
author: Alum
name: Emory University

body: It's somewhat annoying that financial aid amounts are not as large as they should be
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: No matter what they say it's not guaranteed that 100% of your need will be met. If the original package they offer isn't enough you have to go to the office a thousand times before they finally find another loan for you.
author: Freshman
name: Emory University

body: Not enough fun parties around here.
author: Freshman
name: Emory University

body: I honestly feel like no one cares about any sports here.
author: Senior
name: Emory University

body: There needs to be a football team.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: Haven't received much financial aid whatsoever.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: Not very active at all as far as parties.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: I did not receive any financial aid from the school and I need some
author: Freshman
name: Emory University

body: Not having a football team limits our school spirit. But we have basketball, baseball, etc.
author: Junior
name: Emory University

body: I do not eat in the dining hall.......bad.
author: Alum
name: Emory University

body: They do not give you enough aid.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: I don't like the food here.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: The policies that this school have bordered on the outrageous at times, where oftentimes even the slightest amounts of noise can get you in trouble.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: The biggest complaints most people have towards the internet is how slow it can become and how frequently it drops. This kind of stuff should not be happening at a major university, especially one of this magnitude.
author: Sophomore
name: Emory University

body: If Greek life didn't exist on Fsu's campus I feel I would have enjoyed my time here a lot more. Greek life allows for this atmosphere of hierarchy and self-entitlement that I do not agree with nor do I support.
author: Senior
name: Florida State University

body: They get away with crimes.
author: Senior
name: Florida State University

body: I hate living on campus, my stuff is moldy for no reason and they lied about the spacious living conditions in Landis. They are way over priced and force me to buy an expensive meal plan that I do not use AT ALL. Such a waste of my money.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: The topic of money is one that is always relevant when i speak to my parents on the phone. Financial aid is the hardest part about being in college. I would take all of the hardest classes on campus in exchange for not dealing with financial aid.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: I am not offered enough money as an out-of-state I don't think.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: If you do not get in one of the few good dorms you are stuck in a cramped dirty room. My friend had mold growing all over her things in Smith Hall.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: then i'm ok with living with i'm offerd
author: Senior
name: Florida State University

body: none of the greek are  in the school
author: Senior
name: Florida State University

body: I didn't get any scholarships. I am paying almost all of it out of pocket and I really didnt get any grants.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: Greek life is stupid and a ripoff. You will be paying for your "friends" that are all backstabbers and fake.
author: Alum
name: Florida State University

body: Parking is free on campus, but it's basically a fight to the death to get a spot. The on campus police constantly give out tickets which sucks because sometimes students have no choice but to park somewhere they're not supposed to. You don't really need a car because there is on campus and public transportation.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: Campus and city buses are terrible. They don't stick to their schedule so you have to arrive 30 min-an hour before you need to be somewhere. Buses are always breaking down which means the replacement bus can't be tracked on the TransLoc app. I am constantly missing buses because they are totally UNRELIABLE. However you pay the transportation fee online.
author: Senior
name: Florida State University

body: Still trying to get aid
author: Sophomore
name: Florida State University

body: Recently my father passed away and I lost half my income and the school did not want to give me any aid or grants when the year before i was given aid with 2 incomes. Their reasoning for not giving me aid was because I have Bright Futures. Bright Futures is a scholarship that I earned, not aid.
author: Sophomore
name: Florida State University

body: FSU is ranked the #1 party school in America...need I say more? I don't partake, but it is very noticeable especially with anyone involved in FSU's vibrant Greek life.
author: Sophomore
name: Florida State University

body: You basically have to drink to fit in.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: I am not a fan of greek life.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: They tend to have all the same personality, the girls are barbies and the guys are jerks.
author: Junior
name: Florida State University

body: Buildings are old with mold and leaks. Rooms are very small and community bathrooms are always disgusting. Rent is over $800 a month for a room a little bigger than a closet, shared with another person.  FSU finally tore down one of the worst buildings but the rest are still barely up to par.
author: Senior
name: Florida State University

body: Sexual assault is an issue that college administrators want to shove under the rug but it is a real problem and if the administrators cracked down on sexual assault it would show potential parents that they care rather than there never being a sexual assault on campus which everyone knows is false
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: Dorm life is terrible. Smith should have been demolished ages ago and if you have a clean room, you probably have an awful roommate.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: There have been multiple sexual assaults on campus while I attended FSU. There was also a gunman my first semester at the library. Also, many attempted abductions have happened near and on the outer edges of campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Florida State University

body: Considering the fact that I spent my first year in the oldest dorm on campus, I did not enjoy campus housing at all. I was in a dorm that was built in 1941. Smith hall was community style living. I lived on the 10th floor which meant I had to take a flight of stairs because the elevator did not go that high. Many of my friends who lived in the building had cockroaches in their rooms along with mold and mildew. To be honest, this residence hall was a huge health hazard and should not have been open. When I tried to switch halls, Florida State denied me the opportunity due to a housing "overload" so I was stuck living in Smith Hall for the entirety of my freshman year.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: It costs a lot compared to the much nicer apartments just a mile from campus. You never know who you'll get paired with roommate wise either.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: I didn't get the worst dorm on campus but I still really dislike it. The amenities in Bryan Hall are pretty clean but my room is a closet in terms of space. It's very difficult to move around in there with my roommate. Also I never see my RA and people do not adhere to the rules about noise at all. Almost every night I'm calling down to the front desk to ask the RA on hand to get people to be quiet and it works for all of five minutes and the RA never follows up on it. Furthermore, when I brought these problems up to my floor RA she did nothing about it and so I'm very upset by that. I have many tests that I need to sleep for. I usually spend more time sleeping in my friend's dorm than I do mine.
author: Freshman
name: Florida State University

body: I lived on campus one year and it was okay. Wouldn't recommend it but everyone basically lives off anyway.
author: Senior
name: Florida State University

body: For students under 21 it's pretty much nonexistent. There's one bar in town that seems to enjoy having Carleton students around, but it's fairly hard to get in if you're underage. Even if you are 21, it's not that great.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: We don't have Greek life on campus at Carleton College, which is absolutely fine by me.
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: No merit scholarships offered, so it's hard for me to pay.
author: Freshman
name: Carleton College

body: No Greek life. I'm grateful for this, since Greek life can mess with a college's culture. However, there is interest housing which I think fulfills a lot of what Greek life aims to offer.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: Very Limited Options – Only a few lucky seniors are able to get draw numbers high enough to live off campus. Carleton also wants to limit the amount of off campus housing in the future. Boo. At least you're close to campus.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: You're Still in Business? The restaurants here are painfully subpar.  Nothing is awful but I have yet to be impressed anywhere.  Come on, it's a college town, can we get ONE decent restaurant?  I'd be willing to pay a little extra.
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: Luck of the Draw – you can't live off campus unless you have a high number in the room draw lottery system.  only 15 numbers or something can live off campus.
author: Junior
name: Carleton College

body: Food Poisoning – I had food poisoning three times while eating at the dining hall.
author: Alum
name: Carleton College

body: Athletics really aren't a huge priority here. Frisbee is probably the most popular sport.
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: People are accepting but diversity is pretty limited. 10% international students means, what? 50 kids a year right. It's Minnesota so white is to be expected, but pretty much everyone here is from the 'burbs.' Ethnic diversity is kind of sad but understandable.There are a lot of different political beliefs, but they aren't explicit. Everyone here is accepted no matter who they are or where they come from, theres pretty much a group on campus for everything, but that doesn't stop diversity from being not great.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: It is pretty isolated, and in a small town, so there is not much going on past 10 off campus
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: very cold. expect snow in may.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: Nightlife, HA! Partying is limited to weekends and once during the middle of the week. Our motto is work hard, play hard. When we do get together, we make up for lost time. However, often the party is dead by 1 or 2. That's what you get in a small town. One bar only. Most gathering are 5-10 close friends drinking and playing some games.
author: Junior
name: Carleton College

body: There are just not many low-cost options to get places. While Northfield Lines is very good about break buses, on a normal day if you just want to hang out in the Twin Cities and/or Mall of America you have limited options at very bad times. You can't park here, so that's out the window. Taking a taxi/shuttle will cost you dear. So if your flight getting back to campus is late and you miss the last Northfield Line bus you might end up very screwed booking a First Choice Shuttle last minute (if you're even early enough to book) and drop a large amount of cash, or just take a taxi and drop perhaps even more cash. The one redeeming quality is the frequency of Target buses.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: Decent, but Gets Old and Is Really Expensive! (And Mandatory...) – The dining hall isn't horrible, but it gets old fast. While they have good ideas about certain things (sustainability, for one), and they are decent at food prep and cooking, the part that always bothered me was the cost. There is no good option for students who live on campus but don't want to eat in the dining hall all the time (as it gets really, really old after about a year). If you want that option, you have to choose to have 12 meals a week, but you don't get compensated enough "dining dollars" to make up for it.
author: Alum
name: Carleton College

body: Grading Horrible – Grading scheme is horrible. Professors dont explain properly
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: Northfield Is Small – Dining options in town are very limited.  The food is nothing to complain about -- Hogan Bros. has awesome sandwiches, El Triunfo's Mexican food is great, there's a Chapati and a couple of Chinese restaurants, plus your usual fast food -- but you run out of options pretty quickly.
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: Rigid Administration – The main thing that frustrates me at Carleton is that we have a bunch of bureaucracy that has gotten in my way.  There are strict policies when it comes to declaring a major or requirements.  Most people never come up against these rules, but if you want or need to do something a little different, it's a bit of a battle with the administration.  However, the professors are amazing when it comes to individual attention and support and the other students are open-minded.
author: Junior
name: Carleton College

body: I am from a very VERY caucasian town, so I believe that diversity at Carleton is ok.  However, I gather that many people do not agree, and they are probably more qualified to comment on the diversity than I am.
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: Difficulty in Breaking Through – There are people of many different races at Carleton and the literature portrays them as intermingling at will, but at times it is difficult to integrate oneself into groups where the common bond is a shared international culture. At the beginning of the school year, for example, Carleton hosts International Student Orientation about a week before other students arrive, so by the time new students arrive, the International students have already solidified friendships and closed themselves off to other avenues of interaction. This is not the only example, however.
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: It Doesn't Get Colder Than This – It is so cold that you can't be outside for more than 5 minutes. Anything longer than that and you will feel needles piercing through your skin all over. Getting way below 0 degrees is commonplace and snow days don't exist.
author: Junior
name: Carleton College

body: People do not care about varsity sports, but many people do participate in intramural sports.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: The rec center is very nice and well-equipped. We also have a state of the art climbing/bouldering facility.
author: Freshman
name: Carleton College

body: Usually parties are between cliques on campus, with a few club sport progressives. Other than that, they're nothing much.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: Diversity here is okay. The school has a crazy liberal bias and if you're not an ultra-liberal, prepared to be called a "racist" or "sexist" rather quickly. Ethnic diversity is lacking, but that's rather common among top liberal arts colleges. Economic diversity is slightly better, and there is also a vibrant LGBT community as well.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: If you don't drink it's a bit difficult to have fun Friday nights, unfortunately. While the students try to make partying inclusive, it is predominantly based on drunken revelry.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: Job and internship prospects are decent, but the Career Center is only useful for a select number of fields. The alumni network is pretty great, but recruiters are practically non-existent. Students should expect to fend for themselves a lot of the time, but a Carleton degree seems relatively well-regarded.
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: Room draw is a pain in the ass, an there are definitely some places that are better than others to live. Nonetheless, people generally deal with their housing
author: Junior
name: Carleton College

body: Because it's a D3 school, sports aren't huge. They somewhat influence the formation of social groups, but people generally branch out
author: Junior
name: Carleton College

body: There are a couple of chill bars/pubs in town, but nightlife only really exists in the cities. Town is within 5 minute walking distance. Minneapolis is a little bit more complicated. The Cave and Froggies are pretty great for dancing, others are good for a chill beer with friends.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: If you're coming to Carleton, unless its for frisbee, it probably isn't for the sports. Varsity athletics isn't really a noticeable part of campus life unless you partake in them in which case they provide a lot of good structure. People don't realy pay attention to varsity here but they appreciate it. Club sports are considered pretty similarly to Varsity, while Varsity tends to be more insular simply because of the amount of time teams spend together, Club sports are close because they regularly throw socials, or want to be close. Nobody really takes sports here that seriously except for secret die-hards, but IM sports are frequently joined for fun. Sports health facilities prioritize varsity and are disorganized but manageable.
author: Sophomore
name: Carleton College

body: Housing varies at Carleton College from the awful Musser which is very cold in the winter and students get sick from the leaky windows to the beautiful Burton which is a lovely dorm.
author: Senior
name: Carleton College

body: I don't have much experience with this yet, but I think it will go okay.
author: Freshman
name: Carleton College

body: I feel very safe on campus and generally campus security is there in case of an emergency.
author: Freshman
name: Carleton College

body: Sports aren't too big on campus, but facilities are sufficient for use.
author: Freshman
name: Carleton College

body: The BA from a liberal arts school doesn't go towards much, but graduating from Carleton with high grades in prestigious
author: Junior
name: Carleton College

body: I live on White Creek and it should be off campus.
author: Freshman
name: Texas A&M University

body: I haven't received any financial aid or scholarships despite having a GPA ranging between 3.75 and 4.0 my entire college career and receiving large scholarships at other institutions previously to attending A&M.
author: Senior
name: Texas A&M University

body: You'll find people of all sorts, of every culture, background, and social group, but only in small amounts. A&M is largely conservative, Christian, and white. There is not much diversity. In general, people are not very accepting towards other religions, races, political beliefs, or sexual orientations. The student body is very narrow minded and racist
author: Sophomore
name: Texas A&M University

body: In my opinion, the financial aid is poor. I did not receive any help from the school or from the government.
author: Sophomore
name: Texas A&M University

body: I didn't receive any financial aid. That's why I'm looking for outside scholarships, because I really can't afford to pay for my entire tuition without help

name: Texas A&M University

body: The financial aid process is tedious and difficult, and it is so hard for someone with a majority ethnicity to get any help at all.
author: Sophomore
name: Texas A&M University

body: Bryan/College Station is a terrible place to have to spend your college life, if it weren't for the university then this place would a be nothing more than a McDonalds/restroom pit stop on the highway.  There isn't anything to do here that isn't A&M related.  Some Texas country artists come to play at Harry's, but the rest of the live music scene is dead.  The worst part, because the town is only existent because of A&M no new businesses succeed here so when the students leave for summer the shops, restaurants, attractions, etc. go under and you're left with little variety.  The food selection here is absolutely horrible, if all you want is strip mall Mexican food, Chinese buffets, or chain restaurants that are littered all over then the food will satisfy you to no end.
author: Sophomore
name: Texas A&M University
